The Colockum Tarps Fire near Wenatchee has blackened more than 25,000 acres of parched grass, brush and undergrowth and destroyed three homes since it began on July 27.  The Mile Marker 28 fire has charred more than 20,000 acres of timberland and shrub in Klickitat County since it began on July 24.  Both fires have required the evacuation of more than 65 homes each.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 30, 2013
Places: Washington, Chelan County, WA, Klickitat County, WA

Title: Water supplies short in Texas
Description: At least a dozen water districts in Texas are within 45 days of running out of water, while another dozen have about 90 days’ worth of water left.  The 109 Texas lakes that provide drinking water were at their lowest average storage for this time of year at 64 percent.  Rivers and lakes are reaching their lowest levels for this time of year since 1990 after record drought in 2011 dramatically reduced water supplies.  Roughly 22 percent of the 4,660 public water suppliers in Texas have voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), July 24, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought, heat, lightning strikes lead to wildfires in Idaho
Description: Much of the southern two-thirds of Idaho was dry, hot and has been hit by a number of lightning strikes, leading to many wildfires.  The 210 Road Fire burned less than a square mile of lodgepole pine and brush south of Stanley in Custer County.  The Ridge Fire blackened nearly 6 square miles north of Lowman in Boise County since it started from a lightning strike.  The Lodgepole Fire began on July 20 and charred nearly 2 square miles near Challis in Custer County.  The Brown Butte Fire has consumed 11 square miles near Shoshone in Lincoln County and was nearly completely contained.  On July 23, more than 1,000 firefighters were battling 11 fires in the region. Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), July 23, 2013
Places: Idaho, Boise County, ID, Custer County, ID, Lincoln County, ID

Title: Nebraska firefighters preparing for another challenging wildfire season
Description: Nebraska state and local fire officials are bracing for another fire season like the challenging one in 2012 when 1,570 wildfires burned 786 square miles, according to the Nebraska Emergency Management Agency.  The state contracted a single-engine firefighting plane and has plans for additional training to help local firefighters meet national emergency response standards.  Much of the state continues to be plagued by drought in 2013 as it was in 2012.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), July 22, 2013

Title: Many conflicts over water use in Colorado
Description: Disputes over water have skyrocketed in Colorado where water is at a premium during drought.  There has been enough contention in Montezuma County in southwestern Colorado for the sheriff to appoint a water deputy to mediate and enforce during squabbles over water.  The deputy has received 20 to 30 calls daily of late, although before the drought, there were maybe four or five calls.  The Montezuma Valley Irrigation Co.'s water commissioner in Cortez often gets 20 to 30 calls before his morning coffee break.  Irrigators sometimes find newly shoveled ditches or catch someone in the act of diverting water.   In one part of Montezuma County, a dozen water users share a ditch, depend on the honor system to regulate water use and have a lot of conflict over water.Water customers in the Dolores Water Conservancy District, including farmers, ranchers, the Ute Mountain Ute tribe and a fishery, received only 25 percent of usual allotments during a shortened season.  Pressured meters track water use, which cuts down on water disputes.In southeastern Colorado, there are fewer disputes over water because there is no water to fight over, said the manager of the Fort Lyon Canal Co.  The Arkansas River and its tributaries are so low that nearly three-quarters of the 93,000 acres that usually receive water from the Fort Lyon Canal Co. did not get water this year, meaning that there wasn’t much sense in planting crops.  Denver Post (Colo.), July 21, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Arkansas farmers urged to prepare for drought
Description: The associate head-Animal Science for the University of Arkansas System Division of Agriculture urged farmers to prepare for worsening drought by checking pastures for overgrazing, preparing to cull herds and being on the alert for excessive accumulations of nitrate and prussic acid in plants with drought taking hold in the state.  Fort Smith Southwest Times Record (Ark.), July 21, 2013

Title: Dry wetlands in Kansas not welcoming to birds
Description: Recent rains have replenished water supplies at many wetlands.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), Aug. 11, 2013Kansas hunters may not be able to take advantage of the above average duck population noted by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service.  Drought has dried up most wetlands in the state, which will not encourage ducks to spend much time in Kansas before moving on to more welcoming regions.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas), July 20, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Reduced almond crop yield in California
Description: Hot, dry weather led USDA-NASS to revise their objective estimate of the almond crop downward by 7.5 percent to 1.85 billion pounds.  Western Farm Press, July 19, 2013

Title: Hay and grazing land in Kansas
Description: Kansas counties with D2 or worse drought are eligible to hay and graze CRP land through August 15.  High Plains Journal (KS), July 19, 2013

Title: Fire officials in Arizona warn outdoor enthusiasts to extinguish campfires thoroughly
Description: Fire officials in Arizona warn outdoor enthusiasts to extinguish campfires thoroughly because forests remain very dry, despite the start of the monsoon.  The Kaibab, Prescott and Tonto forests lifted their fire restrictions on July 17 with the advent of the monsoon.  Arizona Republic (Phoenix) & AZCentral.com (Ariz.), July 21, 2013

Title: Emergency haying and grazing approved in 54 Nebraska counties
Description: Fifty-four of Nebraska’s 93 counties were authorized for emergency haying and grazing on Conservation Reserve Program acres for 2013 because drought has damaged pastures.  Some of the counties included are Boone, Custer, Garfield, Greeley, Howard, Loup, Merrick, Nance, Valley and Wheeler.  The authorization for emergency haying and grazing came at the end of the primary nesting and brood rearing season in the state.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), July 17, 2013

Title: Two Kansas senators push for emergency haying and grazing on Conservation Reserve Program lands
Description: U.S. Senators Pat Roberts (R-Kan.) and Jerry Moran (R-Kan.) requested emergency haying and grazing on Conservation Reserve Program lands to aid livestock producers who need additional forage for their animals while drought has decreased pasture production.  Wisconsin Ag Connection (Marshfield, Wis.), July 12, 2013

Title: Reduced wheat harvest in Colorado
Description: From the USDA’s June forecast to this month’s forecast, the winter wheat harvest estimate was downgraded 18 percent to 49.5 million bushels, which would be 33 percent less than the 2012 harvest.  Colorado Springs Gazette (CO), July 12, 2013
Places: Colorado, Denver, CO, Colorado Springs, CO

Title: Drought, other factors limited the grasshopper population in Colorado
Description: Drought, pesticide and fungus from a cold, wet spring have lowered the number grasshoppers in Colorado to about 3 per square yard, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Test areas in the previous two years had roughly 17 grasshoppers per square yard.  A field-crop entomologist at Colorado State University said, "The drought depleted their resources, so we've seen a big turnaround."  The Denver Post (Colo.), July 11, 2013

Title: Dry conditions in Texas limited or prevented Rio Grande turkeys from reproducing
Description: Dry conditions in Texas limited or prevented Rio Grande turkeys from mating, breeding and nesting, which is usually at its height in March and April.  Hens’ physical condition was too poor for successful reproduction, and there was not enough nesting cover, due to inadequate rainfall.  In late May through the start of June, rain fell and improved range and habitat conditions.  Some of the turkeys made a successful, albeit late, nesting effort.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), July 11, 2013

Title: Indiana's trees dying due to drought
Description: About 50 percent of Indiana’s poplar trees were damaged by drought, said a Department of Natural Resources plant pathologist.  WFIU-FM (IN), July 8, 2013

Title: Hay supplies tight in Colorado; horse owners cannot afford hay
Description: Drought has cut the amount of hay able to be grown in Colorado, driving hay prices higher.  Many horse owners have no choice but to sell them, euthanize them or send the animals to Mexico or Canada for slaughter.   The chief of Colorado's Bureau of Animal Protection said that the price of hay, which used to cost $120 per ton, sells for $250 to $350 per ton.  A horse owner from Kiowa surrendered three horses this past year because drought prevented her from growing hay to feed her horses.  High hay prices have pushed many horse owners to sell their animals, which has driven down the price of horses so that even good horses only bring $100 to $125 at auction.  Denver Post (Colo.), July 7, 2013

Title: Fireworks, fire restrictions for most Utah counties
Description: The Utah state forester enacted fireworks restrictions for 18 of the 29 counties in the state, due to the unusually dry weather expected to last through the next several weeks.  The fireworks restrictions make it illegal to light fireworks in the unincorporated parts of the 18 counties, including Sevier, Wayne, Piute and Sanpete.  The restrictions will remain in effect until further notice.  Additional fire restrictions prohibiting open burning, smoking outside of an enclosed vehicle, building or developed recreation area and other activities took effect in Garfield, Beaver, Carbon, Emery, Grand, Iron, Kane, San Juan and Washington counties, due to drought and the elevated fire risk.   Richfield Reaper (Utah), July 7, 2013

Title: The state of California has spent $130 million of its emergency fund on firefighting expenses
Description: The state of California has spent $130 million of its emergency fund on firefighting expenses since July 2013, and Cal Fire anticipates needing another $82 million by the end of June.  Over 1,200 wildfires—more than double the five-year average—have burned in the state since the start of the year.Los Angeles Times, May 5, 2014

Title: Many New Mexico communities banned some or all fireworks
Description: Across New Mexico, many counties and communities have banned some or all fireworks, due to the elevated fire danger brought by drought, strong winds and dry vegetation.  Officials urged the public to attend professional displays rather than lighting their own fireworks.  Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), June 29, 2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: New Mexico, Santa Fe County, NM

Title: Fires and drought classifications in Colorado
Description: Dust storms, fires and fire bans in the area, southwest area has increased it's drought classification from "severe" to "extreme".
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Wildfires raging in New Mexico are charring acres of remaining grazing land, forcing ranchers to move cattle out of state
Description: Wildfires raging in New Mexico are charring acres of remaining grazing land, forcing ranchers to move cattle out of state.  A range resource specialist with the New Mexico Department of Agriculture explained, “There are poor range conditions statewide.  Finding grass that doesn't have some cattle on it or some areas of rangeland that haven't been destocked because there's just no grass left is nearly impossible in New Mexico."  Agriculture officials have contacted the U.S. Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management in an effort to find public or private land where cattle might graze.  Drought led forest officials to curb the number of livestock in the Gila National Forest, while the Silver Fire drove at least 150 cattle from an allotment.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), June 25, 2013
Places: New Mexico, Grant County, NM, Sierra County, NM

Title: Nebraska farmers with hay for sale were urged to list it on the state hay hotline
Description: Nebraska farmers with hay for sale were urged to list it on the state hay hotline to help ranchers who need hay find it, said Nebraska Agriculture Director Greg Ibach.  He noted that the state was entering its second year of drought, and hay supplies may be scarce.  The number for the hay hotline is 1-800-422-6692.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), June 22, 2013

Title: Vegetation in New Mexico dangerously dry, compared to Colorado where wildfires were burning
Description: The mayor of Ruidoso noted the difference between the color of vegetation in Colorado and that of New Mexico.  He referenced the Black Forest fire that consumed more than 300 homes in Colorado and described the greenness of the plant life in Colorado, in comparison with the worse-looking vegetation in New Mexico, which he termed as ”scary” with respect to the fire danger.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 21, 2013

Title: New Mexico agencies strive to bring water to wildlife
Description: Two state agencies and a nonprofit organization are working together to bring water to New Mexico’s thirsty wildlife during the drought.  The New Mexico Department of Game and Fish donated $40,000 to the New Mexico Department of Agriculture (NMDA) to assist ranchers with the added costs of pumping and transporting water during drought.  Wildlife benefit from water sources for cattle, so the assistance to ranchers will help wildlife.  The funds will move from the NMDA to the New Mexico Association of Conservation Districts, a nonprofit organization representing the state’s 47 soil and water conservation districts.  New Mexico ranchers will be eligible for up to $350 to help defray the costs of hauling or pumping water.  KOB-TV NBC 4 (Albuquerque, N.M.), June 19, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: More animals are being struck by vehicles in New Mexico
Description: More animals are being struck by vehicles in New Mexico, particularly in Albuquerque’s East Mountains, noted officials with the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish.  In the past few days, two deer and a bear were hit by vehicles.  Drought is likely the reason the animals are out on the move.  "When you get these animals up around looking for water, looking for food, they will start crossing roads," says Game and Fish spokesman.  Elk, deer, javelina, bears and antelope are some of the animals struck by cars recently.  KRQE-TV CBS 13 (Albuquerque, N.M.), June 19, 2013

Title: Hay cost $280 per ton in Iowa
Description: The price of alfalfa hay in Iowa reached $280 per ton in June 2013 as the 2012 drought reduced hay supplies, according to records kept by the University of Wisconsin.Rainfall over the summer of 2013 increased hay production, finally ending the drastic hay shortage in the region that began in late 2011 when hay growers shipped much of their excess hay to Texas after the state endured a blistering summer that dried up crops.  The northern Plains were gripped by drought in 2012, leaving farmers looking great distances to find hay.  Contributing to the hay shortage, farmers also planted more corn in hopes of turning a good profit rather than planting hay.  Mason City Globe-Gazette (Iowa), Sept. 23, 2013

Title: Drought levels and dry soil in Southwest Colorado and central New Mexico.
Description: Southwest Colorado upgraded from D1 to D4 drought condition, dry soil being blown away, hurting agriculture.
Places: Dolores County, CO, La Plata County, CO, Montezuma County, CO, Cortez, CO, San Juan County, CO, New Mexico

Title: Governor of New Mexico urged local governments to restrict fireworks
Description: Gov. Susana Martinez requested that local governments in New Mexico to move quickly to restrict fireworks, due to drought and the elevated fire danger.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), June 11, 2013

Title: Twenty percent of the wheat acreage in Colorado a total loss
Description: Twenty percent of the wheat acreage in Colorado is a total loss, according to the executive director of the Colorado Association of Wheat Growers.  He also noted that the figure could reach 30 percent by next month.  A survey by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service during the first week of June revealed that 60 percent of wheat farmers described their crop condition as poor to very poor.  At this time in 2012, only 23 percent of the wheat crop was in poor to very poor condition.  Kiowa County has no viable wheat crop, according to an area farmer, who stated, “It's the worst I've ever seen.  We are at zero. We will have absolutely no wheat crop. The entire county is full of dead wheat fields."  Drought damaged the wheat crop, which was ultimately killed by late spring freezes.  Denver Post (Colo.), June 6, 2013

Title: West Fork Complex fire burned 124 square miles in southern Colorado
Description: The West Fork Complex fires in southwestern Colorado scorched 124 square miles after several lightning-sparked wildfires merged to form an enormous wildfire in the San Juan Mountains of southern Colorado.  The fires have not destroyed any structures and continue to burn drought-stricken, beetle-killed trees.  Initially, firefighters were not optimistic about being able to prevent the tourist town of South Fork from burning, but were successful in protecting the town.  A June 5 lightning strike ignited a fire in the San Juan Mountains west of the Continental Divide, while another lightning strike sparked another fire east of the divide.  Lightning started another fire near Creede, after which the wildfires were termed the West Fork Complex.  Many other wildfires burned across Colorado.  Boise Idaho Statesman (Idaho), June 25, 2013
Places: Colorado, Mineral County, CO, Rio Grande County, CO

Title: New public service announcement to encourage continued water conservation in Texas
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality urged the public to continue conserving water in a public service announcement featuring country music singer Kevin Fowler.  He sings “Take Care of Texas” on a riverbank.  The PSA encourages the public to enjoy outdoor recreation and to take care of the environment.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), June 4, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Emergency grazing on CRP acres authorized in 192 Texas counties
Description: One hundred ninety-two Texas counties are eligible for emergency grazing on Conservation Reserve Program land for the 2013 fiscal year,  effective June 2 through the next 90 days.  Only lands that were not hayed or grazed in 2011, 2012 or the fall or winter of FY 2013 may be approved for use.  The Farm Service Agency's fiscal year begins on Oct. 1.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), June 7, 2013

Title: Cargill's profits down 19 percent, partially due to drought
Description: Cargill, producer of food and agricultural products, saw a 12 percent decline in its net earnings of $424 million for the fourth quarter, ending May 31, compared to $483 million for the fourth quarter in 2013.  Revenue, however, was up 2 percent for the quarter to $36.2 billion, in comparison with $35.4 billion in 2013.  The drop in fourth quarter earnings can be traced to adjustments the company made to cope with Venezuela’s change in currency exchange rates.Cargill’s profits for the year were $1.87 billion, 19 percent lower than last year.  The decrease occurred due to China’s rejection of some U.S. corn shipments, drought in the U.S. in 2013 and higher transportation expenses related to the rail car shortage.Twin Cities Business (Minneapolis, Minn.), Aug. 7, 2014

Title: June feedlot placements in Kansas were 9 percent lower
Description: June feedlot placements in Kansas were 9 percent lower than they were in June 2012, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, as drought continues to hurt cattle operations in the state by limiting pasture and water supplies.  There were 5 percent fewer Kansas cattle sold to slaughter.  The total feedlot population decreased 2 percent in June, compared to June 2012 and was the lowest since 1994.  Farmers need improved pasture conditions and replenished stock ponds before they can begin rebuilding their cattle herds.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), July 29, 2013

Title: Sharp-tailed grouse and partridge populations down in North Dakota
Description: The sharp-tailed grouse and partridge populations were down in North Dakota due to snow, rain, drought and habitat losses.  The late-summer survey showed that sharp-tailed grouse numbers were lower than the spring survey indicated.  Brood results were down 50 percent and indicate that the grouse population was down 51 percent across the state.  Bismarck Tribune (N.D.), Sept. 12, 2013

Title: Many California farmers producing more, using less water with drip-tape
Description: Drought and limited water allocations pushed California farmers to seek more efficient ways to irrigate their crops.  Some farmers plant crops that need less water, store excess water in groundwater reserves during wetter years, try growing genetically altered crops that lose less water through evapotranspiration, leave land fallow or use drip-tape to direct water where it can be better used with less water waste.  Roughly one-third of the 9.4 million acres of irrigated land in California is irrigated with drip-tape to conserve water.  In addition, yields are higher using drip-tape than they are with other irrigation methods.  A grower northwest of Visalia estimated that he uses 20 to 40 percent less water with drip-tape.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 30, 2013

Title: Emergency Drought Relief Fund to assist with projects in Oklahoma
Description: The governor of Oklahoma signed House Bill 1923, creating the Emergency Drought Relief Fund.  Landowners can get assistance through the fund to help cover the costs of pond cleanup and construction; water conservation measures for agriculture; water for livestock; rural fire fighting; red cedar removal; soil conservation and other things.  The Emergency Drought Commission determines how the funds are used.  Tulsa World (Okla.), May 30, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought has drawn down the level of many lakes across Kansas
Description: Drought has drawn down the level of many lakes across Kansas, particularly in the western part of the state.  Many streams are at historically low levels, and many stock ponds are dry, forcing farmers to haul water or relocate the cattle.Marion Reservoir was nearly 3 feet below its conservation pool level, leading to the closing of a couple of boat ramps.  Cheney Reservoir, west of Wichita, was more than 6.5 feet below normal and contained 64 percent of capacity.  Just one of seven boat ramps remained open, according to a Cheney State Park ranger.  He urged people less familiar with the lake to slow down to avoid barely submerged objects in the water.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), May 26, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought and other factors reduced visitation to New Mexico's state parks by more than 40 percent over Memorial Day weekend
Description: Unrelenting drought played a role in the 40.6 percent reduction in visitors to New Mexico’s 35 state parks over the Memorial Day weekend, according to the director of state parks.  Fewer than 315,000 people enjoyed state parks the last weekend in May, dragging revenue down by 41.3 percent for a total of roughly $157,000 for the weekend.  Low water levels have prompted officials to close Conchas, Clayton, Morphy and Storrie lakes to motorized boating.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 13, 2013

Title: Wildfires burning in New Mexico over the last month consumed more than 192 square miles
Description: Wildfires burning in New Mexico over the last month consumed more than 192 square miles.  The Silver Fire continues to burn in the Gila National Forest and will increase the area burned before it is contained.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), June 25, 2013

Title: More than a dozen bills concerning water conservation, storage and legal issues were introduced in the 2013 General Assembly in Colorado
Description: More than a dozen bills concerning water conservation, storage and legal issues were introduced in the 2013 General Assembly in Colorado after drought and wildfires affected the state in 2012.  Sterling Journal-Advocate (Colo.), May 22, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Vegetation statewide in Nevada manifests drought stress
Description: Poor green up on the range and water stressed vegetation were a couple of the drought impacts listed in a report from the Natural Resources Conservation Service.  Areas with insufficient or no reservoir storage may encounter water shortages.  The snow water content in the Upper Humboldt River Basin was 25 percent of the May 1 median.  Elko Daily Free Press (Nev.), May 15, 2013

Title: Poor wheat crop in Texas left custom harvester in Nebraska without work
Description: A custom harvester in Manley was not working harvesting wheat in Texas as she should be doing because drought and freezing temperatures damaged the crop.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), May 13, 2013

Title: Nebraska's wheat crop expected to be 20 percent smaller than in 2012
Description: The National Agricultural Statistics Service expects Nebraska’s wheat harvest to be 42.9 million bushels or 20 percent smaller than the 2012 wheat crop as drought continues to hamper plant growth.  The crop is rated as 16 percent very poor, 33 percent poor, 39 percent fair, and 12 percent good with none of the crop in the excellent category.  Given the state of the wheat in Nebraska and western Kansas, wheat prices may spike this year.  This is Nebraska’s smallest crop of wheat since 1944.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), May 13, 2013

Title: Drought-stressed crops left unused fertilizer in Iowa fields, impacting water quality
Description: Nitrate levels continue to run high in Iowa, running up a tab of $500,000 for Des Moines to treat the water. Drought in 2012 kept plants from taking up fertilizer, which is the main source of nitrates in the Midwest. Spring rains and runoff washed nutrients into area rivers, raising nitrate levels above the 10 milligram per liter level considered safe for drinking. Numerous rivers in Iowa have high levels of nitrate in the water. Des Moines Register (Iowa), July 1, 2013.The nitrate level in the Raccoon River was 24 milligrams per liter, higher than the previous record of 22 milligrams per liter. The nitrate content of the Des Moines River was 22 milligrams per liter, much higher than the previous record of 14.2 milligrams per liter. The general manager for the city water works said, “The real problem is it's the worst we've ever seen. Although the drinking water is safe, it's difficult to keep it that way." It costs roughly $7,000 daily to treat the water and remove nitrates to a safe level. Dubuque Telegraph Herald (Iowa), May 12, 2013; Mitchell Republic (S.D.), June 5, 2013.Des Moines Water Works began using its $4 million nitrate removal equipment to bring nitrate levels in the water from the Des Moines and Raccoon rivers into compliance with the Environmental Protection Agency’s standard of 10 milligrams per liter. During drought in 2012, plants did not take up all of the fertilizer in the soil, leaving it to be washed out with this spring’s rains. It costs roughly $7,000 daily to treat the water and remove nitrates to a safe level. Cedar Rapids is treating their water for high nitrate levels also. Dubuque Telegraph Herald (Iowa), May 12, 2013.
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Iowa, Boone County, IA, Buena Vista County, IA, Calhoun County, IA, Carroll County, IA, Dallas County, IA, Emmet County, IA, Greene County, IA, Guthrie County, IA, Hamilton County, IA, Humboldt County, IA, Kossuth County, IA, Polk County, IA, Sac County, IA, Webster County, IA

Title: Two Oregon senators requesting emergency grazing opportunities on federal land
Description: Sen. Ron Wyden and Jeff Merkley of Oregon sent a letter to the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Department of the Interior to request emergency grazing opportunities on federal lands as drought worsens and reduces forage for livestock.  Daily Astorian (Ore.), May 10, 2013

Title: Hay still in short supply in Montana
Description: Hay is still in short supply in Montana, due to drought and fires in 2012.   Parts of the state remain dry and could yield fewer cuttings than usual, prolonging the hay shortage in the area.  Bozeman Daily Chronicle (Mont.), May 9, 2013

Title: Fire restrictions in New Mexico
Description: New Mexico officials announced fire restrictions for the entire state, effective May 8, due to the elevated fire danger and prevalence of fires.  The restrictions ban the use of fireworks, campfires and other open fires and are valid statewide, including on non-municipal, non-federal and non-tribal lands.  Most of the state is in extreme or exceptional drought, and soil moisture is nonexistent in many areas.  The New Mexico Game and Fish Department officers will patrol more heavily to ensure that the fire restrictions and other laws are followed.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), May 3, 2013

Title: The state forester of Arizona warned that fire danger is high statewide
Description: The state forester of Arizona has warned that the fire danger is high statewide, due to dry conditions, but particularly high for southeastern Arizona.  Well-timed rains led to prolific grass growth in the Sonoran Desert near the Phoenix urban area, which has turned into loads of dry fuel.  East Valley Tribune (Ariz.), May 3, 2013

Title: The South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks Commission recommended offering thousands fewer deer licenses and tags during rifle, archery and muzzleloader seasons
Description: The South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks Commission recommended offering thousands fewer deer licenses and tags this fall during rifle, archery and muzzleloader seasons near the East River and West River where roughly 3,700 deer were killed by disease in 2012.  Drought may be curbing reproduction in parts of the state in 2013.  It was proposed that no antlerless deer licenses would be offered for general rifle, archer and muzzleloaders hunts in Bon Homme, Charles Mix, Clay, Codington, Douglas, Grant, Hutchinson, Lincoln, Turner, Union and Yankton counties.  Counties that may have significantly fewer tags during the East River main season from Nov. 23 through Dec. 8 are Yankton, Bon Homme, Brule, Buffalo, Charles Mix, Clark, Clay, Douglas, Hanson, Hutchinson, Lincoln, McPherson, Marshall, Sanborn, Spink, Sully, Turner and Union counties.  Meanwhile, Hand, Hughes and Miner counties may have larger numbers of tags.  There may be substantially fewer tags in Pennington, Bennett, Custer, Harding, Meade and Perkins counties in western South Dakota.  Altogether, there may be 14 percent fewer or 50,635 resident hunters East River tags, 3 percent fewer or 44,750 West River tags and a total of 3,300 Black Hills tags.  Aberdeen American News (S.D.), May 3, 2013

Title: Winds and dry conditions conducive to fire in California
Description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has received about 50 percent more calls statewide this year compared to average as dry conditions and temperatures start to rise.   Winds have contributed to many wildfires burning statewide.  Two fires burned in Butte County, charring more than 350 acres of brush land and another one burning 300 acres, and producing smoke that drifted across the valley.  The Cedar Fire burned 55 acres and was 40 percent contained.  The Yellow Fire scorched about 125 acres near Calistoga and was 50 percent contained.  Near Yountville in Napa County, the Silverado River burned 75 acres and was fully contained.    East of Los Angeles, the Summit Fire charred 1,700 acres, damaged a home, forced evacuations and was 30 percent contained.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), May 2, 2013

Title: Kansas winter wheat tour finds drought damage in the west
Description: Wheat production in Kansas is expected to be 313.1 million bushels, or 18 percent less than last year, due to drought and freeze damage.  The average yield is anticipated to be 41.1 bushels per acre.  Kansas produced 382.2 million bushels of wheat in 2012. Reuters (N.Y.), May 2, 2013.Far western Kansas’ wheat crop is suffering from a crippling drought compounded by several bitter freezes, while areas farther east are in better shape. That was the assessment that several participants in the 2013 Kansas Winter Wheat Tour provided to Dan Voorhis of the Wichita Eagle. The preliminary estimate for state-wide winter wheat yield was 40.5 bushels per acre, less than 48.8 observed last year ("Wheat crop looks pretty good in eastern Kansas, tour participants say," The Wichita Eagle, Kansas, May 1, 2013). Weber Commodities assembled photos from the 2013 Kansas Wheat Tour that show the differences between winter wheat in D1, D3 and D4. Photo near Oberlin in Decatur County, Kansas, which is in D4 (Exceptional Drought) drought, shows almost no winter wheat growth, with yield estimated at 21 bushels per acre. A photo near Liebenthal in Rush County, Kansas, in D3 (Extreme Drought), shows growth with an estimated 19 bushels per acre. A photo taken near Leonardville, Riley County, Kansas, in D1, shows winter wheat growth, with an estimated 48 bushels per acre (photos and information submitted by Brad Rippey, USDA Office of the Chief Economist).

Title: Dry conditions in California prompted CalFire to issue a statewide ban on burning
Description: Dry conditions in California prompted CalFire to issue a statewide ban on burning to reduce the likelihood of wildfires.  Fire personnel in the East Bay hills and Diablo Range put up “barbeque suspension” signs in parks to alert park visitors to the elevated fire danger.  The fire marshal of the Contra Costa Fire District said that notices to remove dry vegetation from their lands was sent to homeowners about a month earlier than usual since the fire season seemed to be getting off to an early start this year.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 1, 2013

Title: Hay stocks in Kansas on May 1 were 460,000 tons or 29 percent lower than on May 1, 2012
Description: Hay stocks in Kansas on May 1 were 460,000 tons or 29 percent lower than on May 1, 2012, according to the Kansas Agricultural Service.  Hay supplies have not been so low since 1957 and were 58 percent below the 10-year average of 1.1 million tons.  Low soil moisture for pasture and grass growth and grazed down pastures in western Kansas do not bode well for increasing the hay supply as drought has persisted for more than two years in the region.  Cattle liquidations will continue without some relief from the drought.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), May 26, 2013

Title: The Nebraska pheasant population has been hindered by drought and reductions in habitat
Description: The Nebraska pheasant population has been hindered by drought and reductions in habitat after emergency haying and grazing was permitted during the summer, according to the Pheasant Forever outlook for Nebraska.Rural mail carrier survey of wildlife data taken in April and July showed that pheasant populations were mostly lower than in 2012 and 38 percent lower statewide.  Pheasant populations in southwestern Nebraska were better than in 2012, but lower compared to previous years.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), Sept. 29, 2013

Title: Nebraska lawmakers striving to bolster the state’s rainy-day fund
Description: Nebraska lawmakers are striving to bolster the state’s rainy-day fund in case the money is needed later if drought continues to rattle the farm economy or other events arise.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), April 28, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Drought is gripping New Mexico
Description: Drought is gripping New Mexico with dwindling water supplies strangling agriculture and forcing communities to limit water use.  Farmland is left idle for lack of water.  The levels of springs in the northern part of the state are falling and wells are going dry near Santa Fe.In eastern New Mexico, wells have gone dry, leaving ranchers to sell their livestock.  Reservoir levels have hit record lows and offer little to water users downstream.  The owners of some pecan orchards in southern New Mexico resorted to trimming the trees to the trunks to reduce the trees’ water needs while there is little water to be had.  Others have drilled new wells and are using the water judiciously or are teaming up with neighbors to acquire water.  The Rio Grande River in Dona Ana County in southern New Mexico went dry, leaving carp fighting for life in a series of puddles and thousands of freshwater clams dead.   At least one restaurant in Hatch charges for a glass of tap water as the level of groundwater continues to decline, leaving town officials seeking new sources for chile growers.  A call was issued on the Pecos River because some water users felt others were taking more than their fair share.  Meanwhile, Texas has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to stop New Mexico from pumping as much water as they do to leave more for farmers in El Paso.  Farmington Daily Times (N.M.), April 25, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: New Mexico soils too dry to allow any runoff to boost water levels in reservoirs
Description: Santa Rosa Lake on the Pecos River did not benefit from winter snow, which has melted, but did not increase the water level of the lake, according to an employee with the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.  In other parts of New Mexico too, stream flow did not increase because the soils were too dry to allow any runoff, noted a federal snow surveyor.  Albuquerque Journal (N.M.), April 25, 2013

Title: Financial and technical aid offered through a new Water Quantity and Drought Pilot in Kansas
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) is offering financial and technical aid through a new Water Quantity and Drought Pilot funded through the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP).  The goal is to improve water quantity-related natural resource issues using the water conservation process by assessing the water source and concerns, creating a conservation plan and possibly using EQIP funds to improve the water source.  The NRCS has two application deadlines for the pilot, May 17 and June 21, 2013.  Pittsburg Morning Sun (Kan.), April 22, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: State-Wide Days of Prayer for Rain and Water Stewardship held in Oklahoma
Description: Oklahoma Interfaith leaders urged their fellow Oklahomans on May 1, June 26 and September 18  to pray for rain and to become better stewards of water.  These days will be recognized as State-Wide Days of Prayer for Rain and Water Stewardship, a cooperative effort of the Oklahoma Association of Conservation Districts, the Oklahoma Conference of Churches and the Whole Creation Community, a ministry of the Episcopal Diocese of Oklahoma.  Oklahoma Farm Report (Okla.), April 23, 2013

Title: Ohio soybean growers urged to check soybean size
Description: Drought in 2012, in addition to late season rains, resulted in larger than normal soybeans.  On average, 2,500 soybeans weigh one pound, but with the 2012 soybeans being larger, just 1,700 soybeans might weigh one pound.  Growers were urged to check soybean size and adjust planters as needed.Agri Marketing (Adel, Iowa), April 22, 2013

Title: Wyoming ranchers welcomed the recent spring snowstorm for the moisture to revive grazing pastures
Description: Ranchers welcomed the recent spring snowstorm for the moisture to revive grazing pastures, despite any calf deaths that may result from the snow.  The executive vice president of the Wyoming Stock Growers Association stated, "I think the general attitude is we were so desperate for the moisture that in the long term that's maybe a sacrifice that people are willing to accept."  Casper Star-Tribune (Wyo.), April 21, 2013

Title: South Dakota officials requesting limited water releases from Missouri River reservoirs
Description: The South Dakota Environment and Natural Resources secretary and the Game Fish and Parks secretary sent a letter to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, asking them to conserve water by limiting releases from the Missouri River reservoirs for the benefit of navigation in areas without commercial barges, which is exactly what the Corps already planned to do.  A spokeswoman for the corps stated that the projected runoff about Sioux City, Iowa should be around 81 percent. Sioux Falls Argus Leader (S.D.), April 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Hay prices remained high in Wyoming
Description: Hay prices remained high in Wyoming as drought prevented hay from growing well in 2012.  A rancher near Gillette said that a ton of first cut alfalfa was selling for $250 to $300 and that much of it was coming from South Dakota and Montana.  Billings Gazette (Mont.), April 14, 2013

Title: Most Nebraska counties declared to be natural disaster areas by the USDA
Description: Eighty-nine  counties in Nebraska were declared to be natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture due to ongoing drought.  The remaining four counties of Nuckolls, Nemaha, Pawnee and Richardson were also eligible for aid.  This declaration permits affected farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural producers to apply for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.  KCSR-AM (Chadron, Neb.), April 12, 2013

Title: Californians urged by Save Our Water to conserve
Description: Save Our Water, California's largest water conservation program, encouraged people to conserve water, given the warnings from state officials about the low snowpack.  The most recent snow survey on March 28 revealed that the snowpack was 52 percent of normal for this time of year.  With just a little bit of the wet season left, there is not much hope for more storms to deepen the snowpack before warmer weather arrives.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), April 1, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Nebraska’s wheat crop consisted of smaller, weaker plants than usual
Description: Nebraska’s wheat crop consisted of smaller, weaker plants than usual as the crop struggled to break through dry soil to grow, according to the executive director of the Nebraska Wheat Board.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), March 26, 2013

Title: Smoking, open fires and fireworks not allowed on state owned lands in New Mexico
Description: Smoking, open fires and fireworks were not allowed on state owned lands in New Mexico because drought and strong winds have elevated the fire danger.   The New Mexico Land Offices oversees 9 million acres of land belonging to the state and 13 million acres of subsurface rights to oil, natural gas and minerals.  Santa Fe New Mexican (N.M.), March 26, 2013

Title: The mayor of St. Louis, Missouri and other mayors from along the Mississippi River want to develop a conservation, drought and disaster plan for the Mississippi River
Description: The mayor of St. Louis, Missouri and other mayors from along the Mississippi River want to develop a conservation, drought and disaster plan for the Mississippi River and visited the White House and Congress to push their plan.  The low flow in the Mississippi River during December 2012 and January 2013 brought home just how vulnerable shipping and the regional economy could be to disruption.  St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Mo.), March 20, 2013

Title: Birds and other wildlife in Kansas struggling to find food and shelter
Description: Birds and other wildlife in Kansas were struggling to find food and shelter since drought has plagued the state for two years, stated a small game biologist.  The recent snowfall makes finding those things even more daunting.  Some birds have congregated along roads to feed and have been struck by passing cars, which is a concern because drought has already reduced the number of various species of prairie birds.  KSN-TV News 3 (Wichita, Kan.), Feb. 28, 2013

Title: Minnesota water permit holders overpumping during drought
Description: Concern for the water supply during drought in Minnesota led a Minnesota Public Radio reporter to investigate overpumping by water permit holders in the state.  Numerous water permit holders pump more water than their permit allows, but the Department of Natural Resources is not adequately staffed to enforce permit violations.  Mankato Free Press (Minn.), Feb. 27, 2013

Title: The Iowa Senate Natural Resources subcommittee approved SF 165, which would provide $1.035 million to assist communities and water utilities with preparation for ongoing drought
Description: The Iowa Senate Natural Resources subcommittee approved SF 165, which would provide $1.035 million to assist communities and water utilities with preparation for ongoing drought.  The money would be used to restart aquifer monitoring and for groundwater source mapping, aquifer modeling and technical assistance for communities and rural water associations.  The full Natural Resources Committee will likely address the bill on Feb. 28.  Mason City Globe-Gazette (Iowa), Feb. 27, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: The executive director of the Indiana Fireworks Distributors and Users Association prepared to fight ban on fireworks if drought brings increased fire danger this summer
Description: The executive director of the Indiana Fireworks Distributors and Users Association stated that local fire officials who banned fireworks last summer, due to the increased fire danger from drought, were “in the wrong” and that his agency will be quicker to challenge any bans that fire marshals might impose if drought is a concern again this year.  A 2006 law prevents local governments from banning personal use of fireworks from June 29 through July 9.  Some Indiana fireworks distributors experienced a loss of 90 percent of their income during the 2012 Fourth of July season. Indianapolis Star (Ind.), Feb. 26, 2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation

Title: About 500 Nebraska firefighters will receive training in the next few months in preparation for another bad fire season in the state
Description: About 500 Nebraska firefighters will receive training in the next few months in preparation for another bad fire season in the state.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), Feb. 22, 2013

Title: The Oklahoma House Committee approved a $10 million drought relief fund
Description: The Oklahoma House Committee approved a $10 million relief fund that could be accessed when the governor of the state declares a drought emergency.  Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), Feb. 20. 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Illinois farmers more interested in wheat after 2012
Description: Interest in wheat crops grew after 2012.  This is in large part due to the fact that wheat crops planted during the drought produced an average of 63 bushels per acre, up two bushels from the previous year.  Wheat was planted in some fields to use up nitrogen in the soil left behind by abandoned corn crops.  Weather will largely determine how much nitrogen is left in the soil when farmers plant this year.  Farmers will need to test their soil to ensure they don’t apply too much nitrogen.  Farm Week (Bloomington, Ill.), Feb. 18, 2013

Title: The Colorado Humane Society received a gift of 21 tons of hay
Description: The Colorado Humane Society received a gift of 21 tons of hay from a generous, anonymous donor.  The hay, worth about $7,000, is intended to feed neglected horses.  Wildfires in the past few years and drought have cut into hay supplies, making any available hay very expensive.  Denver Post (Colo.), Feb. 13, 2013

Title: Texas water supplies remain depleted after years of drought
Description: There were 1,011 communities in Texas with water restrictions, stated L’Oreal Stepney, the deputy director for water at the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  He also reported that 19 water systems have less than 180 days’ worth of water, three systems have less than 45 days’ worth and one system relies on trucked-in water to meet basic needs.  The state climatologist warned the House and Senate Natural Resources Committees that the state may be headed into its second worst drought as rainfall deficits remained high across the state.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 5, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought, high feed prices a concern for buyers at buffalo auction in Rapid City, South Dakota
Description: Buyers at the annual Dakota Territory Buffalo Association sale took drought and high feed prices into consideration before purchasing buffalo, they said.  One buyer from Sauk Centre, Minnesota said that drought in other parts of the country were drawing hay and other crops out of Minnesota, making it more expensive to feed animals.  The owner of Western Buffalo Company in Rapid City thought that buffalo prices would be higher if there was not drought, but still thought that prices were reasonably good.   Rapid City Journal (S.D.), Feb. 5, 2013
Places: Sauk Centre, MN, South Dakota, Pennington County, SD

Title: Seven of the 24 ethanol plants in Nebraska have closed
Description: Seven of the 24 ethanol plants in Nebraska have closed as high corn prices increase the cost of ethanol production to unprofitable levels.  The ethanol plant in Hastings closed recently.  Many of the plants that have stopped production will resume production after the 2013 corn harvest.  KOLN/KGIN (Lincoln, Neb.), Feb. 4, 2013

Title: More farmers in Eddy County, New Mexico selling water to oil and gas industry
Description: The Office of the State Engineer has received more water permit applications in the last year, leading to a backlog as those with a water rights claim apply to transfer it from agricultural use to commercial use.  Agricultural endeavors have not been so lucrative during the recent years of drought in Eddy County, and farmers can make more money by selling their water to the oil and gas industry for hydraulic fracturing.  There have also been more applications for drilling supplemental wells, deepen existing wells or drill a new well.Carlsbad Current-Argus (N.M.), Jan. 29, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Illinois farmers must carefully consider nutrient loss in biomass after drought
Description: Farmers who harvested biomass after the drought will have to be especially careful when considering how much nutrients were removed from the field.  The ratio of grain to biomass changes in drought years, as does the amount of nutrients taken up by the plant.  To determine how much nutrients remain in the field, farmers will need to consider when the crop was harvested and how much biomass was removed.  Farm Week (Bloomington, Ill.), Jan. 28, 2013

Title: Low Mississippi River hurt barge traffic in Louisiana
Description: AEP River Operations LLC was not using all of its towboats and moved workers around to find work for them as drought reduced the number of barges moving on the Mississippi River.  Profits that would normally be generated in the previous year were not available this January to sustain the company until work picks up.  The vice president of Gulf operations for American Commercial stated that the drought cost the company roughly $27 million in lost business and revenue as boats and workers sit idle.  The company would normally be hiring in January, but is not this year.  Washington Post (D.C.), Jan. 14, 2013

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas began requiring that new power generators show proof of water access and rights
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas began requiring that new power generators show proof of water access and rights before the council will add the power company to its state planning model.  The goal is to ensure that power companies use their water supplies sensibly to have adequate supplies during drought.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Feb. 6, 2013

Title: More farmers in Minnesota investing in irrigation systems
Description: More farmers in Minnesota were investing in irrigation systems as recent dry spells made dryland farming less lucrative.  From the start of 2013 through early September, farmers had submitted applications for 466 irrigation permits, more than double the number of applications in 2012.   The Minnesota Department of Natural Resource records show that interest in irrigation in the last several years, with a sharp increase this year.  St. Cloud Times (Minn.), Sept. 9, 2013

Title: Above normal fire activity in Oregon since the start of 2013
Description: Oregon has experienced 104 wildfires that burned 307 acres of land protected by the Oregon Department of Forestry since the start of 2013 as low precipitation and warm temperatures have increased the fire danger.  On average, there are 52 fires that burn 122 acres, according to records from 2003 through 2012.  This coming fire season is expected to be busier than usual.  Salem Statesman-Journal (Ore.), May 14, 2013

Title: High number of irrigation permits issued in South Dakota
Description: After the state experienced drought in 2012, the South Dakota Department of Environment and Natural Resources issued 354 irrigation permits in 2013--at least twice as many irrigation permits as were issued in 2012.  Forty percent of the permits issued last year went to farmers in five southeastern counties.KELOLAND-TV CBS 11 (Sioux Falls, S.D.), Jan. 28, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Kansas farmers make indemnity claims of $33.5 million in first half of 2013
Description: The Risk Management Agency office in Topeka has received indemnity claims for $33.5 million for 2013 already.  Of the 9.4 million acres affected, more than $31 million of the claims are for the damaged wheat crop.  Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Kan.), June 8, 2013

Title: Wildfires consumed more land in Oregon than in any year since 1951 after lightning and drought contributed to blazes affecting 325 square miles
Description: The Oregon Department of Forestry needs an additional $40 million to pay for firefighting expenses during 2013, when more than 162 square miles of state, private and U.S. Bureau of Land Management acres went up in flames.  The state Department of Forestry already spent $122 million to cover firefighting costs in 2013, but with eight times more acres burned than the 10-year average, expenses were much higher than anticipated.  The Legislature will address the needed $40 million when it convenes in February.  Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), Nov. 22, 2013.Wildfires consumed more land in Oregon in 2013 than in any year since 1951 after lightning and drought contributed to blazes affecting 325 square miles.  One hundred sixty-two square miles of state-protected land were blackened by wildfires, eight times the 10-year average, according to the Oregon Department of Forestry.  The state spent $122 million to fight the fires and expected to be reimbursed $47 million from federal agencies, leaving the state responsible for the remaining $75 million.  The Department of Forestry had $45 million set aside for firefighting and will have to request $30 million from the Legislature to cover the remainder.The fires charred an estimated $370 million worth of timber on state, private and U.S. Bureau of Land Management lands.  Five major fires started from a dry lightning storm in southwestern Oregon in late July where dry conditions allowed the fires to grow rapidly.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), Oct. 17, 2013

Title: Drought in the U.S. was a boon to Louisiana farmers and ranchers who got better prices for their feed grains and cattle
Description: Drought in the U.S. was a boon to Louisiana farmers and ranchers who got better prices for their feed grains and cattle while other parts of the country suffered.  The value of beef cattle and calves was 18 percent higher over 2012 at $663 million.  The value of the Louisiana agricultural economy hit a new high of $11.8 billion in 2013.Baton Rouge Advocate (La.), March 24, 2014

Title: Fire activity above normal in California
Description: CalFire has been called to more than 4,500 wildfires that blackened more than 92,000 acres since the start of 2013.  By this time last year, CalFire had responded to 3,300 fires that charred 43,000 acres.  Dry conditions and gusty winds have contributed to the swift growth of some of the fires.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 20, 2013The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has responded to roughly 2,900 fires since the start of 2013, stated a spokesman for the department, and attributed the uptick in fire activity to dry brush and weather conditions that are characteristic of August or September.  The average number of fires for the first half of the year is less than 1,800 fires.   Bill Patzert, a climatologist with the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in La Cañada Flintridge said, “We're in a long-term drought.  The situation is extremely crispy and dry. That equals incendiary."  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), June 27, 2013Fire activity has been high in California with more than 1,200 wildfires scorching 40,000 acres, in comparison with the annual average to date of 600 fires affecting 1,200 acres, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.  "It's very unusual to have this much fire activity this early in the year.  Dozens of wildfires burning in May is unheard of. These are conditions we should be seeing in July and August," said the information officer for CalFire.  USA Today, May 14, 2013

Title: Low water levels in Kansas may contribute to high number of drownings in 2013
Description: Twelve people were fatally injured or drowned in Kansas lakes, ponds and rivers since the start of the year, according to the Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourism.  Five drownings occurred during the first week of July.  Normally there are three to six drownings annually.  The department's boating law administrator suspects that low water levels due to drought have made lakes more dangerous.  "These lakes are deceiving because they're low enough from the drought that you think you can keep wading out, but then you hit a drop-off and suddenly go from chest high water to water that's 10 or 12 feet deep and panic," he said.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), July 11, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Wildfire activity in Montana has been above normal
Description: Wildfire activity in Montana has been above normal, according to the Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation.  Nearly 5,000 acres have been charred since the start of the year as the southern half of the state experienced drought.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), May 26, 2013

Title: Net farm profit in South Dakota fell nearly 40 percent in 2013
Description: Net farm profit in South Dakota fell nearly 40 percent in 2013, due to the wrenching drought in 2012, according to the program director for the South Dakota Center for Farm/Ranch Management.  Average farm income was $141,973 in 2013, compared to $236,437 in 2012.  The five year average for farm net income was $197,556.  Drought drove up livestock feed prices, sharply cutting into profits.Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), April 23, 2014

Title: Drought hampered crop growth in Iowa in 2013
Description: Drought hampered crop growth in Iowa in 2013 and left corn production only 15 percent higher than 2012 corn production.  Soybean production was 0.8 percent lower than 2012.  Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier (Iowa), Feb. 27, 2014

Title: Fewer chile grown in New Mexico in 2013
Description: Chile growers in New Mexico produced fewer chile due to water shortages and insufficient laborers to harvest the crop, which is done manually.  There were 65,000 tons of chile produced in the state in 2013, roughly 16 percent less than was produced in 2012 when nearly 78,000 tons of the hot pepper were grown.  Less than a decade ago, chile production exceeded 100,000 tons.Farmers planted fewer acres of chile in 2013, partly due to drought because there was not enough water.  Some farmers may have groundwater, but that is often too saline and hurts the pepper plants’ yields.  The value of the crop slipped to roughly $49.5 million in 2013, nearly $16 million less than the crop brought in 2012.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 27, 2014

Title: Drought and other factors cut the lesser prairie chicken population in New Mexico; other wildlife suffering too
Description: Drought and other factors cut the lesser prairie chicken population in New Mexico by 50 percent in 2013.  The lead biologist with the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish stated that drought was the main culprit and that the birds will likely recover next year, given all of the precipitation New Mexico received this summer.  An aerial survey conducted in the spring by the Audubon New Mexico, a state environmental organization, revealed that the lesser prairie chicken population fell to 17,600 birds from 34,440.The biologist also noted that drought has cut down the populations of quail and other wildlife because there was nothing for them to eat.  Clovis News Journal (N.M.), Sept. 27, 2013

Title: California fire crews have fought more than 680 wildfires since the start of 2013
Description: California fire crews have fought more than 680 wildfires since the start of 2013, which is 200 more than usual for this time period.  Some of those fires grew to affect 300 to 400 acres.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 25, 2013

Title: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation
Description: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation between January and June 2013, which was the driest in the state’s recorded history.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: 2013 drought cut Colorado's agricultural production by 25 percent
Description: Drought cut Colorado’s agricultural production by 25 percent in 2013, said State Representatives Don Coram (R-Montrose) and Jerry Sonnenberg (R-Sterling), members of the House Agriculture, Livestock and Natural Resources Committee.Sterling Journal-Advocate (Colo.), Aug. 4, 2014

Title: The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources approved more than twice as many new wells in 2013 as in the previous year
Description: The 2012 drought made Wisconsin farmers long for irrigation capability to increase crop production.  From the start of 2013 through Oct. 1, the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources approved the construction of 258 new irrigation wells.  The annual average of irrigation wells approved by the DNR between 2007 and 2012 was 122, less than half the number given the go-ahead in 2013.  Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), Oct. 22, 2013

Title: Free Agricultural Emergency Permits in Wisconsin to ease restraints on large hay loads
Description: The governor of Wisconsin ordered the continuation of free Agricultural Emergency Permits from the state Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection and Wisconsin Department of Transportation to hasten the transport of large loads of hay across the state for hungry livestock.   Drought in 2012 reduced hay production and resulted in low, on-farm hay stock levels in Wisconsin and throughout much of the Midwest.  As of May 1, 2013, dry hay stocks in Wisconsin amounted to 410,000 tons, which is 56 percent less than a year ago.  This is an extension of an Executive Order from 2012 allowing the DATCP and WisDOT to issue the free permits.  Eau Claire Leader-Telegram (Wis.), May 29, 2013

Title: The Texas Farm Bureau reported that food prices have risen rapidly in the past three months
Description: The Texas Farm Bureau reported that food prices have risen rapidly in the past three months as food prices reflect the strain of the 2011 drought and the Midwest drought in 2012 on agriculture.  Thirteen of the 16 items it surveys every three months rose considerably, particularly meats.  The price of lean ground beef rose by 10.5 percent, while the cost of top cut sirloin steak climbed roughly 19 percent or nearly one dollar since the last survey three months ago.  KJ 97 KAJA-FM (San Antonio, Texas), March 27, 2013

Title: Mistletoe production down in Texas
Description: A mistletoe grower in Priddy in central Texas said that the dry conditions prevented mistletoe from growing, resulting in a mistletoe shortage in the state and country.  Mistletoe is a parasitic plant that grows on some trees.  Since drought has killed many trees across the state, mistletoe wasn’t faring so well either.  Q 101.9 KQXT-FM (Texas), Dec. 24, 2012

Title: Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas urged farmers, ranchers and communities to examine their water use and have drought plans
Description: Gov. Sam Brownback urged farmers, ranchers and communities to examine their water use and have drought plans as drought persists.  Water supplies are critically low at reservoirs across the state.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), Dec. 21, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Agricultural economists at Colorado State University were surveying farmers and ranchers in the state in an effort to learn how drought affected Colorado’s agricultural activities in 2012
Description: Agricultural economists at Colorado State University were surveying farmers and ranchers in the state in an effort to learn how drought affected Colorado’s agricultural activities in 2012 for a project called “Telling the Story – Drought in Colorado.”  The economists plan to use the information to create more effective management tools for use in future droughts.  The survey can be accessed at http://tinyurl.com/CSU-drought.  Of special interest is the drought’s impact on operations netting $100,000 or more annually.  The responses will be analyzed beginning in early January 2013.  Sterling Journal-Advocate (Colo.), Dec. 21, 2012

Title: Statewide ban on fireworks and open fires in Utah
Description: Utah had a statewide ban on fireworks and open fires, except for campfires in designated areas, as drought increases the fire danger.Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), June 20, 2012

Title: Water releases from Carlyle Lake in Illinois to boost level of Mississippi River by 6 inches
Description: The U.S. Army corps of Engineers began releasing water from Carlyle Lake on Dec. 15 to boost water levels on the Mississippi River as much as 6 inches by Dec. 24.  The effort was undertaken to keep barge traffic moving past Thebes, Illinois where rock pinnacles jeopardize navigation if water levels get much lower.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Dec. 17, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin scheduled a meeting on Dec. 17 in advance of the potential shutdown of the Mississippi River from low water flows
Description: Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin scheduled a meeting on Dec. 17 in advance of the potential shutdown of the Mississippi River from low water flows.  Invited guests include members of the state’s congressional delegation, Gov. Pat Quinn and representatives of the agricultural, shipping, coal and petroleum industries.  East Alton is the venue for the meeting.  State Journal-Register (Springfield, Ill.), Dec. 14, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The governor of Tennessee encouraged U.S. Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell to sponsor and pass legislation to require the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to release more water in the Missouri Riv
Description: The governor of Tennessee encouraged U.S. Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell to sponsor and pass legislation to require the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to release more water in the Missouri River to bolster water levels for barge traffic.  WHBQ Fox 13 Memphis (Tenn.), Dec. 13, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Strong winds blew out some winter wheat in Nebraska
Description: Strong winds blew out some winter wheat in Nebraska, according to a crop specialist with the University of Nebraska.  Low soil moisture kept some wheat from germinating also.  CNBC (N.J.), Dec. 6, 2012

Title: Uptick in imported grain traveling by rail in North Carolina
Description: Drought in the Midwest led many livestock producers to import grain from South America.  The imported grain arrives at the Port of Wilmington and is moved by train across North Carolina.  The communications director for CSX said that the uptick in rail traffic was not related to Storm Sandy and affirmed that the increased rail traffic was imported grain for livestock. Wilmington Morning Star (N.C.), Dec. 5, 2012

Title: Drought killed Christmas tree seedlings on some tree farms in Ohio, but left some tree farms relatively unscathed
Description: Drought killed Christmas tree seedlings on some tree farms in Ohio, but left some tree farms relatively unscathed, according to the wife of the president of the Ohio Christmas Tree Association.  One Christmas tree grower near Toledo said that 45 to 50 percent of his 5,000 seedlings died.  He anticipates planting 10,000 seedlings in the spring of 2013 to compensate for those lost in 2012.  Toledo Blade (Ohio), Dec. 4, 2012

Title: Mule deer populations in eastern Montana declined due to drought and bad weather
Description: Mule deer populations in eastern Montana declined due to drought and bad weather during last winter and spring, according to a fish and wildlife report submitted to the Western Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies in July 2013.  Billings Gazette (Mont.), Oct. 17, 2013

Title: Hay prices high, supplies short in Montana
Description: Hay prices were high in Montana, where many ranchers in need of hay were looking to out of state sources because there was little available hay, due to drought and fires in Montana.  One rancher from Boyd said that he uses supplements that increase the digestive efficiency in his cattle, requiring them to eat 25 percent less hay.  KTVQ-TV Q2 Billings (Mont.), Nov. 29, 2012

Title: Drought and high hay prices led to what some Humane Society officials in Texas term the “Donkey Crisis of 2012”
Description: Drought and high hay prices led to what some Humane Society officials in Texas term the “Donkey Crisis of 2012.”  Drought drastically reduced grass and hay production in 2011, leaving donkeys with little to eat and making the purchase of hay for feeding donkeys very costly.  An investigator with the Humane Society of North Texas said that a 60-pound bale of hay cost about $14, double what it cost two years ago.  The Humane Society and the Peaceful Valley Donkey Rescue (PVDR) have been overwhelmed with donkeys for the past year and a half and want to give them to good homes.  The PVDR has roughly 1,000 donkeys at its headquarters.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 25, 2012

Title: High hay prices a challenge for Michigan horse owners
Description: The barn manager of a non-profit group that takes care of old, abused, rescued and neglected animals in Howell shared that feed costs have almost doubled in the past year.  Drought lowered hay production in the Midwest, which the Michigan State University thought to be down 15 to 30 percent.  Hay used to cost $2 to $6 per bale, but has risen to $6 to $15 per bale, stated a member of the Michigan Commission of Agriculture & Rural Development.  Horse owners in Gaylord mix other foods in with the hay to stretch the hay supply.  Traverse City Record-Eagle (Mich.), Nov. 25, 2012

Title: Farmers in Missouri baling, selling corn stalks for livestock feed
Description: Farmers in Missouri were baling and selling corn stalks for livestock feed in lieu of hay since little grew well during this past growing season.  The Missouri Department of Agriculture noted that the corn stover sold for $60 to $100 per ton or $35 to $45 for a large round bale.  Prior to this year, the state Department of Agriculture did not monitor corn stover prices, but its utility as cattle feed in such a parched year led the agency to track its value.  Farm equipment manufacturers, such as Deere and Co., have begun to make corn stover balers, which require stronger teeth to collect the corn stalks and strong belts to form the round shape.  An official with the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Natural Resource Conservation Service warned that the corn stalks are good at preventing soil erosion and should not be removed from fields with slopes greater than 5 percent.  Gathering the stover can also result in nutrient loss.  Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), Nov. 22, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: The winter wheat crop in Nebraska not faring well
Description: The winter wheat crop in Nebraska was not faring well because little rain has fallen.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture said that roughly 92 percent of the crop has emerged.  Farmers report that their stands of wheat were thin or spotty.  Only 17 percent of the crop was rated to be in good condition, and none of it was rated excellent.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 21, 2012

Title: Lingering drought in New Mexico forced ranchers to continue culling their herds, raised concerns about water supplies
Description: Lingering drought in New Mexico forced ranchers to continue culling their herds, while some dairy and other agricultural businesses have closed their doors.  Snowpack was about half of the normal amount for this time of year, leaving agricultural interests and others uneasy.  Reservoir levels were at their lowest level also, noted a hydrologist for the Bureau of Reclamation.  In southern New Mexico, farmers have had to rely on wells since water allotments from the Rio Grande were a fraction of the contracted amount, due to low rainfall.  The state has been in drought for two years.  Carlsbad Current-Argus (N.M.), Nov. 19, 2012

Title: Missouri horses develop drought-related bacterial infection
Description: Extremely dry weather has caused an especially large number of horses to become infected with a bacterial disease, Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis.  Usually a rare condition, the infection causes painful swelling and abscesses in the legs, chest, and abdominal cavities.  Horse owners should be on the lookout for lethargic horses with swelling or sores and treat horses as advised by a vet.  If left untreated, the disease could result in lameness and death, and can spread to other animals.  Farm Week (Bloomington, Ill.), Nov. 16, 2012

Title: The Minnesota Department of Agriculture urged farmers to be proactive and take action to minimize drought impacts
Description: The Minnesota Department of Agriculture urged farmers to be proactive in light of the existing drought and prepare for continuing dry conditions by improving soil moisture retention, planting drought-tolerant crops, mitigating against wind erosion and checking irrigation equipment.  Meanwhile, the state was looking into resources for farmers and attempting to make state and federal programs easier to access.  KSTP-TV ABC 5 Minneapolis/St. Paul (Minn.), Nov. 15, 2012

Title: The Ohio Agriculture Department strongly recommended that beekeepers feed their bees to help them endure the winter
Description: The Ohio Agriculture Department strongly recommended that beekeepers feed their bees to help them endure the winter.  The dry summer and limited food storage at some bee colonies may lead the queen bee to produce fewer eggs.  Bee larvae are normally fed honey and pollen, but can also be fed fondant or sugar syrup.  Agriculture officials recommend additional feeding if the back of the hive can be lifted easily.  Hives should not be opened if the temperature is below 60 degrees unless it is urgent that the bees be fed.  Dayton Daily News (Ohio), Nov. 11, 2012

Title: Illinois saw fewer pumpkin diseases during dry summer
Description: In stark contrast to many other crops that suffered due to this summer’s severe drought, pumpkin patches in Illinois have been thriving in the hot, dry weather. The dryness of the summer prevented rind-rotting molds and fungi from growing in pumpkin patches, so even pumpkins that were planted after the drought set in were able to grow to maturity.  Chicago Tribune (Ill.), Oct. 10, 2012

Title: The U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasted South Dakota’s average corn yield lower than usual
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasted that South Dakota’s average corn yield would be 29 percent lower than average since drought hurt the crop.  Soybean production in the state was expected to be 130 million bushels, which is 14 percent lower than in 2011, while corn production was predicted to be 503 million bushels, or 23 percent lower than last year.  Sioux Falls Argus Leader (S.D.), Nov. 9, 2012

Title: Hawaii drought affects ranching, water supplies, plants and animals, orchards
Description: On Kauai, the water level in the Alexander Reservoir is so low that irrigation water service has been suspended. Pasture conditions are poor. Cattle have been removed from the Mahaulepu area due to poor pasture conditions. On Oahu, ranchers on the west side have destocked pastures due to poor grazing conditions.
