A voluntary 10 percent reduction in water use is in place as a precaution for the Waimanalo Reservoir. On Molokai, pastures and vegetation conditions are very oppor west of Kaunakakai. The water level in the Kualapuu Reservoir is very low so the state of hawaii Department of Agriculture has continued a 30 percent reduction in irrigation water consumptions. On Lanai, certain areas are very dry, affecting even drought-resistant plants and trees such as Kiawe. Mouflon sheet, axis deer and game bird populations have been reduced. On Maui, Low water supply has reduced production at the Olinda water treatment facility. Pastures in southwest Maui were destocked several months ago due to lack of sufficient forage. The Maui County Department of Water Supply is asking for a 5 percent reduction in water use for Upcountry residents and 10 percent for central and south Maui. The Big Island is seeing significant impacts from the Kau, North Koha, South Kona and South Kohala districts related to ranching, ornamental plants, fruit orchards and bees. From the Nov. 8, 2012, Drought Information Statement produced by the Honolulu Forecast Office of the National Weather Service.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Texas scored a D-minus on an assessment of its drinking water
Description: Texas scored a D-minus on an assessment of its drinking water by the American Society of Civil Engineers.  The D-minus reflected the poor availability of drinking water in Texas after years of drought and did not indicate that the water was of inferior quality.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 8, 2012
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Warm, dry fall weather hurting grass and small grain growth in Oklahoma
Description: Warm, dry fall weather was hurting grass and small grain growth in Oklahoma.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture rated 30 percent of the winter wheat crop as being in poor to very poor condition, down 18 percent from the previous week.  Aberdeen American News (S.D.), Nov. 8, 2012

Title: Ethanol plant in South Bend, Indiana holding off on purchasing pricey corn
Description: An ethanol plant in South Bend has not purchased corn in six weeks because corn prices were too high, making the business unprofitable. An ethanol plant in Mt. Vernon, Indiana closed temporarily, as have 26 of the 211 ethanol plants run by the Renewable Fuels Assn. The hot, dry summer reduced corn yields, driving prices to record highs.  Farmer's Exchange (New Paris, Indiana), Nov. 2, 2012
Places: Indiana, Mount Vernon, IN, South Bend, IN

Title: Fewer visitors to ski resorts in Colorado
Description: Ski resorts in Colorado were seeing fewer visitors because low snowfall discouraged skiers from coming.  Skier visits to the 21 resorts in Colorado Ski Country USA were down 11.5 percent through the end of 2012, compared to the previous year.  At Loveland Ski Area, just 40 of the 93 runs were open during the third week of January.  The 2011-12 winter was driest in the last 20 years, and the 2012-2013 season has gotten a slow start, in terms of snowfall.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), Jan. 25, 2013

Title: Dry weather in southern Florida reduced the size of oranges
Description: Dry weather in southern Florida has reduced the size of oranges, driving the price of orange futures 3.2 percent higher.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s forecast for total orange production is 146 million boxes, which is 5 percent lower than October’s forecast.  Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Dec. 12, 2012

Title: Florida citrus crop harmed by a number of factors
Description: Warm, dry weather, heavily-laden citrus trees and citrus greening disease contributed to the losses felt by the citrus growers in Florida.  The USDA adjusted their production estimate from 154 million boxes of fruit in Oct. 2012 to 141 million boxes.  Washington Post (D.C.), March 2, 2013

Title: Drought drove down demand for tractors and storage units for company based in Duluth, Georgia
Description: Drought drove down demand for tractors and storage units, prompting Agco Corp., based in Duluth, Georgia, to trim its forecast for the year after a searing summer of drought.  The company’s full year forecast fell to $5.20 per share, although it was previously expected to range from $5.50 to $5.75.  CNBC (N.J.), Oct. 31, 2012

Title: Iowa's forage experts stated that drought trimmed hay production by a third to a half in most parts of the state
Description: Iowa's forage experts stated that drought trimmed hay production by a third to a half in most parts of the state.  Many cattlemen began feeding hay much earlier than usual because pastures did not grow back well.  Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier (Iowa), Oct. 31, 2012

Title: Water releases increased from two Georgia lakes
Description: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers increased water releases at Lake Lanier from 1,100 cubic feet per second (cfs) to 2,500 cfs and at West Point Lake from 2,100 to 2,300 cfs to 3,500 cfs to provide more water to parched downstream water users in western Georgia, eastern Alabama and northwestern Florida as drought persisted in the region.  The additional water will benefit the middle and lower reaches of the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River Basin.  The releases were intended specifically to boost levels of Lake Seminole in southwest Georgia and Walter F. George Lake on the Georgia-Alabama border.  Atlanta Journal-Constitution (Ga.), Oct. 26, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Barbour County, AL, Chambers County, AL, Henry County, AL, Houston County, AL, Lee County, AL, Russell County, AL, Calhoun County, FL, Franklin County, FL, Gadsden County, FL, Gulf County, FL, Jackson County, FL, Liberty County, FL, Georgia

Title: Agriculture officials in Arkansas warned ranchers not to be too hasty to rebuild their herds
Description: Agriculture officials in Arkansas warned ranchers not to be too hasty to rebuild their herds after some rain greened up the vegetation.  Ranchers also ought to consider forage supplies and the potential for continuing drought in 2013.  Pond and stream levels remained very low.  Arkansas Democrat Gazette (Little Rock, Arkansas), Oct. 27, 2012

Title: Soybean yields in Michigan were about 20 percent lower and corn yields were 25 below last year’s harvest
Description: Soybean yields were about 20 percent lower and corn yields were 25 below last year’s harvest, due to drought, according to a senior extension editor at Michigan State University Extension.  Losses were greatest in the southern part of the state, while the northern part fared much better.  Hay was in very short supply after the dry summer.  Lansing State Journal (Mich.), Oct. 25, 2012

Title: Drought, reduced forage add to challenges for sheep producers in South Dakota
Description: Sheep producers in South Dakota were struggling with low prices for their livestock and too many predators and also have to contend with drought and limited forage for their animals.  The added challenge of drought may make it difficult for sheep producers to remain in business if the drought persists for another year, according to one sheep rancher.  KOTA-TV ABC 3 (S.D.), Oct. 23, 2012

Title: South Dakota sheep ranchers were selling their livestock
Description: South Dakota sheep ranchers were selling their livestock because there was not enough feed for the animals since drought had reduced forage.  Prices for sheep had declined also.  The sheep yard manager in Saint Onge said that prices were much higher in 2011 when some sheep sold for $2.40 per pound, compared to this year when prices have fallen to $1.10 per pound, partly because the slaughterhouses were already full of sheep.  KOTA-TV ABC 3 (Rapid City, S.D.), Oct. 22, 2012

Title: Kansas horse owners struggling to afford hay for their horses
Description: Kansas horse owners were struggling to afford hay for their horses.  Large round bales of hay presently cost $40 to $60 dollars each, but cost an astronomical $115 to $120 per bale at this time last year, due to drought.  Area pastures were still recovering from years of drought.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), Oct. 20, 2013
Places: Kansas, Shawnee County, KS, Silver Lake, KS

Title: More than 8,000 whitetail deer in Michigan died from a disease spread by biting flies
Description: More than 8,000 whitetail deer in Michigan died from a disease spread by biting flies, according to the state Department of Natural Resources.  During the summer, there were reports of deer that had died from the disease, but the number of dead deer had reached 8,671 as of October 8.  Many of the dead deer were in the southern Lower Peninsula, west of Interstate 75.  More deer carcasses are likely to be found as the corn harvest progresses.  An employee at a sporting goods store in Hastings said that people were buying fewer guns, arrows and crossbows this year ahead of the November 15 start of the deer season.  He also stated that some hunters planned not to hunt in favor of letting the remaining deer repopulate.  Dayton Daily News (Ohio), Oct. 20, 2012

Title: Food and Drug Administration permitting Kansas elevators to mix aflatoxin-tainted corn with other corn for animal feed
Description: Much of the corn in central Kansas tested positive for aflatoxin this year because drought stressed the corn, increasing the likelihood that aflatoxin would be present.  Because so much corn was contaminated with aflatoxin, the Food and Drug Administration is permitting Kansas elevators to mix the tainted corn with other corn that has little or no aflatoxin for animal feed.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Oct. 19, 2012

Title: Dairy farmer in Reno County, Kansas losing money with high production costs
Description: A couple with dairy cattle near Hutchinson had 900 acres of milo and corn mainly for cattle feed that were not harvestable for the second straight year, due to drought, but cut the crops for silage instead to feed to the cattle.  The awareness that he was losing money on his dairy activities with the high cost of feed weighed heavily on the farmer’s mind.  The expense of feed has made it difficult for many dairies across the nation to stay open and forced some to close, but the challenge has been particularly intense in Kansas because the last two summers were dry.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Oct. 19, 2012

Title: Drought and strong winds in Kansas have boosted the amount of particulate matter in the air
Description: Drought and strong winds in Kansas have boosted the amount of particulate matter in the air.  The state Department of Health and Environment found particulate levels to be nearly 200 micro grams per cubic meter in Wichita on the day several vehicles crashed due to poor visibility in northern Oklahoma.  The federal standard for a 24-hour period is 150 micro grams per cubic meter.  Pratt Tribune (Kan.), Oct. 30, 2012

Title: Non-essential water use to be curtailed in Minnesota
Description: An official with the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources announced that all nonessential water use should be curtailed in the state.  In northeastern, north-central and southern parts of Minnesota, 50 companies were told to stop drawing water from streams and to use alternative water supplies.  Businesses along the St. Louis River system, such as the Sappi Fine Paper mill and the USG ceiling panel plant in Cloquet, were affected.  Brainerd Daily Dispatch (Minn.), Oct. 18, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Sixty percent of the corn harvest in Indiana was complete and revealed a 40 percent reduction on the corn yield
Description: Sixty percent of the corn harvest in Indiana was complete and revealed a 40 percent reduction on the corn yield in the state, according to a Purdue University agricultural economist.  The average corn yield this year was 100 bushels per acre, in comparison with better years when the yield is normally 165 bushels per acre.  Roughly 40 percent of the soybean crop has been harvested and showed nearly a 20 percent decline in yield at 41 bushels per acre, down from the usual 50 bushels per acre.  WVUT-TV Vincennes University (Ind.), Oct. 16, 2012

Title: Different start to pheasant season in Minnesota
Description: The hot, dry summer brought changes for the pheasant season that began on October 13.  Drought allowed the corn to mature and be harvested about three weeks ahead of schedule, leaving no tall cornfields as cover for the birds.  More than 53 percent of the corn was harvested as of the week ending in October 5, according to the director of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service in St. Paul.  Some grasslands in the federal Conservation Reserve Program and the Walk-In Access lands were cut for hay because livestock producers needed food for the cattle or expired and were plowed in preparation for spring planting.  All of these changes left pheasants more exposed than in previous years.  Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Oct. 6, 2012

Title: Iowa State University agriculture experts advised farmers to test forages for quality
Description: Iowa State University agriculture experts advised farmers to test forages for quality this fall because variable nutrient levels and high nitrate levels can occur in forages grown during drought.  Corn silage, for example, ought to be tested for protein, energy, other nutrient values and nitrate levels.  Mason City Globe-Gazette (Iowa), Oct. 24, 2012

Title: U.S. Department of Agriculture anticipated decreased corn and soybean yields for Iowa
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture anticipated that Iowa corn and soybean yields would be 140 bushels and 43 bushels per acre, respectively, after a hot, dry summer decreased production.  The average corn and soybean yields last year were 172 bushels and more than 50 bushels per acre.  WHO-TV NBC 13 Des Moines (Iowa), Oct. 12, 2012

Title: Iowa farmers were urged to avoid tilling the soil
Description: Iowa farmers were urged to avoid tilling the soil to retain soil moisture and reduce erosion as dry conditions persist.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Oct. 11, 2012

Title: Ranchers in Montana were selling greater numbers of cattle than usual
Description: Ranchers in Montana were selling greater numbers of cattle than usual because drought reduced the amount of useable pasture and water and hay prices were high, stated the natural resources director with the Montana Stockgrowers Association.  In some instances, wildfires burned fences, which also pushed ranchers to sell.  An additional 1,000 head per sale moved through auctions in Billings and Miles City, compared to sales numbers in 2011.  Calves were sold early also.  Missoula Missoulian (Mont.), Oct. 8, 2012
Places: Montana, Miles City, MT, Billings, MT

Title: Nebraska forester urged tree watering to avoid drought damage
Description: Trees, especially young trees, should be watered in the fall and during the winter when the ground is not frozen to keep the trees alive and healthy during drought, said a Nebraska forester.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Oct. 8, 2012

Title: The governor of Washington prohibited outdoor burning on private lands
Description: The governor of Washington prohibited outdoor burning on private lands to lessen the likelihood of a fire.  Tacoma News Tribune (Wash.), Oct. 7, 2012

Title: The U.S. Department of Agriculture scheduled four regional workshops to inform farmers and ranchers about resources to help them through drought
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture scheduled four regional workshops to inform farmers and ranchers about resources to help them through a season of drought.  The workshops were to be held in Omaha, Nebraska; Pueblo, Colorado; Pine Bluff, Arkansas; and an undetermined location in Ohio.  The Commerce Department, the Small Business Administration and the Federal Emergency Management Agency were also involved with planning for these meetings.  Dayton Daily News (Ohio), Oct. 7, 2012
Places: Pine Bluff, AR, Pueblo, CO, Omaha, NE, Ohio

Title: Washington Department of Natural Resources issued an emergency order banning fires
Description: The Washington Department of Natural Resources (WDNR) issued an emergency order banning all fires on state, private and tribal forest lands in the state under the WDNR’s management protection or administration.  Tacoma News Tribune (Wash.), Oct. 7, 2012

Title: Michigan vintners were thrilled with the grapes after a hot, arid summer
Description: Michigan vintners were thrilled with the grapes after a hot, arid summer because such conditions make the grapes sweeter and more flavorful.  A member of the Michigan Wine Producers Association stated that wine merchants were anticipating that 2012 will go down as one of the best years for grapes and Michigan wines.  The grape harvest started about a month early in many places because the warm growing season hastened grape growth and maturity.  Lansing State Journal (Mich.), Oct. 4, 2012

Title: Californians urged to be cautious with fire outdoors
Description: Warm temperatures and drought prompted Cal Fire officials to urge Californians to be especially careful with fire outdoors since the fire season has been particularly active this year.  Since the start of 2012, Cal Fire has fought 5,300 wildfires that burned nearly 130,000 acres, compared to the 4,000 wildfires that charred 55,000 acres in 2011.  The second largest wildfire in the history of the state occurred in August when the Rush Fire scorched 271,911 acres in Lassen County.  Lake County News (Calif.), Oct. 4, 2012

Title: Drought caused the price of hay to triple in Illinois
Description: Drought has caused the price of hay to triple due to both lowered hay supply and higher demand for it. A 9-acre hay field near Amboy usually produces about 300 bales with each cutting, but yielded just 87 bales in early October.  Hay prices have risen to $7 to $10 per bale, up from about $2.50 to $3 per bale.  As a result, horse owners are under financial pressure to let go of horses. Also, a Champaign-based nonprofit humane society has seen an upswing in the number of cases of starving horses this summer. Daily Illini (Champaign, Ill.), Oct. 3, 2012

Title: Thousands of white-tailed deer dead from epizootic hemorrhagic disease in northern and eastern Nebraska
Description: Epizootic hemorrhagic disease killed large numbers of white-tailed deer in northern and eastern Nebraska.  The state Game and Parks Commission fielded more than 3,000 calls from people who reported dead deer floating in rivers and creeks and in harvested grain fields.  The disease seemed to affect localized areas and was not widespread.  The Game and Parks Commission may reduce the number of deer permits while the deer population is enduring this outbreak.  EHD outbreaks are often worse in drought years when deer cluster around sparse water holes, allowing midges that carry the disease to infect animals more easily.  Nebraska Radio Network, Oct. 2, 2012

Title: Leaders in North Dakota met to consider what actions might be taken if drought persists another year or more
Description: Leaders in North Dakota met in Fargo to consider what actions might be taken if drought persists another year or more.  Planning was highly recommended from state to city level.  Fargo has been considering alternate water supplies from the Missouri River, but has not yet settled on a course of action.  Jamestown Sun (N.D.), Oct. 2, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought-stressed alfalfa in Wisconsin suffered from high rates of winterkill
Description: Drought-stressed alfalfa in Wisconsin suffered from high rates of winterkill and a particularly wet spring, according to an agriculture instructor at Mid-State Technical College.  He expects that up to 10 percent of the farmers in Wood, Marathon and Clark counties may stop farming due to financial problems after two years of poor weather.  Farmers in this area are struggling to get their first cutting of hay and alfalfa after feeding all of their hay during the winter.  Wet fields kept some farmers from planting corn by the mid-May crop insurance deadline, but some farmers, desperate for feed, are still trying to plant corn to use it as silage.  Lacrosse Tribune (Wis.), July 8, 2013
Places: Wisconsin, Clark County, WI, Marathon County, WI, Wood County, WI

Title: The total deer harvest in Nebraska was down 30 percent
Description: The total deer harvest in Nebraska was down 30 percent to 60,548 after exceptional drought and an unusually severe episode of epizootic hemorrhagic disease killed thousands of whitetail deer, leading the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission to cut the number of antlerless permits.  Hunters bought fewer permits and killed fewer deer.  Deer permit sales dropped 13 percent to 122,214 in 2012.  The whitetail buck harvest was 26,309 or 29 percent less than the previous year; the whitetail antlerless harvest was 24,974 or 36 percent lower; the mule deer buck harvest was 7,325 or 3 percent less; and the mule deer antlerless harvest was 1,940 or 8 percent lower than in 2011.  Panhandle Post (Chadron, Neb.), March 1, 2013

Title: Many dairies in California have closed, due to high feed costs and low milk prices
Description: Many dairies in California have closed as high feed prices after an intense summer of drought and low milk prices set by the California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA) drove them out of business.  Dairymen in Wisconsin and Minnesota down to Missouri were also feeling the pain of high corn and soybean prices.  Milk prices determined by the CDFA have been often $2 per hundredweight lower than in the rest of the country during 2011 and 2012, putting California dairy farmers at a disadvantage.  A CDFA spokesman explained that the lower milk prices were due to the glut of milk in the state.  Nearly 300 California dairies have closed since 2008, leaving 1,668 dairies still in operation.  Another several hundred dairies may be on the verge of shutting their doors this year.  The San Luis Obispo County Tribune (Calif.), Sept. 29, 2012

Title: Kansas governor asked water experts to meet to slow use of state's aquifers
Description: The governor of Kansas asked the state’s water experts to meet in October to find the best way to conserve the water that the state still has as the levels of underground aquifer were falling at an alarming rate.  MSNBC, Sept. 28, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought cost Arkansas beef cattle producers about $128 million
Description: Drought cost Arkansas beef cattle producers about $128 million, according to a survey done by the University of Arkansas System Division of Agriculture.  Because the estimate does not include economic impacts at a community level, the loss estimate is considered to be conservative.  The loss amounts to $141 per cow in the state.  Most Arkansas ranches have roughly 36 head of cattle, amounting to an average loss of $5,000 for each producer.  KTHV-TV CBS 11 Little Rock (Ark.), Sept. 27, 2012

Title: The Illinois Department of Natural Resources estimated in September that Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease had killed over 700 deer
Description: The Illinois Department of Natural Resources estimated in September that Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease had killed over 700 deer.  The extreme dryness this summer has caused deer populations to congregate around limited water sources, where they are bitten by disease carrying gnats. The gnats transmit Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease to deer, a viral disease that causes high fever, internal bleeding, and eventually death. EHD does not affect people and usually will not harm domestic animals.  State Journal-Register (Springfield, Ill.), Sept. 27, 2012

Title: Aflatoxin contaminated corn to be fed to cattle in Indiana
Description: Indiana’s cattle may be fed corn with low levels of aflatoxin after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted the request from the Indiana State Department of Agriculture to mix the aflatoxin-contaminated corn with other cattle feed, thereby stretching feed supplies and making use of as much of the states’ corn as possible.  Farmer's Exchange (Ind.), Oct. 5, 2012

Title: Illinois trees putting on a less vibrant display this fall
Description: The combination of three wetter-than-average years in a row (2009-2011) followed by the severe drought of this past summer has reduced oxygen and water storage capacity in tree roots, resulting in a dull fall.  Trees are not as capable of producing carbohydrates and sugars when they do not get enough moisture, which makes leaves turn brown instead of the usual vibrant fall colors.  In extreme cases, leaves will simply fall off without changing color at all.  Chicago Tribune (Ill.), Sept. 25, 2012

Title: Many cattle producers in Utah were taking their livestock off mountain grazing land early
Description: Many cattle producers in Utah were taking their livestock off mountain grazing land early since drought withered the forage.  Because the price of feed was three times what it used to be, many livestock were up for sale.  A leader at the Utah Cattlemen’s Association stated, “I am hearing ranchers say they have never seen a year like this, ever."  Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), Sept. 23, 2012

Title: The governor of Colorado lifted restrictions on the transportation of hay
Description: The governor of Colorado lifted restrictions on the transportation of hay when he signed an executive order on September 23 easing height and weight limits.  The order was effective through October 21.  Fort Collins Coloradoan (Colo.), Sept. 23, 2012.  The executive order was extended another 30 days.  Denver Post (Colo.), Oct. 24, 2012

Title: Additional firefighting resources in Minnesota
Description: Due to the elevated fire danger, the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources brought additional firefighting resources to combat fires and placed them on a Level 5 alert, the highest level.  The Minnesota Incident Command System agencies were concerned that the extended dry spell would allow large woody debris and standing conifer trees to ignite easily, as well as peat soils.Alexandria Echo Press (Minn.), Sept. 21, 2012
Places: Minnesota, Becker County, MN, Beltrami County, MN, Benton County, MN, Cass County, MN, Clearwater County, MN, Douglas County, MN, Hubbard County, MN, Kanabec County, MN, Kittson County, MN, Lake of the Woods County, MN, Mahnomen County, MN, Marshall County, MN, Mille Lacs County, MN, Morrison County, MN, Otter Tail County, MN, Pennington County, MN, Polk County, MN, Red Lake County, MN, Roseau County, MN, Stearns County, MN, Todd County, MN, Wadena County, MN

Title: Dry pastures, low water supplies in North Dakota
Description: Dry conditions in North Dakota left almost two-thirds of the pasture and rangeland in the state in poor to very poor condition.  More than half of the stock water supplies were short to very short.  The Jamestown Sun (N.D.), Sept. 18, 2012

Title: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife prohibited use of fire on its land
Description: The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) prohibited fires, campfires, outdoor smoking, outdoor welding, chain saws, internal combustion power tools, target shooting, save that done at established range sites and off road vehicles driven in backcountry locales on all lands belonging to the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife in the state.  Tacoma News Tribune (Wash.), Oct. 7, 2012

Title: Surface water use permits suspended, restricted across Minnesota
Description: The Minnesota Department of Natural Resources suspended or restricted surface water use permits to businesses, golf courses, parks departments and others in various parts of the state as drought lowered river flows.  Sixteen users from Moorhead to users in the southeastern part of the state were told that their water withdrawals were suspended until conditions improve.Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Sept. 17, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Illinois shorebirds struggle to find food, but wetland vegetation is lush and will benefit ducks
Description: In addition to the fish kills and outbreak of deer disease this summer, the drought has had both positive and negative effects on Illinois birds. Wetland vegetation has flourished on the banks of the receded Illinois River, creating a dense cover of vegetation on any bare ground. On one hand, this has made life for shorebirds very difficult, as there is no exposed mud for them to probe for food. On the other hand, however, ducks and other water birds will have a huge amount of food to feast on when water returns to the area.  Fisheries biologists say that while many fish died from elevated water temperatures and low oxygen levels, it was unclear how many fish died and what must be done to restore the fish populations.  State Journal-Register (Springfield, Ill.), Sept. 15, 2012

Title: Hay thefts increased in Colorado as drought reduced supplies
Description: Hay thefts have increased in Colorado as drought reduced supplies, leading to higher prices for the hay.  In one instance, hay thieves hotwired heavy farm equipment to take $5,000 in hay from a Larimer County farm.  The sheriff’s office urged those with hay to keep it out of sight and in a safe location.  Smaller bales ought to be kept near homes and inside a sturdy fence with a locked gate.  Bozeman KBZK (Mont.), Sept. 14, 2012

Title: Free nitrate testing for drought-stricken corn at Husker Harvest Days
Description: Drought brings a higher risk of dangerous nitrate levels in cornstalks and stems, prompting the University of Nebraska-Lincoln to offer free nitrate testing at Husker Harvest Days near Grand Island.  Cattle can die from ingesting corn with high nitrate levels.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Sept. 12, 2012

Title: The Iowa Fire Service Training Bureau stopped or altered some training activities to conserve water
Description: The Iowa Fire Service Training Bureau stopped or altered some training activities to conserve water while the state is in drought.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Sept. 12, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: 16 Kansas dairymen dumped aflatoxin-tainted milk
Description: The Kansas dairy commissioner said that 16 dairymen statewide have had to dump milk since Sept. 11 because the level of aflatoxin in the milk was too high from the cattle eating aflatoxin-tainted corn.  A dairyman in Reno County dumped about $5,000 worth of “hot milk” or aflatoxin-tainted milk on his alfalfa for one week in October because the level of aflatoxin was too high—above 0.5 parts per billion—for the milk processing plant to accept it.  It was a bitter disappointment to have to waste the milk, but it was not fit for human consumption.  Since changing his cows’ feed ration from corn to milo and wheat, the cows were not getting adequate energy from the feed and were producing less milk.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Oct. 19, 2012

Title: Late spring freeze, drought diminished apple crop in Illinois
Description: The combination of an early spring, followed by a freeze in April, and the persistent summer drought has drastically reduced apple yields at Curtis Orchard to “ten percent or less” of that produced in a normal year. Although the drought certainly didn’t help, the first two factors were most problematic; the early spring caused fruit to start growing early, which then enabled the frost to freeze a big part of the crop. Orchards across the nation are all experiencing this problem, and many are forced to close for the year or purchase fruit from neighboring cities or states.  Champaign News-Gazette (Ill.), Sept. 9, 2012

Title: Many cattlemen in Nevada have been forced to sell livestock because dry conditions have prevented pastures from growing well
Description: Many cattlemen in Nevada have been forced to sell livestock because dry conditions have prevented pastures from growing well, according to the president of the Nevada Cattlemen’s Association.  He suspects that grazing allotments will be slow to recover even with a good winter and expects that there will be few options for out of state grazing, given the drought in Idaho, Wyoming, the Dakotas and other states.  Wildfires contributed to the problem as flames consumed plenty of rangeland this summer, leaving less alternative rangeland for grazing.  Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Sept. 9, 2012

Title: The governor of Missouri urged crisis centers in the state to address suicide prevention in farming communities because prolonged drought has increased stress
Description: The governor of Missouri urged crisis centers in the state to address suicide prevention in farming communities because prolonged drought has increased stress to unbearable levels for some in agriculture.  Drought has caused crop and pasture losses, forcing some farmers and ranchers to think about how much loss they can sustain before they must alter their operation dramatically or even get out of the business.  About 700 fliers were distributed by crisis workers this month.  A suicide prevention counselor at Freeman Hospital in Neosho said that their hotline has been getting 40 to 70 calls per week from farmers under great stress after a very difficult summer of drought.  The number for the National Hopeline Network, one of many suicide hotlines, is 1-800-SUICIDE (1-800-784-2433).  OzarksFirst.com (Mo.), Sept. 7, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Nine cattle in Nebraska died from Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease
Description: Nine cattle in Nebraska died from Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease (EHD), a disease that more commonly affects deer.  EHD is spread by biting gnats, causes internal bleeding and has killed at least 700 deer in Illinois this summer.   The state veterinarian confirmed the cases of EHD in cattle in various parts of the state and urged producers to check with their veterinarian if they think their cattle are affected.  Symptoms of EHD in livestock include fever, swollen eyes, ulcers on the mouth, lameness and labored breathing.  The first autumn frost usually stops EHD outbreaks.  WHIO (Dayton, Ohio), Sept. 6, 2012

Title: Feedlots in Idaho not making profit
Description: A Nampa man who owns feedlots in Oregon, Melba and Twin Falls with 6,000 to 30,000 cattle said that higher corn prices meant that his feedlots were not quite breaking even or were just breaking even.  The price of feed corn rose to $300 per ton from $200 per ton.  The market price for cattle is roughly $1.20 per pound, but that it runs feedlots about $1.30 per pound to put weight on the animals, according to the executive vice president of the Idaho Cattle Association.  The feedlot owner said that he needed to get $1.25 per pound to break even and said that he may need to lay off some employees if corn prices continue to rise.  Boise Idaho Statesman, Sept. 6, 2012
Places: Idaho, Melba, ID, Twin Falls, ID

Title: Farmers compete against energy companies for available water in Colorado
Description: Farmers are competing against energy companies for available water in Colorado and fear that they will lose because they cannot pay as much for water as the energy companies can. Farmers pay $30 per acre-foot for water, and even up to $100 per acre-foot when water supplies are tighter.  Energy companies pay $1,000 to $2,000 for the same amount of municipal water. Boise Idaho Statesman, Sept. 6, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Emergency haying and grazing program in Montana
Description: An emergency haying and grazing program in Montana was extended through November 30 so ranchers may access Conservation Reserve Program land since feed supplies were low.  Bozeman Daily Chronicle (Mont.), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: USDA Designates 4 Counties in Montana as Primary Natural Disaster Areas With Assistance to Producers in Surrounding Counties and States
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) on Sept. 5 designated four counties in Montana as primary natural disaster areas due to damages and losses caused by the recent drought. Ten contiguous counties in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming were also eligible for low-interest emergency loans under this declaration. This declaration permits  farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural producers who meet eligibility requirements to apply for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.  USDA FSA press release, Sept. 5, 2012, Bozeman Daily Chronicle (Mont.), Sept. 5, 2012
Places: Fremont County, ID, Beaverhead County, MT, Broadwater County, MT, Deer Lodge County, MT, Gallatin County, MT, Jefferson County, MT, Lewis and Clark County, MT, Madison County, MT, Meagher County, MT, Park County, MT, Powell County, MT, Silver Bow County, MT, Wyoming, Park County, WY, Teton County, WY

Title: Carp died from depleted, warm pond at state park in eastern Iowa
Description: Ponds in the Mines of Spain State Park were depleted and warmer than usual from the hot, dry summer, causing carp to die.  Farm ponds and other backwaters cut off from river and streams have also been the sites of fish kills.  Dubuque Telegraph Herald (Iowa), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: Emergency haying and grazing permitted on land in Reinvest in Minnesota program
Description: The Board of Water and Soil Resources is permitting emergency haying and grazing on drought-affected land in 70 of the state’s 87 counties with land in the Reinvest in Minnesota program.  Alexandria Echo Press (Minn.), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: USDA Designates All Counties in Indiana as Primary Natural Disaster Areas with Assistance to Producers in Surrounding States
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) on Sept. 5, 2012, designated the entire state of Indiana, which includes 92 counties, as a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by the combined effects of excessive heat, frost, freeze and drought that began Feb. 1, 2012, and continues. Agricultural producers in contiguous counties in adjacent states are also eligible for low-interest emergency loans. USDA Farm Service Agency press release, Sept. 5, 2012.
Places: Clark County, IL, Cook County, IL, Crawford County, IL, Edgar County, IL, Gallatin County, IL, Iroquois County, IL, Kankakee County, IL, Lawrence County, IL, Vermilion County, IL, Wabash County, IL, White County, IL, Will County, IL, Indiana, Boone County, KY, Breckinridge County, KY, Carroll County, KY, Daviess County, KY, Gallatin County, KY, Hancock County, KY, Hardin County, KY, Henderson County, KY, Jefferson County, KY, Meade County, KY, Oldham County, KY, Trimble County, KY, Union County, KY, Berrien County, MI, Branch County, MI, Cass County, MI, Hillsdale County, MI, Saint Joseph County, MI, Butler County, OH, Darke County, OH, Defiance County, OH, Hamilton County, OH, Mercer County, OH, Paulding County, OH, Preble County, OH, Van Wert County, OH, Williams County, OH

Title: Many livestock producers in Nebraska selling cattle
Description: Many livestock producers in Nebraska were selling cattle as 95 percent of the pasture and rangeland in the state was in poor to very poor condition, according to the USDA.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: USDA conservation easement holders in South Dakota urged to consider management options
Description: The state conservationist with the USDA’s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) in Huron urged USDA conservation easement holders to consider their management options during drought.  Easement holders can ask to use the Wetlands Reserve Program or Emergency Watershed Protection Program, which will prompt the local NRCS to assess the habitat conditions and decide the terms of use for the land.  The main purpose of protecting wildlife habitat will remain the top concern for the easement.  Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: Drought has encouraged the formation of peculiar blobs in the Wapsipinicon River in Iowa
Description: Drought has encouraged the formation of peculiar blobs in the Wapsipinicon River in Iowa and other Iowa rivers.  The slimy, firm things are actually clusters of bryozoa, or a colony of tiny, filter-feeding animals with the scientific name Pectinatella mangifica.   A fisheries biologist with the Department of Natural Resources at Manchester said that the blobs form when the water is warm with little to no current.  A biology professor and bryozoan expert at Wright State University in Ohio said that the blobs are colonies of many thousands of animals that have no sensory organs or ability to move and adhere to each other for mutual benefit.  “The colony creates its own current that draws in water, enabling each individual to be more efficient in filtering nutrients from the water,” he explained.  The colonies are not harmful to people, but they can clog water intakes.  A photo of a two-foot long colony accompanied the article.  Cedar Rapids Gazette (Iowa), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: Drought limited popcorn production in Illinois
Description: The drought that wreaked havoc on crops throughout the summer has also had a drastic effect on the productivity of popcorn plants nationwide.  Retail prices for popcorn rose from roughly $20 for a 50 pound bag to at least $30, stated the owner of Pop It Rite.  Wholesale prices were rising also.  Because of the shortage in supply, consumers can expect to see an increase in the price of popcorn on supermarket shelves.  However, because the price of popcorn in theaters is already so inflated, moviegoers will most likely not have to pay more for a bucket of the popular snack.  As the corn crop suffered and popcorn prices rose, the Weaver Popcorn Company Inc. looked further afield for popcorn growers, talking with farmers in Louisiana, other southern states and even South America.  Chicago Tribune (Ill.), Sept. 2, 2012

Title: Additional cow elk tags issued in Utah
Description: The Utah Wildlife Board approved 1,450 additional cow elk permits, with nearly 1,200 of those permits for the wildlife units in the Uintah Basin.  The need for the additional permits stemmed from meager rainfall since early April and poor range conditions that provide inadequate vegetation to sustain the deer and elk that overwinter there.  The goal was to reduce the cow elk population to give deer a better chance to survive the winter.  Salt Lake City Deseret Morning News (Utah), Sept. 2, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Utah, Carbon County, UT, Daggett County, UT, Duchesne County, UT, Emery County, UT, Grand County, UT, Uintah County, UT, Wasatch County, UT

Title: The number of cattle taken to Kansas feedlots in September down 25 percent
Description: The number of cattle taken to Kansas feedlots in September was 25 percent lower than in September 2011, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  In addition, the number of cattle sold by feedlots to packers was 17 percent lower also.  Drought and heat limited hay supplies and desiccated surface waters in southern Kansas in 2011 and parched all of the state in 2012.  The Wichita Eagle (Kan.), Oct. 28, 2012

Title: Hay available for South Dakota ranchers affected by fire in 2012
Description: About 400 donated 2011 Conservation Reserve Program mid-term management hay bales were available through the South Dakota Department of Agriculture (SDDA).  Livestock producers who own or lease land affected by wildfires this year are invited to apply for the hay.  Others with 2011 CRP mid-term management hay were encouraged to give the baled residue to the SDDA instead of destroying it.  Applications must be received by Sept. 7 at 5p.m.  Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), Sept. 1, 2012

Title: Montana Governor Schweitzer issued an executive order declaring a statewide fire emergency
Description: Montana Governor Schweitzer issued an executive order declaring a statewide fire emergency, due to the hot dry conditions and the elevated fire danger.Helena Independent Record (Mont.), Aug. 31, 2012

Title: Montana archers, hunters should check for land closures due to fire danger
Description: Officials with Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks urged archers and bird hunters to make sure certain areas have not been closed due to the fire danger or presence of fires.  Stage 1 fire restrictions remained in effect on state and federal lands, prohibiting open fires.  Helena Independent Record (Mont.), Aug. 31, 2012
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation

Title: The Illinois Department of Transportation began allowing hay shipments on interstates effective August 31 to hasten the delivery of hay
Description: The Illinois Department of Transportation began allowing hay shipments on interstates effective August 31 to hasten the delivery of hay to hungry livestock.  Hay loads up to 12 feet wide may be moved on interstates, whereas they were previously only allowed on state routes.  This authorization extends through December 31, 2012.  Grainnet (Decatur, Illinois), Sept. 4, 2012

Title: The Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship began aflatoxin screening on August 31 to ensure that milk remained safe for consumption
Description: The Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship began aflatoxin screening on August 31 to ensure that milk remained safe for consumption.  Milk processors began screening Grade A and Grade B farm bulk milk pickup tankers and farm can milk loads for aflatoxin each week.  Drought can encourage the growth of a fungus that produces harmful aflatoxin.  The department will also begin testing corn across the state for aflatoxin.  Corn with aflatoxin levels of 20 parts per billion (ppb) or higher cannot be used for human consumption or for feed for dairy animals or immature animals.  Nebraska City News-Press (Neb.), Aug. 29, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Excessively hot and dry conditions in Illinois favored the growth of an invasive variety of pigweed
Description: The excessively hot and dry conditions of the summer have favored the growth of an invasive variety of pigweed. The weed, which can grow up to six feet tall, is capable of killing off entire fields, as it did in 2011 to numerous soybean crops in the South. Farmers should be especially fearful of pigweed, as it is resistant to glyphosate herbicides and can grow two to three inches a day.	Peoria Journal Star (Ill.), Aug. 27, 2012

Title: Less food, water for doves in Missouri
Description: Dove hunters in Missouri were urged to be particularly careful this year because drought has limited the food supplies and water sources for the doves, thereby reducing the amount of land suitable for dove hunting.  More hunters than usual may be concentrated in smaller areas, increasing the likelihood of an accident if hunters are not careful.  Dove season opens on Saturday, September 1.  Columbia Missourian, Aug. 24, 2012

Title: The governor of South Dakota eased restrictions on height and weight requirements for trucks transporting hay
Description: The governor of South Dakota eased restrictions on height and weight requirements for trucks transporting hay.  The drought dried up pastures and the hay crop, making it a challenge to keep livestock fed.  Grand Forks Herald (N.D.), Aug. 24, 2012.  The easing of restrictions will continue through Dec. 21.  Rapid City Journal (S.D.), Oct. 19, 2012.  Oversized loads of hay may be moved on South Dakota roads through Feb. 21, 2013.  Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), Dec. 21, 2012

Title: All Kansas counties received federal disaster designation
Description: Marshall County was designated a federal natural disaster area, the last Kansas county to receive the designation, as drought and heat devastated agricultural activity in the state.  Topeka Capital Journal (Kan.), Aug. 24, 2012

Title: Wells running dry in Indiana
Description: Between 100 and 150 people reported to Indiana state officials that their wells were dry or nearly dry from mid-June through the end of July, said the head of the water rights and use division of the Indiana Department of Natural Resources.  New York Times, Aug. 23, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Private wells running dry in Illinois
Description: Although Illinois did not keep track of dry private wells, Frank Dunmire, executive director of the Illinois Rural Water Association, in Taylorvillle, noted that there was abundant anecdotal evidence that more private wells were running dry amid the summer drought.Quincy Herald-Whig (Ill.), Aug. 21, 2012
Places: Illinois, Cass County, IL, Madison County, IL

Title: Increased need for well drilling in Audrain County, Missouri
Description: The demand for well drilling was higher than usual in Audrain County, stated a well driller based in Mexico.  He noted that farmers needed water for their livestock as ponds went dry.  In Audrain County, his business drilled 10 wells in two weeks.  Quincy Herald-Whig (Ill.), Aug. 21, 2012
Places: Missouri, Audrain County, MO, Mexico, MO

Title: Drought led the Idaho Wheat Commission to scale back spring wheat production forecasts by 36 percent
Description: Drought led the Idaho Wheat Commission to scale back spring wheat production forecasts by 36 percent.  The spring wheat yield was expected to be 72 bushels per acre, compared to 84 bushels per acre in 2011.  Production was expected to be 33.1 million bushels from 460, 000 harvested acres.   "The dryland fields of east Idaho are hurting the most," according to the Idaho Wheat Commission executive director. "There are fields there where if you take a head of wheat and rub it though your hands, there will be no kernels."  Much of the wheat crop in the state was fine, other than the rainfed wheat in eastern Idaho.  Capital Press - Agriculture Weekly (Salem, Ore.), Aug. 21, 2012

Title: Feed costs skyrocketing for Mississippi catfish farmers
Description: Catfish producers in Mississippi were paying nearly $570 per ton of feed in August 2012, compared to just $380 per ton during the fall of 2011, according to Jimmy Avery, Mississippi State University Extension aquaculture specialist and director of the Southern Regional Aquaculture Center.  Feed costs hovered around $400 per ton in the spring of 2012, but shot up in recent weeks.  Demand for farm-raised catfish had also fallen, as have fish prices, making it harder for producers to cover costs.Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, Miss.), Aug. 20, 2012

Title: The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency was allowing power plants to release hot water into waterways
Description: The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency was allowing four coal-fired and four nuclear power plants to release hundreds of millions of gallons of hot water near 100 degrees Fahrenheit into state lakes and rivers, according to the Chicago Tribune.  Environmentalists fear that the hot water will harm wildlife, but the electricity generated by the plants is needed.  The director of the Natural Resources Defense Council stated that the power plants ought to simply power down rather than releasing the hot water into area waterways, because Illinois exports electricity.  None of the fish kills in the state were linked directly to the hot water from power plants.  Peoria Journal Star (Ill.), Aug. 20, 2012

Title: Dry conditions hurt the Wyoming hay crop
Description: Dry conditions have hurt the Wyoming hay crop, driving estimates down to an expected yield of 925,000 acres of hay and an overall tonnage of 1.82 million tons, 23 percent lower than the 2011 harvest.  If this comes to pass, it will be the worst hay acreage in almost 80 years and the worst production since 2002.  The director of the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service office in Cheyenne said that the lousy hay crop has raised prices.  Casper Star-Tribune (Wyo.), Aug. 18, 2012

Title: Some plants in Illinois backyard gardens surprisingly productive
Description: While yielding near-disastrous results on various cash crops across the nation, the lack of rain this summer has had an overall positive effect on personal gardens.  Since plants were not being watered by rain, gardeners took a more active role in caring for their gardens to ensure that their roots were getting enough water.  Produce that thrives in hot weather, such as tomatoes and squash, has done remarkably well this year, especially since the heat reduced the amount of disease in vegetables.  Chicago Tribune (Ill.), Aug. 18, 2012

Title: Less demand for crop spraying in Oklahoma
Description: An agricultural pilot who sprays fields in Oklahoma for weeds and pests said that the drought has greatly reduced demand for his services since nearly all of Oklahoma’s farmland is rain fed. Herbicide is only effective when plants are growing, but the lack of moisture was not encouraging plant growth.  StateImpact Oklahoma, Aug. 17, 2012

Title: Fewer livestock entered in Nebraska State Fair
Description: About ten percent fewer livestock were entered in the open class competition at the Nebraska State Fair, due to continuing drought, poor pastures and high feed costs, according to Bill Angell, Nebraska State Fair livestock superintendent. Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Aug. 17, 2012
Places: Nebraska, Hall County, NE, Grand Island, NE

Title: More Iowans calling the Iowa Concern Hotline
Description: More Iowans were calling the Iowa Concern Hotline, which provides helpful information referral and legal advice.  Many of the recent calls have been about how to stretch household finances as food prices rise.  The line was originally the Rural Concern Hotline when it was created in 1985 amid the farm crisis, but has evolved to encompass other sectors as well.  The number is 800-447-1985.  KJAN-AM (Iowa), Aug. 17, 2012

Title: Home foundations cracked in Illinois
Description: Many Illinois homeowners noticed cracked basement walls as drought caused damage to home foundations.  Repair costs typically run in the thousands and are not often covered by insurance. Quincy Herald-Whig (Ill.), Aug. 16, 2012

Title: Drought watches, warnings for parts of Virginia
Description: The Appomattox River Basin was in a drought warning due to low rainfall and high temperatures.  People were asked to conserve water voluntarily.  In the Northern Piedmont and Roanoke River drought evaluation regions, there were drought watches to alert the public that drought conditions may be on the horizon if rain does not fall soon.  Stream flows, groundwater levels, agriculture and public water supplies were feeling the effects of the low rainfall, stated the Virginia Drought Management Task Force.  WAMU FM 88.5 American University Radio (Washington D.C.), Aug. 16, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Virginia, Amelia County, VA, Amherst County, VA, Appomattox County, VA, Bedford City, VA, Botetourt County, VA, Buckingham County, VA, Campbell County, VA, Charles City County, VA, Chesapeake City, VA, Chesterfield County, VA, Cumberland County, VA, Dinwiddie County, VA, Hampton City, VA, Henrico County, VA, Isle of Wight County, VA, James City County, VA, Newport News City, VA, Powhatan County, VA, Prince Edward County, VA, Prince George County, VA, Rockbridge County, VA, Suffolk City, VA, Surry County, VA, Virginia Beach City, VA

Title: Some Hawaiian ranchers sold cattle when pastures became depleted
Description: Grass on the Ponoholo Ranch on the Big Island was scarce, forcing the sale of about 2,000 cattle.  Drought has affected this part of the island for eight years.  Cattle on the Parker Ranch were moved from the dry slopes of Mauna Kea to the Waimea side of the ranch which receives more rainfall.  Parts of the ranch have not had any forage growth for more than a year.  Some cows that were not producing calves were sold.  The president of the Hawaii Cattlemen’s Council said that ranchers statewide reduced herd sizes by roughly one-third in an effort to eke through the drought.  New York Times (N.Y.), Aug. 15, 2012
Places: Hawaii, Hawaii County, HI, Kauai County, HI, Maui County, HI

Title: North Dakota in agricultural drought emergency
Description: The governor of North Dakota announced an agricultural drought emergency because 50 counties, including five Indian reservations, in the state were in drought.  The declaration directs state agencies to prepare for drought response activities.  Jamestown Sun (N.D.), Aug. 15, 2012

Title: Colorado governor seeking decision on water diversion
Description: Gov. Hickenlooper of Colorado has asked President Obama to hasten decisions about proposed water projects intended to support urban growth as drought ups the urgency of the endeavor.  Denver Water seeks to divert 18,000 acre-feet of water from the Colorado River Basin from the west side of the Continental Divide for storage in the Gross Reservoir near Boulder.  Denver Post, Aug. 15, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship requested permission to use corn with higher than allowed levels of aflatoxin
Description: The Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship requested that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration allow corn with aflatoxin levels higher than 20 parts per billion (ppb) to be mixed in with aflatoxin free corn for animal feed.  Drought can encourage the growth of a fungus that produces the harmful aflatoxin.  Nebraska City News-Press (Neb.), Aug. 29, 2012

Title: Brown recluse spiders invading Oklahoma homes
Description: Exterminators were dealing with an unusually large number of brown recluse spiders in homes in the vicinity of Broken Arrow and parts of Oklahoma.  It was thought that the mild winter and lengthy drought were responsible for the swell in the spider population.  Brown recluse bites can result in a minor skin irritation or more serious issues, such as disfigurement or death.  Those bitten by a brown recluse were urged to see their doctor for assessment. KSDK-TV NBC 5 St. Louis (Mo.), Aug. 15, 2012
Places: Oklahoma, Tulsa County, OK, Broken Arrow, OK

Title: Governor of Arkansas announced $2 million in assistance for ranchers
Description: The governor of Arkansas announced that $2 million from the Governor’s Disaster Fund was available for ranchers in need of forage or hay for their cattle, sheep and goats.  The money will bolster the Livestock Assistance Grant Program and will be administered by the Arkansas Agriculture Department.  Producers must apply within 14 days.  ArkansasBusiness.com (Ark.), Aug. 16, 2012

Title: Low average corn yield expected in Missouri
Description: Hot, dry weather in Missouri during the summer of 2012 damaged crops and led to an estimated average corn yield statewide of 75 bushels per acre.  KOMU (Columbia, Mo.), Aug. 14, 2012

Title: Business people in Harper County, Kansas striving to create more water sources for oil companies
Description: The economic development director in Harper County and other business people were striving to create water sources for oil drillers who need water to continue drilling for oil.  They have dug ponds next to streams, while another man dug a 300-feet wide and 15-feet deep lake on swampy land to supply Select Energy with water, which the business sells to oil companies.  Select Energy has brought in water trucks from Pennsylvania to transport water from outside the state to facilitate oil production.  A partner for one of the oil companies in Kansas revealed that he intended to frack and drill for oil, but did not have enough water to get it done as drought and concerns about having enough water kept farmers from selling their water.  He finally located water that was transported to the site, but the search for the water delayed the project by six weeks and drove up the cost of completing the project by nearly three times the budgeted amount.  WIBW Kansas Newsleader (Topeka, Kan.), Aug. 10, 2012

Title: More bear complaints in Vermont
Description: Vermont’s dry summer led to more bear complaints than usual, according to Forrest Hammond, Department of Fish and Wildlife biologist.  Farmers were urged to harvest their corn crops as soon as possible.Journal Gazette.net (Fort Wayne, Ind.), Aug. 9, 2012

Title: Drought tree care tips posted on Indiana Arborist Association's Facebook page
Description: The Indiana Arborist Association posted tree care information on its Facebook page to remind residents how to care for their trees during drought.Muncie Star-Press (Ind.), Aug. 8, 2012

Title: Nevada cattle ranchers struggled to feed their livestock as drought dried up pastures and limited hay supplies
Description: Nevada cattle ranchers struggled to feed their livestock as drought dried up pastures and limited hay supplies, leading many ranchers to sell cattle earlier than they normally would and at a reduced price.  The vice president of the Nevada Cattlemen’s Association said that calves were bringing $70 to $100 per head less in August than they did in May.   The Midwestern drought drove up prices for field crops, such as soybeans and corn, making feeding livestock a more expensive proposition.  Elko County ranchers, in particular, were very low on hay and selling livestock a month early.  Cattle are typically sold between October and December.  Elko Daily Free Press (Nev.), Aug. 8, 2012

Title: Purdue Extension hosts meetings to help producers manage drought challenges in Indiana
Description: Purdue Extension is hosting a series of regional drought meetings across Indiana.  The intent is to help crop and livestock producers manage financial and operational challenges brought on by the drought.  There has been great interest and participation in the meetings so far.  Check Purdue Extension's Drought Event Calendar for upcoming meeting dates and locations (https://ag.purdue.edu/extension/eden/pages/drought.aspx#calendar).From Melissa Widhalm, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, on August 8, 2012

Title: Drought limited occurrence of tornadoes in Illinois
Description: Although the lack of rainy weather this summer mostly generated concerns associated with drought, another interpretation of the persistently sunny skies is that people did not have to worry about severe thunderstorms and tornadoes. With no moisture to draw in from the ground storms don’t have the resources needed to gain intensity, so they dry out before any real damage can be done.  State Journal-Register (Springfield, Ill.), Aug. 8, 2012

Title: Corn chopped for silage in eastern Nebraska
Description: Much of Nebraska’s dryland corn, largely found in the eastern third of the state, was suffering from too little precipitation.  Many producers were opting to chop the corn for silage or hay to compensate for poor pasture conditions.  Dryland corn comprises more than 40 percent of the Nebraska’s 10 million acres of corn.Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Aug. 7, 2012
Places: Nebraska, Antelope County, NE, Boone County, NE, Burt County, NE, Butler County, NE, Cass County, NE, Cedar County, NE, Clay County, NE, Colfax County, NE, Cuming County, NE, Dakota County, NE, Dixon County, NE, Dodge County, NE, Douglas County, NE, Fillmore County, NE, Gage County, NE, Hamilton County, NE, Jefferson County, NE, Johnson County, NE, Knox County, NE, Lancaster County, NE, Merrick County, NE, Nance County, NE, Nemaha County, NE, Nuckolls County, NE, Otoe County, NE, Pawnee County, NE, Polk County, NE, Richardson County, NE, Saline County, NE, Sarpy County, NE, Saunders County, NE, Seward County, NE, Stanton County, NE, Thayer County, NE, Thurston County, NE, Washington County, NE, Wayne County, NE, York County, NE

Title: Low river flow in Colorado limited rafting options
Description: The owner of a rafting tour company said that while he normally takes people on trips down nine different rivers in Colorado, river flow on only four of those rivers supported rafting this year.  He hired fewer guides in anticipation of fewer trips.  Stream flow about one month ago was below average at more than 80 percent of the long-term river gauges monitored by the U.S. Geological Survey.  Flows were at historical lows at 23 gauges.  Bloomberg (N.Y.), Aug. 7, 2012

Title: Most Arkansas counties have burn bans
Description: Most Arkansas counties adopted burn bans and all outdoor burning to minimize the occurrence of wildfires while the state endured drought, high to extreme wildfire danger and tinder-dry vegetation.Baxter Bulletin (Ark.), Aug. 7, 2012

Title: Nebraska ranchers hauling water to livestock
Description: Many Nebraska ranchers were hauling water to their livestock as water sources dried up amid the hot, dry summer.  Scottsbluff Star Herald (Neb.), Aug. 7, 2012
Places: Nebraska, Adams County, NE, Antelope County, NE, Arthur County, NE, Banner County, NE, Blaine County, NE, Boone County, NE, Box Butte County, NE, Boyd County, NE, Brown County, NE, Buffalo County, NE, Burt County, NE, Butler County, NE, Cass County, NE, Cedar County, NE, Chase County, NE, Cherry County, NE, Cheyenne County, NE, Clay County, NE, Colfax County, NE, Cuming County, NE, Custer County, NE, Dakota County, NE, Dawes County, NE, Dawson County, NE, Deuel County, NE, Dixon County, NE, Dodge County, NE, Douglas County, NE, Dundy County, NE, Fillmore County, NE, Franklin County, NE, Frontier County, NE, Furnas County, NE, Gage County, NE, Garden County, NE, Garfield County, NE, Gosper County, NE, Grant County, NE, Greeley County, NE, Hall County, NE, Hamilton County, NE, Harlan County, NE, Hayes County, NE, Hitchcock County, NE, Holt County, NE, Hooker County, NE, Howard County, NE, Jefferson County, NE, Johnson County, NE, Kearney County, NE, Keith County, NE, Keya Paha County, NE, Kimball County, NE, Knox County, NE, Lancaster County, NE, Lincoln County, NE, Logan County, NE, Loup County, NE, Madison County, NE, McPherson County, NE, Merrick County, NE, Morrill County, NE, Nance County, NE, Nemaha County, NE, Nuckolls County, NE, Otoe County, NE, Pawnee County, NE, Perkins County, NE, Phelps County, NE, Pierce County, NE, Platte County, NE, Polk County, NE, Red Willow County, NE, Richardson County, NE, Rock County, NE, Saline County, NE, Sarpy County, NE, Saunders County, NE, Scotts Bluff County, NE, Seward County, NE, Sheridan County, NE, Sherman County, NE, Sioux County, NE, Stanton County, NE, Thayer County, NE, Thomas County, NE, Thurston County, NE, Valley County, NE, Washington County, NE, Wayne County, NE, Webster County, NE, Wheeler County, NE, York County, NE

Title: Emergency haying and grazing permitted in Indiana
Description: The Natural Resource Conservation Service declared that all counties in the state of Indiana were eligible for haying and grazing land in the Floodplain Easement Program to help livestock producers find feed since many pastures were dry and not growing back.  The NRCS also allowed emergency haying and grazing on land in the Conservation Reserve Program and the Wetland Reserve Program to alleviate hay and pastures shortages.  Haying may be done through September 1, while grazing may continue through September 30.  Evansville Courier and Press (Ind.), Aug. 6,2012

Title: Uninsured or under-insured farmers in Wisconsin can get $75 vouchers to visit with a counselor
Description: Uninsured or under-insured farmers in Wisconsin can get $75 vouchers to visit with a counselor and talk about things they’re dealing with as drought takes a toll on their farm.  A University of Wisconsin Extension agent from Adams County said, “Farmers are closely tied to their crops and if they don't have a crop, there's something about that, that really, psychologically and emotionally affects farmers.  Right now, that's probably the hardest thing.”  Oshkosh Northwestern (Wis.), Aug. 5, 2012

Title: Livestock sales were 150 percent of normal in Wisconsin during the past week
Description: Livestock sales were 150 percent of normal in Wisconsin during the past week, stated the spokeswoman for a livestock sales association that has 11 auction markets throughout the state.  Farmers were giving their herds winter hay because the dry conditions prevented grass from growing.  Some livestock producers were opting to sell animals.  One farmer from Lebanon sold 10 animals from his herd of 30 cattle since his feed corn did not grow well.  Oshkosh Northwestern (Wis.), Aug. 5, 2012
Places: Wisconsin, Lebanon, WI, Johnson Creek, WI

Title: Corn, soybean meal prices higher in Maryland
Description: The cost of corn and soybean meal rose with drought conditions and expected short supplies.  Corn prices increased about 40 percent in the past month and were expected to near a record $7.99 per bushel reached in June.  A dairy farmer in Caroline County paid about $350 for a bag of soybean meal during the previous winter, but the same bag was currently selling for $518. The Baltimore Sun (Md.), Aug. 4, 2012

Title: Roughly 40 Kansas cities have adopted water restrictions
Description: Roughly 40 Kansas cities have adopted water restrictions or were on the verge of doing so.  Some of the communities with voluntary water restrictions include Lawrence, Dodge City, Leawood, Emporia, Seneca and Topeka.Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), Aug. 3, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Missouri farmers and ranchers facing crop loss and dry pastures
Description: Missouri farmers and ranchers were facing crop loss and dry pastures.  Corn yields look to be poor.  It remained to be seen whether soybeans would produce pods.  Cattle producers were selling livestock because forage was unavailable and pastures were not growing.  Some cows, stressed by the heat, have gone into labor early, delivering calves that cannot endure the heat.  Many faces reflected desperation as drought continues to parch crops.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture declared all of Missouri a disaster area, and Gov. Jay Nixon declared a state of emergency in late July.St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Mo.), Aug. 3, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Statewide burn ban, state of emergency in Oklahoma
Description: The governor of Oklahoma announced a statewide burn ban on August 3 as drought increased the fire danger to very high levels.  She also declared a state of emergency on August 13 for all of Oklahoma to allow the emergency agency to make preparations for disaster relief and application for federal assistance if it is needed.  Johnson City Press (Tenn.), Aug. 4, 2012.  The governor of Oklahoma lifted the statewide ban on outdoor burning.   Tulsa World (Okla.), Sept. 5, 2012

Title: Governor declares state of emergency for Arkansas
Description: Governor Mike Beebe has declared a state of emergency for all of Arkansas due to ongoing severe drought conditions. The drought has resulted in a hay shortage, and this declaration will allow oversize loads of hay to be moved quickly throughout the state. Submitted by Melissa Widhalm, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, on August 14, 2012

Title: Emergency haying and grazing in Illinois
Description: The Illinois Farm Service Agency announced the release of certain Conservation Reserve Program acreage for haying and grazing beginning on Aug. 2.  At least half of each field or contiguous fields must be left un-hayed for wildlife.  The emergency grazing will be permitted from Aug. 2 through the end of September. Evansville Courier and Press (Ind.), July 31, 2012

Title: Kansas offering a cost-sharing program to help livestock producers improve water supplies for their herds
Description: Kansas is offering a cost-sharing program to help livestock producers improve water supplies for their herds as the state endures persistent drought.  The State Conservation Commission chose to use $500,000 from existing funds to assist livestock producers with water projects in pastures and other areas with marginal or non-existent water supplies.  Producers can get as much as $2,000 for each project or up to $4,000 per landowner.  Program participants should aim to restore existing ponds, develop wells or springs or finish ongoing water storage projects.  Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), Aug. 1, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Fire restrictions implemented for numerous Montana Fish, Wildlife, and Parks lands and fishing access sites
Description: Stage I and II Fire restrictions have been declared for numerous Montana Fish, Wildlife, and Parks-owned lands and fishing access sites. From Jess Aber, Montana DNRC, Helena, Montana, on August 7, 2012
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation

Title: Hot weather, high feed prices drove down milk production in California
Description: Hot weather and high feed prices drove down milk production in August, as dairy men had to ration feed, stated the CEO of Western United Dairymen.  Average production costs were higher than milk prices in the second quarter of 2012.  Western Farm Press, Nov. 28, 2012

Title: Archer Daniels Midland's 4th quarter profit fell
Description: Record high corn prices slashed Archer Daniels Midland’s net income for the fourth quarter by 25 percent.  Corn processing results dropped $48 million, due to negative ethanol margins.  ADM earned $284 million, or 43 cents per share, while revenue slid less than a percent to $22.68 billion, compared to $22.87 billion the previous year.Springfield State Journal-Register (Ill.),  July 31, 2012

Title: Kansas farmers with wells were demanding higher prices from oil producers wanting to purchase water
Description: Kansas farmers with wells were demanding higher prices from oil producers wanting to purchase water.  The going price of water used to be 35 cents per barrel, but were refusing offers of 75 cents a barrel as drought increases the value of water to the farmers.  The CEO of a gas and oil company stated that 10 to 12 percent of the wells intended for fracking were on hold.  CNN, July 31, 2012

Title: More than $3.2 million in state aid approved for Missouri farmers and livestock producers
Description: More than $3.2 million in state aid has been approved for Missouri farmers and livestock producers in need of fresh water.  Ninety percent of the cost of digging deeper wells or extending pipes and pumping systems will be paid by the state in response to the blistering drought conditions.State officials approved 674 applications for the program.  Springfield News-Leader (Mo.), July 31, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Two Pennsylvania counties not issuing permits allowing oil producer to pump water from river
Description: The CEO of an oil and gas company stated that his firm was having difficulty finding water to use in its oil production in the Marcellus region in Pennsylvania.  Two counties stopped issuing permits for the company to pump water from rivers as dry conditions reduce water supplies.   CNN (Ga.), July 31, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The governor of Kansas updated an executive order originally put out in late July to ease the requirements hay transportation
Description: The governor of Kansas updated an executive order originally put out in late July to ease the requirements on trucking so farmers can get hay to hungry livestock.  The more recent order suspended requirements for registration and fuel tax permits from the Kansas Revenue Department and some regulations from the Kansas Corporation Commission.   Topeka Capital Journal (Kan.), Aug. 24, 2012

Title: High incidence of mosquitoes with West Nile virus in Oswego County, New York
Description: Health workers in Oswego County found few mosquitoes, less than 100 per day, as they sought to collect them to test for diseases, such as West Nile and Eastern equine encephalitis.  In wetter years, they easily find 2,000 to 3,000 mosquitoes daily.   By the end of July 2012, despite the low numbers of mosquitoes, 216 mosquito pools had tested positive for West Nile virus.  By the end of the year, there were 107 reported cases of West Nile and nine deaths across the state of New York.  Albany Times-Union (N.Y.), July 31, 2013

Title: The dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico shrank to 2,889 square miles in response to fewer nutrients flowing down the Mississippi River during drought
Description: The dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico shrank to 2,889 square miles in response to fewer nutrients flowing down the Mississippi River since areas upstream were suffering from drought.  The dead zone this year was the fourth smallest in recorded history.  The largest dead zone occurred in 2002 when it grew to 8,400 miles.  The average during the past five years was 5,684 square miles.  Louisville Courier-Journal (Ky.), July 30, 2012

Title: Missouri program to improve water access on farms
Description: Gov. Jay Nixon announced a $2 million program to assist Missouri farmers with improving water supplies by drilling or deepening existing wells or expanding their irrigation systems.  Interest in the program was far beyond expectation and has driven up the cost of the program nearly 15 times the original amount to roughly $29 million, covering 5,885 approved applications. KOMU (Columbia, Mo.), Aug. 28, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Many Kansas communities striving to conserve water
Description: Nearly 40 communities in Kansas had voluntary or mandatory restrictions on water use as drought and high demand depleted public water supplies.  Atchison was rationing water.  Cities and towns with mandatory water restrictions included Mulvane, Abilene, Ellsworth, Jefferson, Russell, Oberlin, Dickinson, Augusta, Logan, Phillipsburg, Caldwell and Goessel.  Dodge City in Ford County, Florence in Marion County and Lyons in Rice County had voluntary water restrictions in effect, according to the Kansas Drought Update issued July 27.  Other communities with voluntary water restrictions included Lawrence, Dodge City, Quinter, Desoto, Olathe, Leawood, Overland Park, Prairie Village, Stilwell, Oakley, Emporia, Florence, portions of northern Miami County, Seneca, Nemaha County, Bern, Osage, Bennington, Lyons, Salina, Topeka, Goodland and Colby.  Ellsworth was in a stage-three water emergency, prohibiting all outdoor watering as demand rose to 600,000 gallons daily for a community of 3,000 people, putting water use for the year 15 million gallons beyond last year’s water use.  The town’s seven wells were about 10 feet lower than usual.  The water superintendent in Ellsworth said that they hoped to purchase water from Post Rock to supplement the city’s wells.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Aug. 1, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
