Places: Kansas, Atchison, KS, Augusta, KS, Oberlin, KS, Abilene, KS, Lawrence, KS, Ellsworth, KS, Dodge City, KS, Quinter, KS, Leawood, KS, Olathe, KS, Overland Park, KS, Prairie Village, KS, Stilwell, KS, Oakley, KS, Emporia, KS, Florence, KS, Goessel, KS, Miami County, KS, Jefferson, KS, Nemaha County, KS, Bern, KS, Seneca, KS, Osage City, KS, Bennington, KS, Logan, KS, Phillipsburg, KS, Lyons, KS, Russell, KS, Salina, KS, Topeka, KS, Goodland, KS, Caldwell, KS, Mulvane, KS, Colby, KS

Title: The Kentucky agriculture commissioner working to create a hay hotline
Description: The Kentucky agriculture commissioner was working to create a hay hotline to help connect livestock producers with hay for sale.  Hay supplies were expected to be short this winter because drought prevented hay from growing, forcing cattlemen to give their animals hay during the summer.  The state ag commissioner stated, “Every beef cattle farmer I've talked to is short on hay."  Evansville Courier and Press (Ind.), July 30, 2012

Title: Fewer exhibitors were competing at county fairs around Wisconsin, due to drought, heat
Description: Fewer exhibitors were competing at county fairs around Wisconsin, stated an agriculture agent with the University of Wisconsin who judged several poultry contests.  The animals were slightly smaller too.  Heat stress might have led some exhibitors to spare the animals the discomfort.  Lacrosse Tribune (Wis.), July 29, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation

Title: Missouri wildlife suffering amid drought, heat
Description: Heat and drought has affected wildlife in Missouri by severely curbing the number of insects.  Many insect species require shallow, temporary pools of water as they advance through various life stages, but there were fewer such pools.Birds that eat insects were suffering from the lack of food, too, and were swarming bird feeders in compensation for the dearth of insects.  Fewer hummingbirds were seen in the Columbia area.  Columbia Missourian (Mo.), July 28, 2012

Title: Nearly half of Oklahoma counties have burn bans
Description: Nearly half of Oklahoma’s 77 counties had burn bans in effect amid the drought and extreme heat.  Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), July 26, 2018
Places: Oklahoma, Adair County, OK, Alfalfa County, OK, Atoka County, OK, Beaver County, OK, Beckham County, OK, Blaine County, OK, Bryan County, OK, Caddo County, OK, Canadian County, OK, Carter County, OK, Cherokee County, OK, Choctaw County, OK, Cimarron County, OK, Cleveland County, OK, Coal County, OK, Comanche County, OK, Cotton County, OK, Craig County, OK, Creek County, OK, Custer County, OK, Delaware County, OK, Dewey County, OK, Ellis County, OK, Garfield County, OK, Garvin County, OK, Grady County, OK, Grant County, OK, Greer County, OK, Harmon County, OK, Harper County, OK, Haskell County, OK, Hughes County, OK, Jackson County, OK, Jefferson County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Kay County, OK, Kingfisher County, OK, Kiowa County, OK, Latimer County, OK, Le Flore County, OK, Lincoln County, OK, Logan County, OK, Love County, OK, Major County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Mayes County, OK, McClain County, OK, McCurtain County, OK, McIntosh County, OK, Murray County, OK, Muskogee County, OK, Noble County, OK, Nowata County, OK, Okfuskee County, OK, Oklahoma County, OK, Okmulgee County, OK, Osage County, OK, Ottawa County, OK, Pawnee County, OK, Payne County, OK, Pittsburg County, OK, Pontotoc County, OK, Pottawatomie County, OK, Pushmataha County, OK, Roger Mills County, OK, Rogers County, OK, Seminole County, OK, Sequoyah County, OK, Stephens County, OK, Texas County, OK, Tillman County, OK, Tulsa County, OK, Wagoner County, OK, Washington County, OK, Washita County, OK, Woods County, OK, Woodward County, OK

Title: The governor of Ohio signed an order directing state agencies to assist farmers who lost crops to drought
Description: The governor of Ohio signed an order directing state agencies to assist farmers who lost crops to drought and help them seek aid.  The governor also wanted emergency low-interest loans, relief payments for non-insurable crops and temporary deferral of payments on prior federal loans for farmers.  The order also pushes for opening Conservation Reserve Program land for haying and grazing and for the Ohio Department of Transportation to allow farmers to cut hay on highways bordering producers’ land.  The Ohio Department of Agriculture was directed to hold meetings to share information on mitigating drought damage concerning forage management, water availability and heat stress.  Toledo Blade (Ohio), July 25, 2012

Title: Governor's declaration of drought emergency in Kansas opened lakes for emergency use
Description: A declaration of drought emergency for all 105 Kansas counties went into effect on July 25, 2012. As a result of this action, some state fishing lakes and Corps of Engineers reservoirs were available as an emergency water source for domestic, municipal and livestock uses. The Kansas Water Office is the first point of contact to obtain access. The governor's executive order was still in effect as of Oct. 25, 2012. Update from Kansas Water Office, Oct. 25, 2012.The governor of Kansas gave permission for livestock producers to draw water from Kansas’ fishing lakes for livestock consumption.  KSCB / KLDG (Liberal, Kan.), July 26, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Stock ponds low, deer abundant in eastern Kansas
Description: Driving the turnpike from Wichita to Topeka most of the stock ponds in the Flint Hills had minimal water remaining. Deer were abundant along the creeks and streams. Dryland corn had been chopped. Along U.S. 77 a number of producers were begining to harvest corn. Trucks were hauling hay in every direction. Soybean leaves were curling and turning yellow.From a federal employee in Wichita, Kansas, on July 27, 2012

Title: All Kansas counties were in a drought emergency, crop losses estimated at $1.5 billion
Description: All Kansas counties were in a drought emergency with crop losses estimated at $1.5 billion.  KSCB / KLDG (Liberal, Kan.), July 26, 2012.  The drought emergency remained in effect.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Dec. 18, 2012

Title: Specialty crops, produce affected by prolonged drought in Indiana
Description: Prolonged, severe drought conditions are beginning to impact specialty crops and produce production across Indiana. Most specialty growers have irrigation systems, but they are not designed for such extreme conditions so they are having difficulty keeping up with demands.  The abnormally hot weather is only compounding the problem.  According to a report issued by Purdue University on July 24, here are some additional details:Tree fruits such as apples and peaches have been least affected, and may actually be seeing a positive impact. The drought is affecting shoot growth more than fruit growth, meaning trees require less pruning and they are receiving more sunlight. Established vineyards with extensive root systems, which typically benefit from dry weather, are showing signs of stress. Young vines are dropping leaves.Watermelon crops have experienced reduced fruit set and yield, and recent rainfall has reportedly come too late for many fields.From Melissa Widlhalm, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, on July 26, 2012; additional information at http://www.purdue.edu/newsroom/outreach/2012/120724MaynardHorticulture

Title: Pastures nearly gone, producers feeding hay in Gentry County, Missouri
Description: Pasture is pretty well gone.  Producers have started full feeding hay.  Hay supplies are between a third and half of normal.  I look for water to become the limiting factor in the next 3 weeks.  Have had lots and lots of calls about nitrate accumulation in corn.  I look for more corn to be harvested as silage in my area than for grain.  The situation is very serious.From Pat Guinan, Missouri State Climatologist, on behalf of an extension livestock specialist in Gentry County, Missouri, on July 24, 2012

Title: Hectic cattle sales in Texas
Description: About 36,000 cattle were sold at auction in Texas, nearly three times the 13,400 head sold just a couple of weeks ago and nearing the 43,600 head sold this time during the unforgiving 2011 drought, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), July 24, 2012

Title: Missouri officials offered to assist farmers with the cost of restoring wells
Description: Missouri officials offered to assist farmers with the cost of restoring wells through drilling deeper or other methods.  So far, more than $18 million has been committed to improving 3,700 wells.  Northwest Herald (Ill.), Aug. 14, 2012.  The number of farmers participating in the program rose to nearly 6,000, putting the amount of assistance offered at $29 million.  Raleigh News & Observer (N.C.), Aug. 30, 2012

Title: At least 37 fish kills were investigated by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources since June
Description: At least 37 fish kills were investigated by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources since June.  Heat and drought reduced flow in rivers and warmed the water, lowering the dissolved oxygen content of the water.  Many cold water fish species like northern pike died.   Fox Sports Radio 1390 (Wausau, Wisconsin), July 23, 2012

Title: Governor of Illinois sought a federal disaster declaration due to heat and drought for nearly all of Illinois’ 102 counties
Description: The governor of Illinois sought a federal disaster declaration due to heat and drought for nearly all of Illinois’ 102 counties when he sent a letter to the secretary of agriculture on July 22.  Thirty counties in the state already received disaster declarations.  Dubuque Telegraph Herald (Iowa), July 23, 2012

Title: High grain cost eliminating profits for Iowa livestock producers
Description: Iowa hog producers were losing about $12.80 per animal, due to high feed costs.  Iowa Environmental Focus (Iowa City, Iowa), Sept. 17, 2012The high cost of grain meant that Iowa hog producers were operating at a loss, due to the 2012 drought, as operating costs exceeded the sales price for hogs.  Cattle producers were feeding hay and hauling water, as pastures and water supplies were dry.  Corn kernels were extremely small.Cedar Rapids Gazette (Iowa), July 20, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Iowa, Buchanan County, IA, Keokuk County, IA

Title: Wisconsin governor visited drought-stricken parts of state
Description: The governor of Wisconsin visited the southern part of the state and told Wisconsin Emergency Management to handle the state’s drought response and recovery efforts.  He expressed concern that wildfires increased the risk of even greater economic losses, notably in agriculture.  Oshkosh Northwestern (Wis.), July 19, 2012

Title: Wisconsin farmers planting second crops to provide feed for cattle
Description: Some Wisconsin dairy farmers, recognizing that they may not have sufficient feed for their cattle during the winter, have taken advantage of the winter wheat maturing weeks early and have planted other crops for feed for their livestock.  One Ozaukee farmer planted soybeans, but others opted to try fall oats and peas for feed.  Some opted to plant short-season corn to use as silage. Bend Bulletin (Ore.), July 19, 2012

Title: Iowa's livestock and ethanol industry quarrel over Renewable Fuel Standard
Description: Heat, drought and historically high corn prices led livestock producers and the ethanol industry to quarrel over the federal mandate requiring the use of ethanol in at least 10 percent of the country’s gas supply.  Livestock producers want the mandate suspended or eased because they feel that ethanol producers do not bear “the full burden of a corn harvest shortfall,” but ethanol producers accused the cattlemen of “shamelessly exploiting the drought” for their own profit.  An alliance from the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association, the National Chicken Council, the National Pork Producers Council and the National Turkey Federation pushed for an easing of the Renewable Fuel Standard enacted seven years ago and stated, “Such relief is extremely urgent because the recent spike in corn prices prompted by drought conditions in much of the Corn Belt has analysts predicting the United States will run short of corn this summer.”  Ethanol interests feel that easing of the Renewable Fuel Standard is premature since the corn has not been harvested yet to know for certain how much corn was produced.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), July 19, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: South Dakota Drought Task Force activated
Description: The governor of South Dakota activated the state’s Drought Task Force to facilitate sharing drought information among government agencies.  Aberdeen American News (S.D.), July 18, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: The governor of Wyoming sought disaster declarations for all counties, but one
Description: The governor of Wyoming appealed to the U.S. secretary of agriculture for drought disaster declarations for all counties in the state, except for Teton.  On July 18, 16 counties received disaster declarations and the remaining counties were eligible for assistance because they bordered primary drought disaster counties.  The disaster declaration also opened up access to Conservation Reserve Program land for haying and grazing.   Cheyenne Wyoming Tribune-Eagle, July 27, 2012

Title: Drought reduced hay crop, driving up hay prices in Colorado
Description: Drought reduced the hay crop in Colorado by at least one-third and driving hay prices to triple, according to an article in the Aspen Times. Given last year’s drought, hay supplies were mostly depleted.  Denver Post (Colo.), July 18, 2012

Title: Ohio Farm Bureau collecting drought damage information using new survey
Description: The Ohio Farm Bureau began using a new survey to see how drought was affecting crop and livestock, water resources, interest in government disaster programs and the anticipated economic toll on farms.  They also posted a resources page for farmers on their website.  Bucyrus Telegraph Forum (Ohio), July 18, 2012

Title: Indiana State Police citing people who toss lit cigarettes from car windows
Description: The Indiana State Police began citing anyone throwing lit cigarettes or other burning material out of a car window because the drought increased the fire danger.  The fine for tossing burning materials from a moving vehicle could be as high as $10,000, while the fine for doing the same from a parked car was as much as $1,000.  WISH-TV CBS 8 Indianapolis (Ind.), July 17, 2012

Title: Many burn bans in Iowa, surface water supplies for firefighting low in some locations
Description: There were 32 burn bans across the state of Iowa as of July 17, due to drought and the elevated fire danger.  During fall when things are usually driest, there are often 15 to 20 burn bans in effect.  A current list of burn bans can be found at the Iowa Department of Public Safety at http://www.dps.state.ia.us/fm/main/burnbans/index.shtml.  Low surface water supplies added to the danger since some rural areas may only have pumper trucks to extinguish fires because hydrants fed by ponds may not meet demand.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), July 17, 2012

Title: Governor of Kansas visited drought-stricken central, southeastern and northwestern parts of state
Description: The governor of Kansas visited central Kansas on July 17 to check on water supplies and southeastern Kansas on July 18 to see drought damaged crops in Allen and Neosho counties.  The director of the Kansas Water Office and the state agriculture director were also touring the area.  The governor continued his tour of the state on July 25 and visited northwestern Kansas to observe drought damage and proclaimed that he was signing a disaster declaration for the whole state.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), July 18, 2012 and Hays Daily News (Kan.), July 25, 2012

Title: Indiana under water shortage warning
Description: The state of Indiana is under a water shortage warning. All residents are being asked to conserve water.  WRTV-TV ABC 6 Indianapolis (The Indy Channel) (IN), July 17, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Trees in jeopardy, fish kills occurring in Iowa
Description: Iowa foresters said that trees across the state were dropping their leaves early, due to the drought, while smaller trees may not be able to survive.  Some cottonwood and ash trees were turning color early from the drought.  The Iowa Department of Natural Resources documented massive fish kills in the last week as streams dwindle and heat decreases the water’s oxygen content.  The western prairie fringed orchid, a threatened perennial wildflower in Iowa, died early this year from the heat, according to a botanist with the Iowa Department of Natural Resources.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), July 17, 2012

Title: Illinois governor visited southern part of state to talk about state drought response
Description: The governor of Illinois traveled to the southern part of the state on July 16 to talk about the state’s response to the drought.  He also encouraged people of the state to pray for rain to bring relief.  Plans for drought assistance at the state level were also in the works.  Springfield State Journal-Register (Ill.), July 13, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Corn produced no kernels in Jefferson County, Illinois
Description: The corn crop was so badly damaged by drought that a farmer near Waltonville was prepared to cut it and feed it to his cattle.  The ears did not produce any kernels.  Illinois Gov. Pat Quinn intended to visit the farm to see drought damage first hand.Cape Girardeau Southeast Missourian (Mo.), July 16, 2012
Places: Illinois, Jefferson County, IL, Waltonville, IL

Title: Debt restructuring available for Illinois farmers
Description: Illinois Gov. Pat Quinn announced that farmers suffering from drought would be eligible for state debt restructuring and loan programs, as well as the aid announced by the U.S. Department of Agriculture in recent days. The Denver Post (Colo.), July 16, 2018

Title: Epizootic hemorrhagic disease killing deer in Indiana
Description: Epizootic hemorrhagic disease (EHD) was killing deer in Indiana, with groups of the dead animals being discovered near water sources.  A small fly called a biting midge passes the virus to deer.  EHD often occurs during drought and usually begins mid-August, although reports of dead deer surfaced in mid-July.  Officials feared that this might become an unusually severe episode of EHD since it began earlier than it normally does.  More than 50 dead deer were discovered in Putnam County, while another 15 dead deer were found in Morgan County.  Samples were taken from the deer to verify that this is indeed an EHD outbreak, but it appears to be the case, especially since EHD has been discovered in Michigan.  Anyone coming across a lethargic or unresponsive deer was urged to contact a local Department of Natural Resources office to have the deer tested.  WRTV-TV ABC 6 Indianapolis (The Indy Channel) (Ind.), Aug. 9, 2012
Places: Indiana, Morgan County, IN, Putnam County, IN

Title: Nearly 6,000 deer succumbed to epizootic hemorrhagic disease in Nebraska
Description: Nearly 6,000 deer succumbed to epizootic hemorrhagic disease in Nebraska since July, according to the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission.  During a two-week period in September, 1,841 deer were reported to have died from the disease, which is spread by biting midges.  When deer congregate around fewer water sources in drought years, there is greater potential for the disease to spread easily.  This has been the worst outbreak of EHD since the 1970s.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Dec. 10, 2012

Title: The dry summer of 2012 suppressed the mosquito population in Iowa
Description: The dry summer of 2012 suppressed the mosquito population by midsummer.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), June 21, 2013

Title: Illinois hog farmers facing considerable financial losses
Description: Hog farmers are facing considerable financial losses as a side effect of decreased crop yields brought on by the drought.  The high increase in feed prices will make the cost of keeping livestock much higher, prompting hog farmers to send breeding animals to slaughter, and leading to a subsequent increase in meat supply and a drop in livestock prices.  Additionally, hog farmers typically do not have any sort of insurance to protect themselves against financial losses, so they will have to cope with the financial pressures until feed prices decrease, which may not happen until fall of 2013.  At this point in time, financial losses in the animal industry are predicted to become much larger than losses in the crop industry.  Champaign News-Gazette (Ill.), July 14, 2012

Title: Ag officials in Missouri were cautioning cattle producers that drought-stressed forages can contain lethal levels of nitrates
Description: Ag officials in Missouri were cautioning cattle producers that drought-stressed forages, such as sorghum, sudan, millet and Johnson grass, can contain lethal levels of nitrates.  Drought-stressed sorghum can also make toxic amounts of prussic acid.  Springfield News-Leader (Mo.), July 13, 2012

Title: Senator from South Dakota contacted secretary of the U.S. Dept. of Agriculture about assistance for producers
Description: A senator from South Dakota contacted the secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture to push for increased flexibility with assistance for drought-affected producers and recommended the approval of emergency haying and grazing on Conservation Reserve Program land.  Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), July 13, 2012

Title: The Indiana Department of Natural Resources noted a number of benefits to the drought
Description: The Indiana Department of Natural Resources noted a number of benefits to the drought that was searing the state.  Some of them were that waterfront homeowners could access manmade features that were normally submerged, cicadas singing earlier in the year, better fishing in Lake Michigan and Asian carp dying, due to low water levels in oxbows and cut off sections of river in southwestern Indiana and in particular, the Wabash River.  Evansville Courier and Press (Ind.), July 13, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Fish kills occurring in Indiana
Description: Fish kills were reported in various locations in Indiana as drought and heat dry up surface water supplies and warm water temperatures.  Five fish died at in the Tippecanoe River near Winamac in Pulaski County, and hundreds of fish at Atterbury Fish and Wildlife Area in Johnson County.  One positive outcome from the fish kills was that Asian carp were among the dead fish in backwaters of the Wabash River in southern Indiana.  Louisville Courier-Journal (Ky.), July 13, 2012

Title: Statewide ban on outdoor residential brush burning in New York
Description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced a statewide ban on outdoor residential brush burning in effect through October 10, due to dry weather and elevated fire danger.  Emergency personnel were also at a higher state of readiness for wildfire outbreaks.  Previously issued burning permits were suspended until conditions ease.There was relatively little snowfall during the winter, increasing the dryness.  Some parts of New York have received just 25 percent of average rainfall during the spring and early summer.  Albany Times-Union (N.Y.), July 14, 2012

Title: South Dakota livestock producers were urged to have their drought-affected forage tested for high nitrate levels
Description: Livestock producers were urged to have their drought-affected forage tested for high nitrate levels that could sicken or kill cattle, said a SDSU Extension Cow/Calf Field Specialist.  Plants high in nitrates lead to the formation of nitrites in the blood stream, which can combine with hemoglobin to create methhemoglobin, which does not transport oxygen so cattle can asphyxiate.  Yankton Press & Dakotan (S.D.), July 13, 2012

Title: Heat and drought were jeopardizing second and third cuttings of hay in New York
Description: Heat and drought were jeopardizing second and third cuttings of hay in New York, stated a spokesman for the New York Farm Bureau.  Corn, too, needed moisture to mature fully.  Albany Times-Union (N.Y.), July 14, 2012

Title: The state agencies involved with the Illinois Drought Response Task Force met
Description: The state agencies involved with the Drought Response Task Force met on July 12 to discuss the ways drought was affecting agriculture, wildlife, water supplies and the landscape.  Columbus Ledger-Enquirer (Ga.), July 18, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: The governor of Missouri requested a primary disaster declaration due to drought damage in all 114 counties
Description: The governor of Missouri requested a primary disaster declaration due to drought damage in all 114 counties in the state.  U.S. Sens. Roy Blunt and Claire McCaskill wrote to the U.S. Department of Agriculture urging quick approval of Governor Nixon’s request.  Springfield News-Leader (Mo.), July 12, 2012

Title: Open fires prohibited on Wyoming Game and Fish Dept. land
Description: The Wyoming Game and Fish Department expanded its ban on open fires to encompass all land owned and administered by the state Game and Fish Commission.  It was prohibited to use a fire, campfire, charcoal grill, coal or wood burning stove on the lands. Billings Gazette (Mont.), July 10, 2012
Places: Wyoming, Albany County, WY, Big Horn County, WY, Campbell County, WY, Carbon County, WY, Converse County, WY, Crook County, WY, Fremont County, WY, Goshen County, WY, Hot Springs County, WY, Johnson County, WY, Laramie County, WY, Lincoln County, WY, Natrona County, WY, Niobrara County, WY, Park County, WY, Platte County, WY, Sheridan County, WY, Sublette County, WY, Sweetwater County, WY, Teton County, WY, Uinta County, WY, Washakie County, WY, Weston County, WY

Title: Fish kills reported in Illinois
Description: Many fish kills have been reported statewide. Relatively large kills occurred on Lakes Clinton and Sangchris, with minor kills on the Rock, Mississippi, and Little Wabash rivers. Powerton has a major fish kill underway.Most state parks in Illinois have implemented an open fire ban until further notice. High fire danger exists in southern Illinois.
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The governor of Arkansas sought a statewide disaster designation
Description: The governor of Arkansas sought a statewide disaster designation from the U.S. secretary of agriculture due to the continuing drought.  Such a declaration would make farmers and ranchers eligible for emergency loans.  Arkansas Democrat Gazette (Ark.), July 11, 2012

Title: Dry conditions slowing, halting crop growth in Pennsylvania
Description: Dry conditions stopped the growth of soybeans in Pennsylvania, stated a meteorologist and hydrologist with the National Weather Service in State College, Pa.  Alfalfa growth was stunted and hay was not growing, reported a Penn State Extension horticulture educator.Bluefield Daily Telegraph (W.V.), July 9, 2012

Title: Wisconsin governor declared a state of emergency for all counties
Description: Gov. Scott Walker expanded the drought emergency to include all 72 counties in the state on July 18.  The statewide executive order allowed the waiver of fees and hastened permitting to let farmers divert water from particular streams and lakes.  Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), July 19, 2012The governor of Wisconsin declared a state of emergency for 42 counties in the southern part of the state as they endured drought or abnormal dryness.  Some of the counties included in the declaration were Fond du Lac, Dodge Calumet, Green Lake and Winnebago.  The declaration will make it easier for farmers to get permits for temporary use of streams and lakes for irrigation.  Green Bay Press-Gazette (Wis.), July 9, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wisconsin, Adams County, WI, Ashland County, WI, Barron County, WI, Bayfield County, WI, Brown County, WI, Buffalo County, WI, Burnett County, WI, Calumet County, WI, Chippewa County, WI, Clark County, WI, Columbia County, WI, Crawford County, WI, Dane County, WI, Dodge County, WI, Door County, WI, Douglas County, WI, Dunn County, WI, Eau Claire County, WI, Florence County, WI, Fond du Lac County, WI, Forest County, WI, Grant County, WI, Green County, WI, Green Lake County, WI, Iowa County, WI, Iron County, WI, Jackson County, WI, Jefferson County, WI, Juneau County, WI, Kenosha County, WI, Kewaunee County, WI, La Crosse County, WI, Lafayette County, WI, Langlade County, WI, Lincoln County, WI, Manitowoc County, WI, Marathon County, WI, Marinette County, WI, Marquette County, WI, Menominee County, WI, Milwaukee County, WI, Monroe County, WI, Oconto County, WI, Oneida County, WI, Outagamie County, WI, Ozaukee County, WI, Pepin County, WI, Pierce County, WI, Polk County, WI, Portage County, WI, Price County, WI, Racine County, WI, Richland County, WI, Rock County, WI, Rusk County, WI, Saint Croix County, WI, Sauk County, WI, Sawyer County, WI, Shawano County, WI, Sheboygan County, WI, Taylor County, WI, Trempealeau County, WI, Vernon County, WI, Vilas County, WI, Walworth County, WI, Washburn County, WI, Washington County, WI, Waukesha County, WI, Waupaca County, WI, Waushara County, WI, Winnebago County, WI, Wood County, WI

Title: Low water levels in many Colorado rivers led to restrictions on fishing
Description: Low water levels in many Colorado rivers led to restrictions on fishing to protect the fish from additional stress from warm water temperatures.  Trout fishermen have been asked to monitor stream temperature on the Yampa, White and Colorado rivers on the Western Slope, on the Arkansas River and on Bear Creek on the Front Range.  Conscientious anglers were not fishing on the Yampa River through Steamboat Springs, due to critically low flows, which could soon lead to a strict emergency closure.Colorado Parks and Wildlife has also instituted a voluntary fishing closure on Bear Creek upstream of Bear Creek Reservoir and requested that anglers only fish the White River near Meeker during morning hours.  Trout Unlimited asked fishermen to avoid fishing the Fraser River and stretches of the upper Colorado River during the hottest part of the day, particularly between Windy Gap and the Williams Fork confluence.  Water temperatures above 70 degrees can kill trout.  Denver Post (Colo.), July 7, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Tennessee has a new website containing a collection of resources to help the state’s farmers and ranchers withstand drought and heat
Description: Tennessee has a new website containing a collection of resources to help the state’s farmers and ranchers withstand drought and heat.  The website can be found at https://utextension.tennessee.edu/drought/ and has information from livestock specialists, plant and pest specialists, veterinarians, family science experts, environmental engineers, horticulturists, and forestry and wildlife experts.  Dr. Justin Rhinehart, UT Extension beef cattle specialist, who coordinated the endeavor, said, “The majority of the listed publications have been developed by UT Institute of Agriculture faculty and staff specifically to help Tennessee farmers and families cope with the immediate negative consequences of drought and high temperature.”Information from the Tennessee Department of Agriculture can also assist producers trying to find hay.  TN.gov, July 6, 2012

Title: Indiana residents warned about fire danger
Description: The Indiana Department of Homeland Security and the Terre Haute Fire Department reminded state residents that the fire danger was high.  “While some areas of the state have seen a little rain in recent days, extremely dry conditions persist,” said Indiana State Fire Marshal Jim Greeson. “Much of the grass and vegetation throughout the state is primed to quickly grow a small spark into a large fire. Hoosiers must continue to exercise great care to prevent devastating fires.”Higher than normal fire activity was ongoing near Terre Haute, due to the hot, dry weather.  Terre Haute Tribune-Star (Ind.), July 6, 2018

Title: Campers, hunters asked to avoid blocking access for wildlife to waterholes in Wyoming
Description: The Wyoming Game and Fish Department have requested that people not camp directly at water holes, preventing wildlife from getting desperately needed water.  With the severe drought conditions, wildlife were having trouble accessing water.  Hunters and campers were also asked to camp away from well-established game trails leading to waterholes.Casper Star-Tribune (Wyo.), July 5, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Anticipated Indiana crop yields declining
Description: Indiana crops are deteriorating as the state faces its worst drought since 1988, said Bob Nielsen, Purdue Extension corn specialist, at a July 5 media briefing. As a majority of the corn crop enters the crucial and sensitive pollination period, there is little chance for recovery, Nielsen said. Without rain and cooler temperatures, he said, corn could lose up to 10 percent yield potential daily. Purdue Extension agricultural economist Chris Hurt estimated that as of July 1, Indiana had already lost 20 percent of the expected corn yields - down to 133 bushels per acre, compared with 166 expected at spring planting. Soybeans fared slightly better in the yield projections, down 15 percent at 41.3 bushels per acre instead of 48.6 bushels expected early in the season. Commodity markets already have taken notice of the projected yield losses. At the end of trading on Tuesday (July 3), corn cash prices were up about 27 percent, and soybean prices were up about 5 percent. (Purdue press release, July 5, 2012)

Title: Missouri cattle producers feeding hay
Description: Many Missouri farmers supplemented their cattle’s diets with hay because the pasture grass has little moisture and lower nutritional value, according to Lonny Duckworth, president of the Missouri Cattlemen's Association.  In addition, there was a hay shortage which may leave farmers short of hay for the coming winter.  Columbia Missourian (Mo.), July 3, 2012

Title: Cattle sales in Arkansas, hay scarce
Description: Many cattle producers in Arkansas were selling livestock and trying to buy hay, but there was little available, according to Tom Troxel, a cattle expert with the University of Arkansas Division of Agriculture Cooperative Extension Service.  Hay was selling for $50 per 750-pound bale.Washington Examiner (D.C.), July 3, 2012

Title: Heat and drought increase demand on utilities in Nebraska
Description: The Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) had to turn to temporary electrical outages in north central Nebraska to deal with the extraordinary demand for electricity on the night of July 18-19.  A spokesman for the NPPD stated that demand has exceeded previous daily records for peak utility use on 19 of the past 22 days, due to heat and drought.  The previous record for electrical use was 2,670 megawatts set back in 2006.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), July 25, 2012

Title: Twenty-three Mississippi counties with burn bans
Description: Twenty-three Mississippi counties had some type of burn ban in place, according to the Mississippi Forestry Commission.  “It’s (a burn ban) because of dry conditions, and a drought we are currently experiencing,” said county Emergency Management Director and Fire Coordinator Stan Owens.Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, Miss.), July 3, 2012
Places: Mississippi, Adams County, MS, Lee County, MS

Title: Gov. Heineman Declares Emergency on Statewide Drought Conditions
Description: Nebraska Governor Dave Heineman declared a state of emergency July 2, 2012, due to current drought conditions throughout the state. The emergency declaration for statewide drought allows state personnel and resources to assist with emergency situations and prevention, and allows maximum flexibility to the state to deploy Nebraska National Guard and Nebraska Emergency Management Agency assets and resources as needed. The governor also directed the Nebraska Department of Roads to advance the starting date for roadside haying from July 15 to July 3 in 55 counties. Press release July 2, 2012.

Title: Missouri governor requested grazing on CRP land
Description: Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon requested that the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency allow ranchers to graze their herds on land enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program, reported the Associated Press.  Columbia Missourian (Mo.), July 3, 2012

Title: Dry conditions affect landscapes, crops in Ohio
Description: I cannot imagine a more dramatic week of drought intensification than this past week. The average high over the first 8 days of July has been 98.6F. Rainfall over the first 8 days of July totalled 0.18 with 0.16 of that on the first. Only 0.02 fell today. Lawns are brown, lake and stream levels are down, unwatered landscapes are showing significant distress with some plants actually shriveling. Lawn mowing operations are being suspended in some cases. Corn in Harrison, OH, is 3 feet high, curled, and browning. From Ronald Rothhaas, Arbor Doctor, Cincinnati, Ohio, on July 8, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The cost of hay in Arkansas rose as high as $137 per ton in 2012
Description: The cost of hay in Arkansas rose as high as $137 per ton in 2012, according to the regional director of the Arkansas Agricultural Statistics Service as drought prevented local farmers from growing much hay.  At midsummer 2012, a ton of high quality Bermuda hay with a total digestible nutrition content of 65 percent cost $285 per ton.  Baxter Bulletin (Ark.), Sept. 26, 2013

Title: High nitrate levels reported in new grains in North Dakota; grasshoppers "thick" in some areas
Description: Dry conditions have resulted in high nitrate levels in new grains, which may produce some problems with making it into hay. Grasshoppers also reported to be thick in some areas.From Patrick Ayd, National Weather Service, Bismarck, North Dakota, on July 18, 2012

Title: Wisconsin snowplow manufacturer reported sales drop
Description: Douglas Dynamics Inc., a manufacturer of snowplows for light trucks, reported that its sales had dropped by 29 percent in the third quarter.  Net sales for the first three quarters of 2012 had fallen to $37.8 million, compared to $53.5 million for the same period in 2011.  Quarterly income was $2.3 million, or 10 cents per share, in comparison with $3.9 million, or 18n cents per share at the same time last year.  Last year’s mild, relatively snowless winter, ongoing economic challenges and the historical drought all played a role in the shortfall in sales.   Milwaukee Business Journal (Wis.), Nov. 6, 2012

Title: Number of farm-related fatalities was down in Illinois
Description: The number of farm-related fatalities was down to 12 in Illinois from July 2012 through June 2013, partially due to drought, because there was less farm work to be done.  One dozen fatalities was the lowest number since COUNTRY Financial began keeping records in 1978.  Springfield State Journal-Register (Ill.), Sept. 24, 2013

Title: High corn prices, combined with low prices for pork, leave hog producers losing money
Description: High corn prices, combined with low prices for pork, leave hog producers losing money.  Corn prices climbed 60 percent to $8 per bushel as drought ravaged the crop this summer.  Hog prices fell 20 percent since June, due to ample supplies in the market.  Steve Meyer of Paragon Economics said that hog producers will lose $12.80 per hog in 2012.  High feeding costs pushed hog producers to get livestock to market more quickly than usual to keep down feeding costs.  A commodity trader with Archer Financial Services stated, “We’ve not seen daily hog kills like this since the end of December 2009.  We’re bumping up against industry capacity. The weekly kill could approach 2.4 million hogs. The last time we experienced weekly kills of this size was January of 2008.”  High corn prices also played a sizable role in the bankruptcy of Canada’s second largest hog producer, Big Sky Farms.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Sept. 16, 2012

Title: Drought devastated Oklahoma's canola crop and plan for a canola processing plant
Description: Drought and freezing weather in 2014 wiped out Oklahoma’s nearly 270,000 acres of canola, and with not enough canola to process, also put an end to a proposed canola processing plant in Enid.  Northstar Agri Industries announced in 2012 it planned to build a canola processing plant in the city and purchased 400 acres of land  on the east side of Enid.  Northstar Agri Industries President Neil Juhnke said canola acres were all that was delaying construction of the plant in 2015.  There needed to be 750,000 to one million acres of the crop to process, but the drought devastated half of the region’s canola in 2014.Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), July 24, 2016
Places: Oklahoma, Adair County, OK, Alfalfa County, OK, Atoka County, OK, Beaver County, OK, Beckham County, OK, Blaine County, OK, Bryan County, OK, Caddo County, OK, Canadian County, OK, Carter County, OK, Cherokee County, OK, Choctaw County, OK, Cimarron County, OK, Cleveland County, OK, Coal County, OK, Comanche County, OK, Cotton County, OK, Craig County, OK, Creek County, OK, Custer County, OK, Delaware County, OK, Dewey County, OK, Ellis County, OK, Garfield County, OK, Enid, OK, Garvin County, OK, Grady County, OK, Grant County, OK, Greer County, OK, Harmon County, OK, Harper County, OK, Haskell County, OK, Hughes County, OK, Jackson County, OK, Jefferson County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Kay County, OK, Kingfisher County, OK, Kiowa County, OK, Latimer County, OK, Le Flore County, OK, Lincoln County, OK, Logan County, OK, Love County, OK, Major County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Mayes County, OK, McClain County, OK, McCurtain County, OK, McIntosh County, OK, Murray County, OK, Muskogee County, OK, Noble County, OK, Nowata County, OK, Okfuskee County, OK, Oklahoma County, OK, Okmulgee County, OK, Osage County, OK, Ottawa County, OK, Pawnee County, OK, Payne County, OK, Pittsburg County, OK, Pontotoc County, OK, Pottawatomie County, OK, Pushmataha County, OK, Roger Mills County, OK, Rogers County, OK, Seminole County, OK, Sequoyah County, OK, Stephens County, OK, Texas County, OK, Tillman County, OK, Tulsa County, OK, Wagoner County, OK, Washington County, OK, Washita County, OK, Woods County, OK, Woodward County, OK

Title: Fire, fireworks restrictions in most Indiana counties
Description: With drought and dry vegetation, most Indiana counties—85 of the 92 counties—had fire restrictions.  In addition, 18 counties and the cities of Evansville, Kokomo and Ferdinand had prohibited the use of fireworks.  Evansville Courier and Press (Ind.), June 30, 2012
Places: Indiana, Allen County, IN, Hamilton County, IN, Kokomo, IN, Miami County, IN, Steuben County, IN, Tippecanoe County, IN, Vanderburgh County, IN, Evansville, IN, Vigo County, IN

Title: Vintners in Ohio were happy with the quality of the grapes this year
Description: Vintners in Ohio were happy with the quality of the grapes this year as drought reduced grape size, concentrated flavors and made the grapes sweeter than usual.  One grower in Enon reported that his vines did not grow as much, requiring less work for pruning than usual.  Mold and mildew normally are a problem from June through September, but he had no need to spray for those issues this year.  The hot, dry summer also moved up harvest time, which is beneficial because the grapes will not be threatened by frost this year.  Drought did diminish the overall yield and grape size, which will increase prices.  Dayton Daily News (Ohio), September 14, 2012

Title: Some Indiana fireworks distributors experienced a loss of 90 percent of their income during the 2012 Fourth of July season
Description: Some Indiana fireworks distributors experienced a loss of 90 percent of their income during the 2012 Fourth of July season after local fire officials banned the personal use of fireworks given the drought and increased fire danger. A 2006 law prevents local governments from banning personal use of fireworks from June 29 through July 9, but local officials acted under statutes giving them  emergency powers to ban the fireworks.  Indianapolis Star (Ind.), Feb. 26, 2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation

Title: Wisconsin crops suffering in the dry heat
Description: Wisconsin’s alfalfa fields turned brown from the lack of rain, while soybeans languished in the dry heat.  The damage was irreparable.  "We have had a lot of corn that is simply not going to make it," said Bob Oleson, executive director of the Wisconsin Corn Growers Association.Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), June 29, 2012

Description: The Missouri Department of Conservation issued a statewide fire ban effective immediately in all conservation areas.  Campfires and all sources of open flames, such as charcoal grills and the use of firewood in cooking fires, was prohibited. Columbia Missourian (Mo.), June 29, 2012

Title: Nebraskans urged to leave the fireworks to the professionals
Description: The Nebraska State Fire Marshal’s Office urged Nebraskans to enjoy a professional fireworks show rather than lighting their own fireworks as the dry weather has elevated the fire danger.Scottsbluff Star Herald (Neb.), June 28, 2012

Title: Kentucky governor orders easier movement of supplies for drought-affected livestock
Description: Kentucky Gov. Steve Beshear signed an executive order, directing the state Transportation Cabinet to hasten the transport of emergency supplies for livestock producers.  The order directed the Transportation Cabinet to waive special registration and permit requirements for vehicles moving relief supplies like water, livestock forage and hay to drought-affected areas.  Sixty-six counties were enduring moderate drought, while 24 counties in the west were experiencing severe drought.Lexington Herald-Leader (Ky.), June 27, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kentucky, Adair County, KY, Allen County, KY, Anderson County, KY, Ballard County, KY, Barren County, KY, Bath County, KY, Bell County, KY, Boone County, KY, Bourbon County, KY, Boyd County, Title: Tennessee Valley Authority drawing down reservoirs to maintain Tennessee River
Description: The Tennessee Valley Authority has drawn more water from its storage reservoirs in east Tennessee and western North Carolina, due to heavier demand from water customers as heat and drought gripped the region.  The water level declined in those reservoirs as the TVA tried to keep water levels high in the Tennessee River.   TimesDaily.com (Florence, Ala.), June 27, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alabama, Colbert County, AL, DeKalb County, AL, Franklin County, AL, Jackson County, AL, Lauderdale County, AL, Lawrence County, AL, Limestone County, AL, Madison County, AL, Marshall County, AL, Morgan County, AL, Cherokee County, NC, Clay County, NC, Graham County, NC, Swain County, NC, Anderson County, TN, Bledsoe County, TN, Blount County, TN, Bradley County, TN, Campbell County, TN, Carter County, TN, Claiborne County, TN, Cocke County, TN, Cumberland County, TN, Grainger County, TN, Greene County, TN, Hamblen County, TN, Hamilton County, TN, Hancock County, TN, Hawkins County, TN, Jefferson County, TN, Johnson County, TN, Knox County, TN, Loudon County, TN, Marion County, TN, McMinn County, TN, Meigs County, TN, Monroe County, TN, Polk County, TN, Rhea County, TN, Roane County, TN, Sequatchie County, TN, Sevier County, TN, Sullivan County, TN, Unicoi County, TN, Union County, TN, Washington County, TN

Title: Damage assessment requested for Missouri crops
Description: Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon urged the Farm Service Agency to assess whether heat and drought were harming the state’s crops and livestock.  The determination would be the initial step in seeking a disaster declaration.Yahoo! News (Sunnyvale, Calif.), June 25, 2012

Title: Nebraska senator sought action on relief request
Description: Nebraska Sen. Mike Johanns, R-Neb., urged Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack to act promptly on the Nebraska Farm Service Agency Committee’s request to "authorize emergency haying and grazing of Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) land in all counties that meet the appropriate drought conditions and to give prompt consideration to future requests."In his letter to Vilsack, Johanns noted that producers in Morrill and Sheridan counties requested early release of CRP acres for haying and grazing, due to drought.  Other counties were preparing to make similar requests to FSA offices.Grand Island Independent (Neb.), June 25, 2012
Places: Nebraska, Morrill County, NE, Sheridan County, NE

Title: Public warned about low lake levels in West Virginia
Description: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers warned the public about low lake levels brought on by “well below normal snow cover this past winter and below normal precipitation this past spring.” Tygart Lake east of Clarksburg was as low as it usually is in early August and was dropping two-tenths of a foot per day, reported the chief of water management for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Pittsburgh District.  Lake recreation areas and boat ramps will likely close earlier than usual this summer.Clarksburg Exponent-Telegram (W.Va.), June 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: West Virginia, Barbour County, WV, Doddridge County, WV, Harrison County, WV

Title: Governor of Wyoming sought a federal disaster declaration
Description: The governor of Wyoming sought a federal disaster declaration as meager runoff from a thin snowpack and a dry spring left ranchers with little forage for their livestock.  Across the state, about one-half of pasture grass and hay production on non-irrigated land was lost, according to the deputy director for the Wyoming Department of Agriculture.  Ranchers were having a very hard time providing for their herds.  Many cattle have been sold, depending how far behind on rainfall a particular area was.  Reuters (New York), June 22, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Utah governor urged communities to ban fireworks
Description: The governor of Utah requested that communities consider banning fireworks during the hot, dry summer.Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), June 22, 2012

Title: Burn ban for state of Colorado
Description: A burn ban was in effect for the state of Colorado due to the dry conditions and potential for big wildfires.  Sterling Journal-Advocate (Colo.), June 22, 2012

Title: Ammunition with steel components banned in Utah
Description: Firing ammunition with a steel component was banned on BLM, state and unincorporated private land in Utah because such bullets were known to spark fires.  With the state being a tinderbox with the ongoing drought, every effort was being made to prevent wildfires.Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), June 22, 2012

Title: Limitations on fireworks use recommended in New Mexico
Description: New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez encouraged local governments to place limits on fireworks ahead of the Fourth of July holiday due to drought and the fire danger.  She sent a letter to mayors and county commissioners and requested that they act quickly to meet a state deadline for restricting fireworks.  The governor cited recent fires as a reason for the limitations.  "As state leaders, we must do everything within our power to keep New Mexicans, and their families and homes, safe," Martinez said.The governor will again push for greater powers for state and local governments to restrict fireworks when conditions present an extreme fire risk.Farmington Daily Times (N.M.), June 22, 2012

Title: Restrictions on open fires, fireworks in Utah
Description: Amid a statewide ban on fireworks and open fires on public lands, several communities have issued restrictions on where fireworks may be used.  Parts of Salt Lake City, Provo, foothill areas in Herriman, Draper, West Valley City, Holladay, Cottonwood Heights and Sandy were some of the communities restricting fireworks use.  The Smith’s grocery chain stopped selling aerial fireworks in its Utah stores, due to the high fire danger.  Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), June 21, 2012
Places: Utah, Cottonwood Heights, UT, Draper, UT, Herriman, UT, Holladay, UT, Salt Lake City, UT, Sandy, UT, West Valley City, UT, Sevier County, UT, Utah County, UT, Provo, UT

Title: About two-thirds of Indiana counties have open burn bans
Description: About two-thirds of Indiana counties have issued burn bans, and many jurisdictions have put limitations on the use of fireworks, according to Indiana State Fire Marshal Jim Greeson.Bedford Times-Mail (Ind.), June 28, 2012More than 40 of Indiana’s 92 counties have enacted open burning bans as local officials worry about the fire danger, given the exceedingly dry conditions.Terre Haute Tribune-Star (Ind.), June 21, 2012
Places: Indiana, Adams County, IN, Allen County, IN, Bartholomew County, IN, Benton County, IN, Blackford County, IN, Boone County, IN, Brown County, IN, Carroll County, IN, Cass County, IN, Clark County, IN, Clay County, IN, Clinton County, IN, Crawford County, IN, Daviess County, IN, Dearborn County, IN, Decatur County, IN, DeKalb County, IN, Delaware County, IN, Dubois County, IN, Elkhart County, IN, Fayette County, IN, Floyd County, IN, Fountain County, IN, Franklin County, IN, Fulton County, IN, Gibson County, IN, Grant County, IN, Greene County, IN, Hamilton County, IN, Hancock County, IN, Harrison County, IN, Hendricks County, IN, Henry County, IN, Howard County, IN, Huntington County, IN, Jackson County, IN, Jasper County, IN, Jay County, IN, Jefferson County, IN, Jennings County, IN, Johnson County, IN, Knox County, IN, Kosciusko County, IN, LaGrange County, IN, Lake County, IN, LaPorte County, IN, Lawrence County, IN, Madison County, IN, Marion County, IN, Marshall County, IN, Martin County, IN, Miami County, IN, Monroe County, IN, Montgomery County, IN, Morgan County, IN, Newton County, IN, Noble County, IN, Ohio County, IN, Orange County, IN, Owen County, IN, Parke County, IN, Perry County, IN, Pike County, IN, Porter County, IN, Posey County, IN, Pulaski County, IN, Putnam County, IN, Randolph County, IN, Ripley County, IN, Rush County, IN, Saint Joseph County, IN, Scott County, IN, Shelby County, IN, Spencer County, IN, Starke County, IN, Steuben County, IN, Sullivan County, IN, Switzerland County, IN, Tippecanoe County, IN, Tipton County, IN, Union County, IN, Vanderburgh County, IN, Vermillion County, IN, Vigo County, IN, Wabash County, IN, Warren County, IN, Warrick County, IN, Washington County, IN, Wayne County, IN, Wells County, IN, White County, IN, Whitley County, IN

Title: Burn bans in force across Indiana
Description: A large number of burn bans are now in effect across Indiana.From Michael Lewis, National Weather Service Northern Indiana, Syracuse, Indiana, on June 20, 2012

Title: Pasture conditions declining in Indiana
Description: Statewide, there are reports of spider mites appearing in drought-stressed soybean fields. Pasture conditions are declining, and some operations are now supplementing hay to livestock. Second hay cuttings have reduced yields due to dry conditions. This information was reported on page 18 of the Jun 19, 2012 edition of the USDA Weekly Weather and Crop Bulletin (valid June 10-16, 2012). From Melissa Widhalm in West Lafayette, Indiana, on June 19, 2012

Title: Ethanol production in Nebraska was down by about 30 percent
Description: Ethanol production in Nebraska was down by about 30 percent as high corn prices and reduced corn production raised concerns over how much corn should be used to produce ethanol.  Three of the 24 ethanol plants in Nebraska temporarily stopped producing the fuel after they originally intended to stop production for just one week for regular maintenance, but lengthened the shutdown to one month, according to an administrator for the Nebraska Ethanol Board.  A new ethanol plant in Aurora did not open as scheduled in June, but will open later.  Nebraska is the second largest ethanol producer in the country.  The Huffington Post (N.Y.), Aug. 3, 2012

Title: Drought stressing crops, trees in Michigan
Description: Drought is seriously impacting most agricultural crops across the southern Lower Peninsula of Michigan, especially the SW 1/4 of the state, and on lighter, coarse-textured soils. Stress symptoms are evident on most vegetation, including many shrubs and younger trees. Wilting/stress symptoms in my local area (Haslett/East Lansing) are the worst that I have observed during my 22 years in the state. Effects of the extended dryness (which began during the first week of May) have been exacerbated by recent abnormally high temperatures and, given low humidity and relatively clear skies, unusually high potential evapotranpiration rates. Forage and corn crops have already experienced significant irreversible damage, with the potential for much more without rain during the next 1-2 weeks.From a university researcher at Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, on July 10, 2012

Title: Personal use of fireworks prohibited in Colorado
Description: The governor of Colorado prohibited open burning and the personal use of fireworks due to dry conditions and elevated fire danger across the state.  Fines may be up to $1,000 for scofflaws.  Eleven wildfires in the state continued to actively burn and have already charred 169,776 acres and 605 homes.  Six people lost their lives in wildfires in 2012.  The Denver Post (Colo.), June 14, 2012 and The Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), July 5, 2012

Title: Missouri crops, lawns affected by drought
Description: Soybean stands were uneven and corn leaves were rolling from lack of moisture across Missouri, according to University of Missouri Extension specialists.  Pastures and lawns became crunchy as drought dried up the vegetation.Memphis Democrat (Mo.), June 14, 2012

Title: Ohia lehua trees dying off in Puu Ka Pele Forest Reserve in Kauhao, Hawaii
Description: There is a noticeable die-off of Ohia lehua trees in a portion of the Puu Ka Pele Forest Reserve in Kauhao.  Spots of dead and dying of old growth trees along ridge tops and southeast facing slopes can be observed by helicopter.From Thomas Kaiakapu, Department of Land and Natural Resources, Lihue, Hawaii, on June 18, 2012

Title: Sorghum not sprouting in Finney County, Kansas
Description: Finney County is dry. Wheat never received the finishing rain and sorghum is not sprouting.
Places: Kansas, Finney County, KS, Garden City, KS

Title: Governor of New Mexico urged cities, counties to decide on allowing fireworks
Description: The governor of New Mexico urgently encouraged city and county authorities to decide before the end of the day whether they would ban fireworks in their communities.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 13, 2012

Title: The Indiana fire marshal urged caution, given  the dry conditions and increased fire danger
Description: The Indiana fire marshal urged caution considering the dry conditions and increased fire danger.  He recommended that no cigarettes be thrown out the window, vehicles should not be parked over grass, caution must be used when grilling outdoors or using fireworks and people should dial 911 if a fire starts accidentally and there is question about whether the fire can be extinguished.  Indianapolis Star (Ind.), June 12, 2012

Title: Proposed horse slaughterhouse Roswell, New Mexico to handle abandoned horses in Southwest
Description: A businessman in Roswell filed an application to convert his livestock slaughterhouse to a horse slaughterhouse to dispose of the many abandoned, emaciated horses roaming the drought-stricken Southwest.  Many horse owners have struggled to find and afford hay for their horses and sometimes abandon them when they see no other solution, leading to overburdening of horse rescue operations.  Horse slaughterhouses were outlawed five years ago in the U.S.  to the relief of horse owners who felt that horses should not be slaughtered and were not treated humanely in the slaughter process.  A supervisor with the New Mexico Livestock Board stated that he gets calls about suspected animal abuse daily and that horse abandonments were increasing.  Because the matter of horse slaughter is very volatile, nothing will be done with the application this year because it is an election year, the businessman was told.  Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), June 6, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health

Title: Ranchers purchasing supplemental feed, destocking herd inventory on  Oahu (Hawaii)
Description: US Drought Monitor recently designated the entire island of Oahu as having abnormally dry conditions.Ranchers are purchasing supplemental feed and are also cutting feed from local sources (corn).  Ranchers are also destocking herd inventory due to forecasted continued dry summer conditions. Farmers in Waimanalo have voluntary water conservation of 10%.From Jason Shitanishi, USDA Farm Service Agency, Honolulu, Hawaii, on June 20, 2012

Title: Drought killed many Christmas trees in Michigan
Description: Drought killed many Christmas trees in Michigan and will force tree growers to plant extra trees this coming spring to make up for the loss.  A Christmas tree grower in Kent County stated that most of his new plantings died during the hot, dry summer.  WZZM-TV Grand Rapids 13 (Mich.), Nov. 20, 2012

Title: Dry conditions lead homeowners to water yards and gardens more frequently in Washington County, Wisconsin
Description: Very very dry conditions have developed across much of the county. Grass has gone yellow to brown across much of the yards and the dirt is bone dry with it also starting to crack in places. Many people are out watering their yards and gardens on an almost daily basis. We have picked up 2-3 inches of rain in the last two months which is several inches below normal. The month of June has been bone dry with most of the area picking up below a half inch of rain.From Adam Rosenberg, NWS Spotter - Skywarn Association, in West Bend, Wisconsin, on June 23, 2012
Places: Wisconsin, Cedarburg, WI, Washington County, WI, Hartford, WI, Jackson, WI, West Bend, WI

Title: Heat and drought contributed to the high number of wildfires in western and central Nebraska during the summer
Description: Heat and drought contributed to the high number of wildfires in western and central Nebraska during the summer that have caused rural fire departments to quickly spend the funds set aside for fuel and maintenance costs.  The prevalence of wildfires made it necessary for many rural fire departments to assist each other with firefighting efforts, forcing fire departments to travel thousands more miles than usual and increase fuel costs.  Nebraska officials estimated that firefighting costs have amounted to roughly $10 million.  A federal emergency grant will cover some of those costs.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Sept. 9, 2012
Places: Nebraska, Dawes County, NE, Sheridan County, NE

Title: Fewer deer harvested in Nebraska in 2013 after drought, EHD in 2012
Description: Drought and a harsh bout of epizootic hemorrhagic disease (EHD) were estimated to have killed one-third of the deer in Nebraska in the summer of 2012.  Some parts of the state were more harshly affected, while other areas suffered few deer losses.  Due to the EHD, there were fewer deer for the fall 2013 hunting season, prompting the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission to offer 87,000 fewer permits and bonus tags in 2013.  The 2013 total firearm deer harvest for the nine-day November firearm season was 36,882, which was 21 percent fewer deer than in 2012.  The big game program manager for the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission expected that roughly 50,000 deer would be harvested during the 2013 season.  About 60,000 deer were harvested in 2012.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), Nov. 30, 2013

Title: Peach trees around Belleville, Illinois produced fewer buds after a year of drought
Description: Drought caused the peach trees at an orchard near Belleville to lose 40 percent of the crop in 2012.  Many growers in Illinois thought that the drought made the peaches smaller, but more flavorful.  The drought also benefited the 2013 peach crop by making the trees produce fewer buds.  Workers did not have to spend as much time thinning the buds manually this spring.  Belleville News-Democrat (Ill.), July 17, 2013

Title: Fewer game birds in Montana
Description: Male sage grouse counts at leks in Montana averaged 14.9 males per lek, which is 48 percent below the long-term average and lower than the average of 19.2 males per lek in 2012.  It is thought that extreme drought in 2012, resulting in low brood survival, caused the population decline.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Aug. 22, 2013

Title: Hay prices high, supplies short in Wisconsin
Description: High hay prices stemming from drought has horse owners struggling to feed their animals and, in some instances, taking their horses to equine rescue operations in Wisconsin.  The president of Spirit Horse Equine Rescue Center in Janesville said that many horse owners have telephoned in recent weeks, seeking a home for their horses, but she cannot afford to take in any more horses.  The feed bill for the 41 horses at the sanctuary costs roughly $900 weekly, four times more than it cost one year ago.  Other horse rescue agencies were in similar straits.  Hay supplies across Wisconsin were lower than they have been in more than 50 years, by some estimates, driving prices for a small bale of hay up to $10, in comparison with $2 to $4 for a small bale in a normal year.  The hay that is available is often old and of poor quality.  Nationwide, hay supplies have not been so low since 1974, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  The high hay prices have led to thefts and scams.  In Rock County, a dairy farmer paid $5,520 for 24 tons of hay, but never received the hay.  The seller was arrested.  In Cadott, hay thieves stole dozens of hay bales intended to feed rescued donkeys.  Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), Feb. 23, 2013

Title: Pheasant-hunting season in Colorado affected by drought
Description: The pheasant-hunting season in Colorado will be different than past seasons because drought has decreased the amount of forage available for the birds to take cover, which also exposes them to more predators and may have diminished pheasant populations across the state.  Some farmers also used land enrolled in Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) for emergency haying and grazing, again leaving less cover for the pheasants.  Some of the land in the state’s Small Game Walk-In Access Program is in the CRP also.  Hunters will need to scout around to find good locations for pheasant hunting this year.  Denver Post (Colo.), Nov. 7, 2012

Title: Drought nearly halved Ohio's apple crop
Description: Ohio’s apple crop was hit by spring frosts, drought during the summer, extreme heat and hailstorms, which, cumulatively, were expected to cut the statewide harvest by nearly half, according to Bill Dodd, president of the Ohio Fruit Growers Marketing Association.  Apples grown during drought were also expected to be sweeter with better flavor.  The size was also reduced, as reported in Pataskala, where some newly planted apple trees perished, while other apple trees did not grow.  Columbus Dispatch (Ohio), Sept. 16, 2012
Places: Ohio, Licking County, OH, Pataskala, OH

Title: Lingering effects of the 2012 drought were still being felt by Iowa Christmas tree growers
Description: Lingering effects of the 2012 drought were still being felt by Iowa Christmas tree growers. Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier (Iowa), Dec. 21, 2014

Title: Officials with the Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourism anticipate fewer game birds across the state
Description: Officials with the Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourism anticipate fewer pheasant and quail across the state.  Heat and drought cut into nesting and brood habitat, stated the editor of the Kansas Wildlife, Parks and Tourism Magazine, meaning that it will be more difficult to find game birds this year.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), Nov. 9, 2012

Title: Drought during 2012 killed many trees across Nebraska; Nebraska Forest Service reconsiders tree recommendations
Description: Drought during 2012 killed many trees across Nebraska, with evergreens being the first to succumb to the dry conditions.  White pines, arborvitae, spruces, and even red cedar trees have also died.  The recent spate of tree deaths and climate change are prompting the Nebraska Forest Service to reconsider which trees it recommends for planting in the state.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), March 20, 2013 and Scottsbluff Star Herald (Neb.), July 10, 2013

Title: Fire-related restrictions were placed on New Mexico lands outside of municipalities
Description: Fire-related restrictions were placed on lands outside of municipalities, except for tribal and federal property, by the New Mexico Forestry Division.  Lighting fireworks, campfires and open fires was forbidden even on private lands outside a municipality.  Farmington Daily Times (N.M.), June 22, 2012

Title: Corn crop exhibited drought stress in Indiana
Description: The corn crop in Indiana exhibited drought stress as high temperatures and lack of rainfall affected the area.  South Bend Tribune (Ind.), May 31, 2012

Title: The Kansas Wildfire Prevention and Education Team encouraged Kansans to be careful with fire outdoors
Description: The Kansas Wildfire Prevention and Education Team encouraged Kansans to continue to follow local burn bans and be careful with fire outdoors because the fire danger remained high.  More than 41,000 acres and 26 structures burned in the state since May, according to the Kansas Forestry Service.  In the past seven days, seven fires charred more than 8,000 acres.  Fires this summer have burned hotter than usual, making them difficult to get under control, officials said.  Kansas City Star & KansasCity.com (Mo.), Aug. 30, 2012

Title: Smoke advisory for New Mexicans downwind of the Gila Wilderness fire
Description: A smoke advisory was issued by the New Mexico Department of Health and New Mexico Environment Department for parts of New Mexico affected by smoke from the Gila Wilderness fire along the western edge of the state. Wind carried the smoke to the east, reaching Roswell and West Texas.  People with health conditions, such as asthma, emphysema and cardiovascular disease were urged to see a health care provider if their usual medications do not alleviate symptoms from the existing conditions.  Clovis News Journal (N.M.), May 24, 2012

Title: Wheat nearly ready for harvest, corn leaves rolling in Kansas
Description: Drove from Wichita, KS, to Chester, NE, on Friday, May 18. Dry and windy conditions all along my trip north on U.S. 81. Wichita to McPherson had wheat nearly ready for harvest and corn leaves rolling in from heat stress. Large cracks in the ground. From Salina to Belleville most of the pasture ponds had water in them but most of the center piviots were watering crops.From a congressional staffer traveling north on U.S. 81 through Kansas, May 24, 2012

Title: Dry conditions hindered wheat kernel formation in parts of Kansas
Description: An agronomist with Kansas State University stated that dry conditions hindered wheat kernel formation with some wheat having little to no grain inside.  National Weather Service records indicate that southwest and central Kansas has received very little to no rain in the past 30 days.  Washington Post (D.C.), May 16, 2012

Title: Drought declaration for New Mexico
Description: The governor of New Mexico issued a drought declaration for the state on May 15.  The declaration will ease the way for farmers, ranchers and communities to get federal funding for drought-related expenses if the funding becomes available.  The Drought Task Force will begin meeting to assess preparation and mitigation strategies as different concerns arise.  The governor also pushed for a review of the state’s drought plan and encouraged municipalities to think about firework bans and fire restrictions.  Santa Fe New Mexican (N.M.), May 16, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Tree mortality survey underway in Texas to assess drought damage
Description: The Texas Forestry Service is attempting to determine more accurately how many trees were killed by the recent intense drought.  Crews are counting the number of dead trees and noting insects and tree diseases within a 75-foot radius on seven hundred plots of land.  A previous tree mortality estimate by the Texas Forest Service put the number as high as 500 million.  The assessment is expected to take two months.  Another more thorough tree study is also planned.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), May 14, 2012

Title: New email notification system to alert residents to wildfires in New Mexico
Description: The governor of New Mexico and state forestry officials announced a new statewide email notification system to alert residents to wildfires.  The unprecedented wildfire season in 2011 underscored the need for better communication to save lives.  The new system works with smartphones and tablets.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 7, 2012

Title: Hay, alfalfa expensive in Missouri
Description: The average price of dry hay in May was $111 per ton, compared to $88 a ton last year, according to the National Agriculture Statistics Service.  The price for a ton was $71 in 2010.  The price for a ton of alfalfa was $190 in May, in comparison with $125 a ton last year at this time.  Columbia Missourian, June 12, 2012

Title: Kansas dairy farmers lost 24 cents on each gallon of milk sold
Description: Dairy farmers lost 24 cents on each gallon of milk sold in May and June, due to drought and exceptionally high production costs, according to the National Agricultural Statistics Service.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), Oct. 19, 2012

Title: New Jersey residents asked to conserve water by the state Department of Environmental Protection
Description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection urged residents to voluntarily use less water after months of below normal rainfall.  Stream flow and groundwater levels were lower than normal.  lehighvalleylive.com (N.J.), May 1, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Greater number of wildfires in Arkansas
Description: The dry conditions contributed to an increased number of wildfires in Arkansas in May when 150 forest fires consumed 1,508 acres, according to the Arkansas Forestry Commission.  On average, 25 fires affect the state in May and burn about 200 acres.  Fort Smith Southwest Times Record (Ark.), June 6, 2012

Title: West central, southwest Florida counties under mandatory water restrictions
Description: A Phase Three Severe Water Shortage continues for Levy, Citrus, Hernando, and Sumter counties. Elsewhere across west central and southwest Florida a Phase One Moderate Water Shortage remains in effect. Water restrictions are in effect for all counties in west central and southwest Florida. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Tampa Bay Area, Florida - April 27, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Florida, Citrus County, FL, Hernando County, FL, Levy County, FL, Sumter County, FL

Title: Locks along Lake Okeechobee (Florida) closed because of low water
Description: The Corps of Engineers of Florida have closed some locks along Lake Okeechobee because of the low water in the lake. The locks that are closed are S-135 at J and S Fish Camp in Martin County, G-35 at Hendry Creek in Okeechobee County, S-127 at Buckhead Ridge in Glades County, and S-131 at Lakeport in Glades County. The South Florida Water Management District has kept all of south Florida in a yearly water restriction, which reduces water usage to 3 days a week. They have also continued the water shortage warning. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Miami, Florida - April 27, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Florida, Glades County, FL, Hendry County, FL, Martin County, FL, Okeechobee County, FL, Palm Beach County, FL

Title: Burning restricted in Lake, Cook, and St. Louis counties in Minnesota
Description: Severe drought persists over Lake and Cook counties and a portion of St. Louis County. Topsoil moisture is rated as 21 percent short, 69 percent adequate, and 6 percent surplus. The fire danger rating is high and burning is restricted, with a variance required in the severe drought area.NWS - Drought Information Statement - Duluth, Minnesota - April 27, 2012
Places: Minnesota, Cook County, MN, Lake County, MN, Saint Louis County, MN

Title: Colorado Water Trust, Nature Conservancy seeking to purchase water rights to benefit wildlife in Colorado rivers
Description: The Colorado Water Trust was seeking water rights holders willing to temporarily lease water rights to allow water to flow in tributaries to the Colorado, Eagle, Fraser and Gunnison rivers.  Meager snowfall this winter will not likely provide enough water for wildlife once municipal and agricultural demands were met, spurring the Colorado Water Trust to act. The agency may have up to $400,000 to use for funding leases.  The Nature Conservancy was considering leasing water rights on the Cache la Poudre River to Fort Collins and the Dolores River below the McPhee Reservoir to preserve wildlife.  The mountain snowpack was 39 percent of normal, foretelling a summer of tight water supplies.  The Denver Post (Colo.), April 26, 2012.A water leasing program put forth by the Colorado Water Trust was successful this summer in directing water to dwindling rivers and streams in the state.  The Colorado Water Trust paid for water from water rights holders who did not intend to use their water and allowed the water to remain in the streams for the benefit of wildlife.  The Yampa River flowing through Steamboat Springs was one stretch of the more than 190 miles of rivers and streams to profit from the program.  Aspen Public Radio (Colo.), Nov. 20, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Colorado, Delta County, CO, Dolores County, CO, Eagle County, CO, Garfield County, CO, Grand County, CO, Gunnison County, CO, Larimer County, CO, Mesa County, CO, Montezuma County, CO, Montrose County, CO, San Miguel County, CO
