Title: Burn bans in Young, Stephens and Eastland counties in Texas
Description: Outdoor burn bans continue for Young, Stephens, and Eastland counties. The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association estimates that it may take more than 5 years to rebuild the Texas cattle industry. To foster the proper rebuilding of herds and help maintain the cattle infrastructure, the Texas Agrilife Extension Service has hosted educational programs throughout the state. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dalls/Fort Worth, Texas - April 26, 2012
Places: Texas, Eastland County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Florida governor briefed on greater likelihood of wildfires in upcoming fire season
Description: The Florida Forest Service director briefed the governor and his cabinet members on the upcoming fire season.  There is a higher likelihood of wildfires in June and July, given the prolonged drought.  In the previous week, there were 91 fires affecting 39,000 acres.  Of those 91 fires, 16 have burned more than 100 acres.  Tallahassee Democrat & Tallahassee.com (Fla.), April 24, 2012

Title: Drought conditions prevented Florida authorities from accomplishing prescribed burning
Description: Drought conditions prevented Florida authorities from accomplishing as much prescribed burning as they would have liked to do, according to the state’s agriculture commissioner.  Palm Beach Post (Fla.), April 24, 2012

Title: Irrigation needed in Delaware
Description: Some Delaware farmers were irrigating fields in preparation for planting, while irrigation was already underway in some orchards, according to a fruit and vegetable specialist with the University of Delaware cooperative extension service.  Both practices are highly unusual for this time of year.  Wilmington News Journal (Delaware Online), April 21, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water use restrictions remain in place in southern Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents of Victoria and Corpus Christi are also encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - April 19, 2012

Title: Producers waiting for moisture before planting in southern Texas
Description: In spite of improved rainfall, producers were still waiting on additional showers for planting crops. Although some soil moisture was available in many areas, it was not enough in general for planting. Cotton farmers over the Rolling Plains in particular were on edge with moisture badly needed before planting. Producers were pre-irrigating where irrigation was available. Winter wheat was mostly a loss because of drought conditions. Pasture and rangeland improved slightly while livestock were in fair to good condition with supplemental feeding. Many trees, shrubs, and grasses have died or responded poorly to the recent moisture. Some poorer fields over the Rolling Plains were being "disastered out" by crop insurance companies. Lubbock entered stage 2 of its drought contingency plan on April 1 because of an anticipated gap in water supply. Stage 2 restrictions limit water usage to certain times and certain days of the week, while refraining from certain other aesthetic or non-essential uses of water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Lubbock, Texas - April 19, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Maryland Department of Natural Resources discouraged open burning
Description: The Maryland Department of Natural Resources urged residents to avoid open burning until rain alleviates the fire danger.  Baltimore Sun (Md.), April 19, 2012

Title: Grassfire delays train in Bownsville, Minnesota
Description: On April 9, Houston County fire fighters battled a grass fire near Bownsville, Minnesota. Firefighters said that the fire burned a marshy area, and no property was damaged. While they were fighting the fire, a train had to be stopped while a special water tanker was brought down the railroad tracks to help fight the fire. It was not clear how the fire started. There were also reports of wild fires in Olmsted County. As of the morning of April 10, no burning permits are being issued across southeast Minnesota. However, camp fires are allowed. NWS - Drought Information Statement - La Crosse, Wisconsin - April 12, 2012

Title: The Connecticut Department of Public Health contacted water companies and requested that they closely monitor reservoir levels
Description: The Connecticut Department of Public Health contacted water companies and requested that they closely monitor reservoir levels and report back if water levels fell enough to trigger drought measures.  Water levels were declining since there was no snowmelt to bolster stream flow and recharge aquifers.  Abundant rainfall in 2010 and 2011 filled reservoirs so none were precariously low at this point.  Torrington Register Citizen (Conn.), April 19, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The drop rate for Florida Valencia oranges climbed to 19 percent
Description: The drop rate for Florida Valencia oranges climbed to 19 percent as freeze damage, dry weather and citrus greening all contributed to stress the fruit trees, leading to the high drop rate.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture revised the expected orange harvest downward by 2 million boxes, which is 1 percent of production, due to the elevated drop rate and the small size of the fruit.  The Valencia orange harvest, which occurs from March through June, was anticipated to be 71 million boxes, down 3 percent from a previous estimate.  Lakeland Ledger (Fla.), April 10, 2012

Title: Drought allowed new weed to thrive in parts of Texas
Description: An invasive weed of Mediterranean origin called bastard cabbage was thriving in parts of Texas where drought killed lots of grass, such as in overgrazed pastures, stated the director of vegetation management for the Texas Transportation Department.  Rapistrum rugosum grows to 2 to 5 feet in height and has full leafy branches with yellow flowers.  The weed was crowding out bluebonnets and other wildflowers in some areas and making it difficult for grass to reestablish itself.  Efforts were underway to control the weed.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 10, 2012

Title: Fire mitigation efforts underway in Minnesota state parks
Description: The Minnesota Department of Natural Resources Parks and Trails Division was mitigating the fire danger in state parks by mowing 30 to 40 feet control lines in prairie openings and considering closing some prairie trails and restricting campfires when fire danger was particularly high.  Low snowfall during the winter prevented the agency from conducting spring burns.  Alexandria Echo Press (Minn.), April 9, 2012

Title: Wildfire damages homes and businesses in Suffolk County, New York
Description: Massive wildfire that has already burned more than 1000 acres continues to burn after starting Monday afternoon around 2:30pm. More than 110 fire companies responded with Air National Guard firefighting team with their helicopters and C-130 ready to spring into action if they are activated. Conditions today have red flag warning with increasing winds and low humidity with no rain in the near term future. Two houses have been burned to the ground with more damaged. Businesses have been burned down as well. Firefighters have been injured. From Michael Bredemeyer, Orient Fire Department/New York State Parks, Riverhead, New York, on April 9, 2012.

Title: Ninety-seven counties in Texas ban outdoor burning
Description: Ninety-seven counties in south and West Texas and the Panhandle have bans on outdoor burning due to dry conditions and elevated fire danger.  Odessa American (Texas), April 9, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions in effect in south Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents of Corpus Christi are also encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) In the past year, a donkey rescue group collected almost 800 abandoned donkeys, animals that were abandoned because of the drought. Also, although conditions have improved after several weeks of rain, Coastal Bend livestock producers continued to supplemental feed their herds. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - April 5, 2012

Title: Outdoor burning restricted in New Jersey
Description: The New Jersey Forest Fire Service restricted outdoor burning, due to low humidity, forecasted strong winds and dry conditions.  The only outdoor fires that are permissible are those in a prepared fire ring with a steel, stone, brick or concrete perimeter with a base of gravel or masonry.  There were 359 wildfires that have consumed 286 acres in 2012, up from 2011 when 190 fires scorched 186 acres over the same period.  New Jersey Herald, April 4, 2012

Title: Some producers feeding hay; low waters affecting canoe business in Missouri
Description: Hay production reduced to half, pasture condition poor. Some livestock producers feeding hay due to lack of pasture. Rivers/streams low, causing a reduction to the canoe business and therefore reducing tourism. From a extension agent in Greenville, Missouri, on May 23, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Lengthy fire season in South Dakota
Description: The fire season in South Dakota began earlier than usual in 2012, when fires began popping up in March and continues with no end in sight.  The fire season normally extends from the latter part of July through mid-September when fall rains ease the fire danger.  The prolonged fire season meant that , an aerial firefighting company with planes stationed around the state in Pierre, Hot Springs, Mobridge and Lemmon have spent more time on call than usual.  Sioux City Journal (Iowa), Oct. 7, 2012

Title: Grass fires reported in South Dakota
Description: The persistent dry weather has allowed farmers to get into their fields and begin planting small grains in some areas of South Dakota. Moisture is still needed in most areas of the state to help with progress and condition of the winter wheat, alfalfa, and pastures. Winter wheat condition is rated at 3 percent very poor, 16 percent poor, 32 percent fair, and 49 percent good to excellent condition. Topsoil moisture is rated at 7 percent very short, 43 percent short, 48 percent adequate, and 2 percent surplus. Subsoil moisture is rated at 4 percent very short, 40 percent short, 55 percent adequate, and 1 percent surplus. Numerous grass fires continue to be reported across various counties because of the continued dryness. During March, several red flag warnings were issued because of the critical fire weather conditions. Grassland fire danger indices have reached the very high to extreme category on several occasions. A March 16 fire near Richmond Road just outside of Aberdeen was one and a half miles long and a quarter mile wide. A burn ban was issued for McPherson County on March 21. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Aberdeen, South Dakota - March 30, 2012

Title: High pollen counts keep allergists busy in central Indiana
Description: Pollen counts have been exceptionally high in central Indiana for the last 14 days. The recent hot, dry summer caused pollen-producing plants to ramp up pollen production because it’s a survival mechanism to ensure that the plants produce offspring after a difficult growing season.  As a result, allergists were very busy and have been busy since March with an exceptionally high number of patients seeking relief from allergies.  Indianapolis Star (Ind.), Sept. 23, 2012
Places: Indiana, Johnson County, IN, Franklin, IN, Marion County, IN, Indianapolis, IN

Title: Ag producers hauling water; urban areas seeing increased irrigation in central Arizona
Description: With several months of dry weather during a typically wet time of year, impacts are multifaceted and include water hauling for farmers/ranchers, increased irrigation in urban areas, and a significant drop in water stores in area reservoirs. The lack of precipitation is also setting the stage for above-average fire activity during the coming months. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Phoenix, Arizona - March 15, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Title: In Texas, water restrictions, burn bans continue; dry weather keeping migrating birds away
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Duval County recently removed its burn ban. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents in Victoria and Corpus Christi are also strongly encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) According to an Associated Press article dated March 1, the Texas drought has affected the migration of many birds that normally come to Texas during the cool season but have gone elsewhere because of the lack of food. This includes whooping cranes, ducks, geese, and other waterfowl. The Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA) announced that, for the first time ever, they will not be releasing water to support rice production. This will have a profound impact on rice production, as the production of Texas rice contributes more than $200 million to the state economy each year and accounts for thousands of jobs. The Texas Crop and Weather Reports for February 28 and March 6 noted that in the coastal bend district, livestock were still being supplemented with hay and protein. In the western areas (considered part of the south district), recent rainfall improved range and pastures, allowing livestock producers to cut back on supplemental feeding. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - March 8, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Red oaks, other tree species affected by drought in South Carolina
Description: The South Carolina Forestry Commission reported that red oak trees have been severely affected by drought causing many of them, especially in the Savannah River basin, to succumb to environmental pests. Other species of trees have also been affected.NWS - Drought Information Statement - Columbia, South Carolina - March 8, 2012

Title: Kansas adopted two new water laws
Description: Kansas adopted two new water laws that give water rights holders more flexibility on water use.  The first allows water rights holders to retain their water rights even if the water goes unused.  Previously water had to be used or water rights holders could lose their rights.  The second bill allows water rights holders to pump more water than annually allotted if additional irrigation water is needed, but must not exceed some set amount that may be used over a certain period of time.   The legislation is intended to prolong the water supply in the Ogallala Aquifer by allowing farmers and ranchers to irrigate more when they need to and by encouraging conservation when rainfall is plentiful.  Hays Daily News (Kansas), March 5, 2012

Title: Roughly 2.05 million cattle were on feedlots in Kansas on March 1, 2013, a decline of about 7 percent
Description: Roughly 2.05 million cattle were on feedlots in Kansas on March 1, 2013, a decline of about 7 percent from the previous year, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  The spokeswoman for the Kansas Livestock Association stated that drought was the reason there were fewer cattle.  Drought dried up pastures in past years, leading producers to sell animals earlier and to hold onto fewer livestock since feed costs were high.  Many cattle producers are not in a position to consider rebuilding their herd since the drought continues.  Another year of drought may force some producers to liquidate their herd.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), April 13, 2013

Title: Oklahoma Department of Agricultural Forestry reports numerous fires in early March
Description: Warm, dry, and windy conditions at the beginning of March led to many wildfires. The Oklahoma Department of Agriculture forestry services reported 26 fires burned approximately 1500 acres within their protection district in eastern Oklahoma on March 5 alone. Several large fires also affected northeast Oklahoma on March 6.

Title: Drought caused birds that usually winter in the Texas Panhandle to go elsewhere
Description: Drought caused birds that usually winter in the Texas Panhandle to rethink their plans.  Just 15,000 ducks were in the Panhandle this winter, in comparison with 36,000 last winter.  Fewer ponds and reduced surface water supplies probably discouraged the ducks from staying there.  Instead, more ducks were wintering in the state’s prairie areas, where biologists estimate there were 1.2 million ducks, up from 885,000 last year.  Biologists wonder how the usual winter habitation might affect the birds’ well being as they begin the return journey to their summer habitat and attempt to reproduce.  The Daily News (Texas), March 1, 2012

Title: Many Christmas tree seedlings died in southern Wisconsin
Description: Many southern Wisconsin Christmas tree farms lost almost all of their seedlings planted in 2012 after drought killed the trees.  Many tree growers were likely to plant more the next year to compensate for the seedlings lost in 2012. At a tree farm near Merrimac, just 300 seedlings of the 4,500 planted survived.  Hardly any of the 30,000 seedlings planted near Endeavor in Marquette County survived.  Nearly all of the 7,000 seedlings planted in Middleton died.Portage Daily Register (Wis.), Aug. 1, 2012
Places: Wisconsin, Adams County, WI, Columbia County, WI, Crawford County, WI, Dane County, WI, Dodge County, WI, Fond du Lac County, WI, Grant County, WI, Green County, WI, Green Lake County, WI, Iowa County, WI, Jefferson County, WI, Juneau County, WI, Kenosha County, WI, La Crosse County, WI, Lafayette County, WI, Marquette County, WI, Milwaukee County, WI, Monroe County, WI, Ozaukee County, WI, Racine County, WI, Richland County, WI, Rock County, WI, Sauk County, WI, Sheboygan County, WI, Vernon County, WI, Walworth County, WI, Washington County, WI, Waukesha County, WI

Title: All counties in Michigan were declared to be natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture due to drought and high temperatures
Description: All counties in Michigan were declared to be natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture due to drought and high temperatures since March 1, 2012.  This declaration permits affected farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural producers to apply for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.  Sault Ste. Marie Evening News (Mich.), Oct. 7, 2012

Title: Two Texas congressmen objected to the Air Force’s plans to move eight C-130 Hercules aircraft from Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Two Texas congressmen objected to the Air Force’s plans to move eight C-130 Hercules aircraft from Fort Worth to Montana, fearing that Texas may be less prepared to fight wildfires in the upcoming fire season.  The assignment of the aircraft to the Texas Air National Guard makes them accessible to the state in the event of disasters, such as a wildfire or a hurricane.   Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Feb. 28, 2012

Title: Forage still inadequate, water restrictions in place across north Texas
Description: Despite the improvement in north Texas, only 18 percent of pasture and rangeland across the state was rated as good or excellent. Forage was still inadequate in many areas. Supplemental feeding, much of which is accomplished with out-of-state hay, remains widespread across the state. Water restrictions remain in place across north Texas. Tarrant Regional Water District (87 percent capacity) and Dallas Water (89 percent) are in stage 1, while the North Texas Municipal Water District will remain in stage 3 until June 1. For Groesbeck (Limestone County), only voluntary conservation is currently ongoing. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas - February 25, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Revenues from snow-based recreational activities down in Vermont
Description: Revenues from snow mobile pass sales and snow-dependent recreational activities were down in Vermont, due to the lack of snow, stated the general manager of Stowe Snowmobile Tours and alternate director for the Vermont Area of Snow Travelers for Washington County.  When fewer people participate in these snow-based activities, other businesses such as gas stations, restaurants and hotels also take in less revenue.  The number of Vermont Area of Snow Travelers passes sold was much lower than at this time last year.  Stowe Reporter (Vt.), Feb. 23, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water use restrictions remain in effect in Texas
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Duval, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents in Victoria are also strongly encouraged to conserve water. Corpus Christi residents are encouraged to voluntarily conserve water. More stringent water restrictions were considered over the past few months, but some local officials were concerned that water restrictions would curtail revenue generated by water usage by companies and residences (and the only way to keep the revenue up during restrictions was to raise water use rates). Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) The Texas Forecast Service recently reported that the Texas drought killed an estimated 5.6 million trees. The Lower Colorado River Authority is expected to announce on March 1 that they will likely not release irrigation water for thousands of farmers in rice growing regions. If true, this will not only impact the rice farmers, but ranchers as well (however, most ranchers have already culled their herds). Also, it is suspected that the whooping crane population may be more widely dispersed this year because of the drought, because of the lack of their important food source - blue crabs. The Texas Crop and Weather Reports for February 14 and 21 contained the following information: In the Coastal Bend district, livestock producers were still supplementing cattle with hay and protein, in part due to lack of forage. For the western areas (considered part of the south district), supplemental feed for cattle was still greatly needed as many ranchers’ hay stocks were short, and prices continued to rise. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - February 23, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: The Oklahoma Health Department announced that the West Nile virus ceased to present a serious health threat within the state
Description: The Oklahoma Health Department announced that the West Nile virus ceased to present a serious health threat within the state.  With the drought, reduction in surface water supplies and diminished mosquito population, just one person was reported to be infected in 2011 and recovered from the illness.  No one in Oklahoma has died from West Nile virus since 2009.  Tulsa World (Okla.), Feb. 21, 2012

Title: Minnesota farmers were encouraged by state officials to purchase crop insurance
Description: Minnesota farmers were encouraged by state officials to purchase crop insurance in view of the present drought conditions affecting most of the state.  The insurance deadline is March 15.  The Minnesota agriculture commissioner and commerce commissioner were among those advocating crop insurance.  Duluth News Tribune (Minn.), Feb. 19, 2012

Title: The governor of New Mexico approved a bill that allows trucks to carry oversized loads of hay
Description: The governor of New Mexico approved a bill that allows trucks to carry oversized loads of hay with a permit since drought has left many ranchers with inadequate hay supplies.  Clovis News Journal (N.M.), Feb. 14, 2012

Title: Seed corn shortage in Minnesota
Description: A seed corn shortage has emerged after a wet spring in Minnesota and northern parts of the Corn Belt in 2011 and drought in corn producing regions later in the year.  Syngenta harvested 15 to 25 percent less seed corn in 2011, while Pioneer Hi-Bred harvested 15 percent less on account of bad weather.  Pioneer even advised customers to check with other seed companies to find what they needed.  An agronomist with Gold Country Seed also confirmed that seed supplies were tight.  Farmers who have not yet ordered seed corn may not be able to get it, which would be unfortunate, given the current high price for corn.  Post-Bulletin (Rochester, Minn.), Feb. 13, 2012

Title: Burning permits required for open burning across the southern three-fourths of Minnesota
Description: Burning permits were required for open burning across the southern three-fourths of Minnesota as dry conditions increased the fire danger.  Abundant fuel on about 185,000 acres in east central Minnesota from a windstorm last summer, in addition to moderate drought, led officials to prepare for an intense fire season by hiring extra firefighters, securing more heavy equipment than usual and extending a contract for helicopter service.  Grasses normally buried under snow provided fuel for wildfires.  Grand Forks Herald (Minn.), Feb. 10, 2012

Title: Live oak trees in Texas sloughing off bark
Description: Live oak trees have been sloughing off bark in many parts of Texas, according to an Abilene area arborist, who stated that the bark was coming loose on the lower trunk, sometimes in small patches and, in other instances, in much larger sections.  The bark was coming loose because the cambium beneath the bark, which transports of nutrients for the tree, had died.  Other arborists across the state confirmed that they were seeing the same problem among live oak trees.  The problem is assumed to be drought-related.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Feb. 7, 2012

Title: The Georgia Forestry Commission encouraged land owners to begin prescribed burning to reduce the amount of fuel for wildfires later
Description: The Georgia Forestry Commission encouraged land owners to begin prescribed burning to reduce the amount of fuel for wildfires later.  Much of the state was in drought, elevating the fire danger.  WALB-TV NBC 10 Albany (Ga.), Feb. 7, 2012

Title: South Florida remains in yearly water restriction
Description: Wells over most of south Florida have continued to run at the lowest 10 to 30 percent of normal levels, with a few of them in Hendry and inland Collier counties running at the lowest 10 percent of normal levels. A burn ban is in place for Hendry County. The South Florida Water Management District has kept all of south Florida in the yearly water restriction, which reduces water usage to 3 days a week. They have also continued the water shortage warning, which means that water shortage conditions are possible in the next 1 to 3 months if the lack of rainfall continues over south Florida. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Miami, Florida - February 2, 2012
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Governor of Kansas urged legislators to update the state’s water policy to give farmers and ranchers some flexibility in water usage
Description: The governor of Kansas urged legislators to update the state’s water policy to give farmers and ranchers some flexibility in water usage, particularly during drought years.  The issue was under discussion in the Senate Agriculture Committee.  Dodge City Daily Globe (Kan.), Jan. 26, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Some cattle were selling for 30 percent more per pound in Oklahoma
Description: Some cattle were selling for 30 percent more per pound than at this time last year, according to a stockyard owner in Tulsa.  The record prices were due to drastically reduced cattle numbers in the U.S. since drought forced many ranchers to sell their livestock rather than purchase expensive hay.    Increasing demand for beef in Japan, South Korea and Mexico also play a role in the higher prices.  KOTV-TV CBS 6 Tulsa (Okla.), Jan. 23, 2012

Title: The Oklahoma Livestock Relief Coalition assists with the cost of caring for abandoned animals
Description: Oklahoma state and agriculture authorities created the Oklahoma Livestock Relief Coalition to assist local law enforcement agencies with the cost of caring for abandoned animals since many horses and some goats and sheep have been abandoned.  Drought, dry pastures and the high demand for hay increased the abandonment rate in some parts of the state.  People can contribute to the OLRC, which will provide law enforcement agencies with funds to care for animals.  Prior to the new program, local law enforcement agencies had to cover the expenses themselves, which can run into thousands of dollars to pay for boarding, feed and veterinary bills.  Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), Jan. 23, 2012

Title: Volunteer fire departments across Texas gearing up for another harsh wildfire season
Description: Volunteer fire departments across Texas were gearing up for another harsh wildfire season since drought was projected to persist for the state.  Unfortunately, state budget cuts eliminated millions of dollars’ worth of grants for volunteer fire departments, making the task of keeping communities safe an enormous challenge and one for which some departments feel unprepared.  A firefighter in Angelina County stated that his two tanker trucks were 25 and 30 years old and were both homemade.  The ages of the vehicles worries him and leaves him wondering if the vehicle is safe and can perform when needed.  A member of the Huntington VFD also expressed concern about the lack of appropriate equipment.  KTRE-TV ABC 9 (Lufkin, Texas), Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Officials in New Mexico prepare for upcoming fire season
Description: New Mexico fire officials were preparing for an early fire season and another year of intense wildfires like the state endured in 2011.  Federal land management agencies also were ensuring that they were stocked and strategically positioned to respond to wildfires as they occur.  The U.S. Forest Service Southwestern Region scheduled a meeting for January 26 to connect vendors in preparation for the upcoming fire season.  Carlsbad Current-Argus (N.M.), Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions continue to affect south Texas
Description: Fire danger is currently moderate to high because of gusty winds and the recent lack of rainfall. As of January 12, burn bans were in effect for 14 counties in south central Texas. The counties with established outdoor burn bans include Bexar, Dewitt, Dimmit, Edwards, Frio, Karnes, Kerr, Kinney, Maverick, Medina, Real, Uvalde, Val Verde, and Zavala counties. Currently, Atascosa, Bandera, Bastrop, Blanco, Burnet, Caldwell, Comal, Fayette, Gillespie, Gonzales, Gudalupe, Hays, Kendall, Lavaca, Lee, Llano, Travis, Williamson, and Wilson counties have lifted their burn bans. Residents in all counties should contact their local county judge’s office or fire marshal before deciding to conduct any type of outdoor burning. The Texas Crop and Weather Report issued by Texas A&M indicated moisture from recent rains was already drying up. Earlier green-up turned brown with freezing temperatures and lack of continued rainfall. With little or no standing crop of native grasses, livestock producers continued to provide heavy supplemental feed for cattle. Some larger ranches sold off more cattle because of projections of continued drought. The San Antonio Water System (SAWS) is currently back in stage 1 water restrictions. The mandatory restrictions and the more frequent rain events have helped to keep the Edwards Aquifer level from falling below 650 feet. The Edwards Aquifer is currently reading 652.4 feet (as of January 12). This is 17.6 feet below the historical monthly average for January, which is 670.0 feet. The aquifer level is 26.8 feet below the level observed on this date in January 2011. Once new restrictions are in place, they will remain in place for 30 days after rising above the trigger level. After 30 days, if the aquifer level remains above the trigger level, then restrictions will be updated. Many communities across south central Texas have implemented the first, second, third, and fourth stages of water restrictions because of the long-term dry conditions and decreasing water supplies. The Barton Springs remain in critical stage 3 with a ten-day average flow of 22.2 cubic feet per minute. The flow rates remain very low despite above-average rainfall in December 2010. The rains did provide some recharge, but the benefits will be temporary unless significant rainfall is observed over the next 6 months. Austin remains in stage 2 water restrictions, San Marcos is in stage 1 water restrictions and the city of Kerrville remains in stage 4 water restrictions. Locations that do not currently have mandatory restrictions continue to strongly promote year round water conservation. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Austin/San Antonio, Texas - January 12, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Discussion of drought's effect on power generation in Texas
Description: The continuing drought in Texas and the threat of insufficient water supplies to produce adequate power had Texas Senate Democrats nervous about the state’s ability to avoid brownouts and to continue to draw businesses to the state.  The topic was discussed at a Senate Committee on Business and Commerce meeting.  State utility authorities asserted that electricity was too cheaply produced to offer any incentive to upgrade infrastructure and encourage more efficient means of generating electricity to avoid drought-induced brownouts.  One senator expressed concern that the state’s power grid deterred companies from setting up shop in Texas.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Jan. 10, 2012

Title: Dry conditions increasing fire danger in Nevada
Description: Dry conditions in northern Nevada prompted the state climatologist to warn the public about the increasing fire danger from dry vegetation across the state.  In late December, 400 acres burned in a brush fire in Carson City.  Large fires in Humboldt, Eureka, Washoe and Elko counties damaged rangeland, homes and wildlife habitat toward the end of 2011.  The climatologist also noted, "In the last month, we've had fire at 6,000-, 7,000-foot elevations, and active fire behavior," which was unusual because the mountains were usually covered in snow at this time of year.  Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Jan. 8, 2012

Title: Mandatory and voluntary fire restrictions remain in place in central Alabama
Description: Some local mandatory water restrictions remain in place, especially in some of the southeastern sections of central Alabama, with voluntary restrictions in other areas. The fire danger risk across central Alabama remains highest in the extreme southeast sections. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Birmingham, Alabama - January 5, 2012

Title: California's 2012-16 drought costs utilities $5.5 billion
Description: The 2012-16 drought in California reduced water supplies, which led to a decrease in hydropower production.  The loss in electricity generation cost PG&E and other California utilities roughly $5.5 billion, according to a study done by researchers at North Carolina State University.  Much of the shortfall in hydropower production was made up by natural gas, a more expensive form of energy production.  The lost hydropower production cost utilities $1.5 billion and the higher demand for electricity amounted to nearly $4 billion.  In 2015 at the height of California’s drought, hydropower met only 6 percent of the Golden State’s electricity needs, whereas it usually covered 15 percent of demand. The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), Aug. 10, 2020

Title: Drought and wildfires hurt the Colorado rafting industry in 2012
Description: Drought and wildfires hurt the Colorado rafting industry in 2012 as visitation dropped 17.1 percent to 411,100 visitor days, which is the lowest level since 2002.  Drought reduced some rivers to a trickle, like the Blue River in Summit County and the Eagle River above Avon.  In northern Colorado, the Cache de Poudre River was closed for three weeks in June as a wildfire burned in the area.  User days for the Poudre River fell by 40 percent in 2012.  The six outfitters on the river pulled in nearly $7 million in revenue in 2012, compared to $11.2 million the previous year, according to a report from the Colorado River Outfitters Association.  There were 19 percent fewer commercial rafters on the Arkansas River in 2012, but the rafters brought $52.6 million in revenue to the communities of Buena Vista, Salida, Cotopaxi and Cañon City, in comparison with $61.7 the previous year.  Statewide, the revenue from commercial rafting dropped 15.7 percent to $127.6 million, lower than the $151.4 million generated in 2011.  The Colorado River benefitted from poorer flows on other rivers and saw 30 percent more visitors rafting from near State Bridge to Utah’s Westwater Canyon.  The Colorado Adventure Center created a couple of zip line tours to compensate for the reduction in rafters since the flow in Clear Creek was down.  Farmington Daily Times (N.M.), Feb. 7, 2013

Title: Californians’ electric bills rose  $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016
Description: Californians’ electric bills rose a collective $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016 as drought sharply reduced the availability of cheap hydroelectricity, estimated the Pacific Institute, an Oakland water policy think tank.  In 2016, federal data showed that Californians spent nearly $39 million on electricity Peter Gleick, the study’s author and institute’s president emeritus, noted that the loss of hydropower caused environmental impacts too.  Carbon emissions from the state’s power plants increased 10 percent during the drought as utilities reverted to conventional sources like natural gas.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 26, 2017
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Imperial County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Ethanol production in Iowa voluntarily declined by about 20 percent since the beginning of 2012
Description: Ethanol production in Iowa voluntarily declined by about 20 percent since the beginning of 2012 as high corn prices combined with reduced corn production from drought and heat raised concerns over the amount of corn used in ethanol production.  The CEO of the Renewable Fuels Association stated that nationwide ethanol production had fallen by 20 percent since the start of 2012 and was at its lowest point in the last two years.   There are 41 ethanol plants in Iowa which produce about one-third of the country's ethanol.  The Huffington Post (N.Y.), Aug. 3, 2012

Title: Last year's drought led Texas pecan trees to produce excessive number of nuts
Description: Drought during the early part of the growing season led pecan trees to produce an abundance of nuts, according to an AgriLife Extension horticulture specialist in College Station, resulting in an anticipated harvest of 65 million pounds of pecans this year.  Last year’s drought badly stressed the trees, prompting them to produce more nuts than usual to ensure the survival of the species, which led to branch breakage, due to the excessive numbers of nuts.  The Vindicaor (Liberty, Texas), Oct. 12, 2012

Title: Drought in 2012 cost Kansas farmers more than $3 billion in crop losses
Description: Drought in 2012 cost Kansas farmers more than $3 billion in crop losses, including the cost of production and the price farmers could have gotten for their crops.  Hutchinson News (Kan.), May 8, 2013

Title: Drought pulled down personal income in South Dakota by 0.2 percent in 2012
Description: Drought pulled down personal income in South Dakota by 0.2 percent in 2012.  Earnings for the farm industry dropped by an estimated 27 percent, compared to 2011, and crop output declined by 18 percent, according to a regional economist with the Bureau of Economic Analysis.  Sioux Falls Argus Leader (S.D.), March 28, 2013

Title: Drought prolonged the prosperity streak farmers enjoyed
Description: The seven year streak of record grain prices and climbing land values has taken a turn as grain prices come down, but drought prolonged the streak, said the president-elect of the Iowa Pork Producers Association.  Net farm income has been at record levels in recent years.  Chad Hart, an economist with Iowa State University, agreed that the prosperity would have ended in 2012 had it not been for the drought buoying grain prices as demand exceeded grain supply, driven by ethanol production and exports of grain and livestock.  Lower grain prices will bring a readjustment of the cost curve, said the director of market development for the Iowa Soybean Association, bringing down prices for farmland rent, seed, fertilizer and other chemicals.  This will be a challenging season of adjustment for farmers.  Sioux City Journal (Iowa), Sept. 29, 2013

Title: Cattle producers suffering in Arkansas
Description: Many Arkansas cattle producers had to use winter feed supplies and were purchasing corn at more than three times the going price three months ago as drought affected corn supplies and prices, according to an extension economist and professor with the University of Arkansas’ Division of Agriculture Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness and the secretary of the state’s Department of Agriculture.  Ranchers were struggling particularly along the Arkansas River and in the northern part of the state and were resorting to selling cattle, even their breeding stock.  Pastures were dry; hay did not grow; and water supplies were low.  At least 30,000 more livestock have been sold this year than last year at this time.  Fort Smith Southwest Times Record (Ark.), Aug. 13, 2012

Title: Drought in 2012 tripled the number of West Nile cases in Iowa
Description: There were 31 cases of West Nile virus in Iowa in 2012, three times higher than an average year.  An epidemiologist with the Iowa Department of Public Health attributed the uptick in West Nile cases to drought, which is preferred by the mosquito species that carries the virus.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), June 21, 2013

Title: Drought caused $974,548,606 in agricultural losses in Texas in 2012
Description: Drought caused $974,548,606 in agricultural losses in Texas in 2012, according to data from the Natural Resources Defense Council, and ranked 10th for the most crop losses from drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Sept. 1, 2013

Title: Eighty-one municipal water systems in Nebraska experienced drought-related supply problems in 2012
Description: Eighty-one municipal water systems in Nebraska experienced drought-related supply problems in 2012, stated the Department of Health and Human Service staff member who monitors municipal water systems.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Nov. 30, 2012

Title: Members of the Nebraska Farm Business Inc. see income disparities in 2012
Description: Drought caused quite a disparity among Nebraska Farm Business Inc. members' incomes in 2012.  The net farm income for the top 15 percent of analyzed farms was $750,000 or greater, while farm income was negative for the bottom 15 percent of farms.  Having irrigation made a big positive difference for farmers, and those with livestock struggled.  Overall, the net farm income in 2012 was the second highest ever in Nebraska.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), May 19, 2013

Title: California farmers pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought
Description: California farmers were pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought and were using hundreds of millions of dollars more electricity than normal to power the pumps.   The co-owner of a ranch northwest of Fresno reported that their power use was two and a half times higher than normal.  In response to the higher demand for electricity, utilities were building new transmission lines and substations to support the additional electricity.  In the Central Valley, farmers may use groundwater to meet more than 60 percent of their irrigation needs in 2015, one-third more than a normal year, said a senior researcher at the University of California at Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.  At that rate, electric bills would rise 77 percent, or $600 million, compared to a year with normal precipitation.  The amount of energy needed to pump groundwater was up 90 megawatt-hours, said the senior vice president of regulatory affairs for Southern California Edison Co., a subsidiary of Edison International.   The utility built the $190 million San Joaquin Cross Valley Loop transmission project in November to meet farmers’ increased need for electricity. Pacific Gas & Electric Co. has proposed a 230-kilovolt transmission line through the Central Valley where power demand for groundwater pumping rose about 40 percent over the average levels for 2008 to 2011.The Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Irrigation brought in $11 billion to Nebraska's economy in 2012
Description: Nebraska farmers’ irrigation capability brought $11 billion into the state’s economy in 2012, according to figures released by the Nebraska Farm Bureau, which wanted to evaluate the importance of irrigation to the state during drought.  The study gives an estimate of irrigated agriculture’s total effect on the Nebraska economy in 2012 and made the estimates by comparing the economic activity of farmers and ranchers with and without irrigation capabilities in 2012.  The study also found that having irrigation encouraged employment numbers and that not having irrigation would have meant the elimination of 31,221 jobs, with more than one-third of those jobs not directly related to crop production, such as real estate, food service, wholesale trade businesses and other areas. Using data from the U.S. Geological Service for 2012 and results from the irrigation study, it was determined that each inch of water put on Nebraska cropland creates about $100 in economic benefit.  Decision Innovation Solutions, based in Des Moines, Iowa, performed the study.  Kearney Hub (Neb.), July 24, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought and high temperatures exacerbated South Dakota’s fire season
Description: Drought and high temperatures exacerbated South Dakota’s fire season, leading to 1,113 wildfires that consumed more than 103,000 acres so far in 2012, compared to 2011 when just 631 fires burned 65,000 acres.  The uptick in wildfires has also cost roughly $4.5 million--nearly five times as much as it cost to extinguish wildfires in 2011—and has strained the budgets of many fire departments.  Much of the increase in firefighting expenses came from the use of aircraft, which was needed to bring even small fires under control because the fire danger was so high from drought.  The Custer Volunteer Fire Department received 30 percent more calls than last year.  Rapid City Journal (South Dakota), Oct. 28, 2012

Title: Poor crop production in Indiana in 2012 left about 30 percent of the state's grain storage capacity unused
Description: Indiana has the capacity to store nearly 1.3 billion bushels of grain, but poor production in 2012, due to drought, left about 30 percent of that capacity unused, according to estimates by Perdue University.  Imperial Valley News (El Centro, Calif.), Oct. 25, 2013

Title: Roughly $1.36 billion in crop insurance claims to go to Kansas farmers for drought-induced crop losses in 2012
Description: Roughly $1.36 billion in crop insurance claims will go to Kansas farmers for drought-induced crop losses in 2012.  About $724 million was for lost corn production, $247 million for grain sorghum, $213 million for soybeans and nearly $162 million for lost wheat production.  Payouts were also made on barley, canola, cotton, dry beans, millet, oats, pasture, potatoes, silage sorghum and sunflowers.  Losses in Shawnee County on mainly corn production amounted to $5.9 million.  In 2011, Kansas farmers received $1.08 billion in crop insurance payments after a dry year, considerably more than the payments of $142 million in 2010 and $291 million in 2009.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), March 26, 2013

Title: Dearth of mature Christmas trees on Nebraska tree farms
Description: The 2012 drought cost Nebraska farmers thousands of Christmas trees as 75 to 80 percent of newly planted trees died, according to Les Korte, president of the Nebraska Christmas Tree Growers Association.  A tree grower in Crete in southeast Nebraska lost more than 1,800 trees in 2012.  Given that it takes years for a tree to reach full size, the drought effect manifests itself years down the road, leaving a shortage of mature trees in 2018.KOLN-TV CBS 10/KGIN-TV CBS 11 Lincoln-Grand Island (Neb.), Nov. 27,  2018
Places: Nebraska, Lancaster County, NE, Hallam, NE, Saline County, NE, Crete, NE

Title: Campfires were prohibited in all Arizona state parks, Game & Fish wildlife areas, state trust land
Description: Campfires were prohibited in all Arizona state parks, Game & Fish wildlife areas, state trust land and all but parts of one national forest as officials try to squelch wildfires amid the low humidity, drought and heat.  Open fires in grills were still permitted at some campgrounds on U.S. Bureau of Land Management acres.  In the Grand Canyon, all campfires were banned except along the Colorado River.  Nearly 75,000 acres have burned in the state since the start of 2012.  Tucson Arizona Daily Star (Ariz.), June 23, 2012

Title: The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimated that drought reduced the crop yield in Wisconsin by 11 percent or more
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimated that drought reduced the crop yield in Wisconsin by 11 percent or more, compared to last year.  The state corn harvest was expected to be 431 million bushels or 17 percent below last year, with yields of 125 bushels per acre, compared to yields of 156 bushels per acre in 2011.  The soybean crop was anticipated to reach 66.3 million bushels or 11 percent less than in 2011.   Beloit Daily News (Wis.), Nov. 15, 2012

Title: Drought damaged Nebraska pastures in 2012 and ended production before the growing season would have otherwise ended
Description: Drought damaged Nebraska pastures in 2012 and ended production before the growing season would have otherwise ended.  As a result, pastures may be slow to green up and be less productive than usual in 2013. An alfalfa grower near Loomis reported that his field produced less tonnage in 2012 than usual, but the quality was good.  Meanwhile, one of his small irrigated alfalfa fields went unharvested because it did not produce much at all.  Scottsbluff Star Herald (Neb.), Feb. 6, 2013

Title: Drought devastated 46.2 percent of the corn crop and 30.9 percent of the soybean crop in Missouri in 2012
Description: Drought devastated 46.2 percent of the corn crop and 30.9 percent of the soybean crop in Missouri in 2012.  The crop losses represented the third largest soybean loss and the biggest corn loss in 60 years.  Columbia Missourian (Mo.), Feb. 10, 2013

Title: Colorado had one of its worst fire seasons in 2012
Description: Colorado had one of its worst fire seasons in 2012, a year of intense drought, when 4,167 wildland fires burned at least 648 structures, killed six people and charred more than 384,803 acres, resulting in property losses of $538 million, according to a report issued by the Colorado Division of Fire Prevention and Control.  Denver Post (Colo.), March 20, 2013

Title: At least 30,000 more cattle were sold at auction in Arkansas compared to 2011
Description: At least 30,000 more cattle were sold at auction in Arkansas than at this time last year, according to the director of the Arkansas Livestock and Poultry Commission.  Hay and pasture production was decimated and water was in short supply.  The poultry industry was not faring well either.  Fort Smith Southwest Times Record (Ark.), Aug. 13, 2012

Title: The Kansas big game program received 1,200 reports about whitetail deer affected by a hemorrhagic disease in 2012
Description: The Kansas big game program received 1,200 reports of whitetail deer becoming ill or dying from a hemorrhagic disease in 2012, according to the program coordinator.  Many of these reports came from eastern Kansas.  Biting midges that transmit the disease claim more victims in drought years when animals congregate around fewer water sources.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), April 27, 2013Epizootic hemorrhagic disease claimed about 400 deer in Kansas, according to a spokesman for the state Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourism.  Dozens of affected deer were in Douglas and Franklin counties.  Biting midges that transmit the disease claim more victims in drought years when animals congregate around fewer water sources.  KSAL-AM (Salina, Kan.), Nov. 19, 2012
Places: Kansas, Douglas County, KS, Franklin County, KS

Title: Drought lowered Iowa’s farm income to $9.3 billion in 2012
Description: Drought lowered Iowa’s farm income by about 15 percent to $9.3 billion in 2012, compared to record high farm income the previous year at $11 billion.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Dec. 8, 2013

Title: Number of mosquitoes carrying West Nile virus at an all-time high in California
Description: Nearly 800 Californians were infected with the West Nile virus in 2014, the worst outbreak in a decade.  Drought was blamed for the record number of cases, and 2015 is expected to bring more of the same.  The virus is mainly spread by mosquitoes that feed on infected birds and transmit the virus to humans.  Many people suffer no ill effects from the virus, while others become extremely sick and even die.When the California drought began in 2012, the number of West Nile virus cases rose to 479 from 158 the previous year.  In 2014, 798 cases were recorded, the highest number since 2005, said the California Department of Public Health.  Twenty-nine people died.  Experts attribute the elevated West Nile activity to stagnant water and water sources in populated areas bringing the virus closer to people.  The virus activity was most intense in Southern California, and especially in Orange County where 266 human cases were reported and the highest rate of infected mosquitoes was found. Water conservation measures prevented the county from flushing its underground storm drains where mosquitoes flourished.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2015The number of California mosquitoes infected with the West Nile virus has risen to record heights this year, according to the California Department of Public Health. Santa Clara County has been a hot spot for birds carrying the West Nile virus, with more than one-third of the total affected birds statewide being found there.  Health departments in Santa Clara, Alameda and Contra Costa counties have been taking measures to reduce the number mosquitoes with the West Nile virus since mosquitoes transmit the disease to birds. The Santa Clara County Vector Control District found that 1 in 20 mosquitoes were infected with the West Nile virus this summer.  Eighty of Alameda County’s 92 West Nile-positive birds were found in Livermore, leading health officials to pull out the stops to eradicate the mosquitoes.Throughout California, there have been 562 human cases of West Nile reported through Oct. 21, more than twice the count at this time in 2013.  Seventeen deaths have been related to the virus since the start of the year, compared with 15 deaths in all of 2013.  Five human cases leading to the neural-invasive type of complication were confirmed in Contra Costa County.  A dozen people in Santa Clara County contracted the virus, with four being hospitalized also with neural-invasive complications.Public health officials say the uptick in West Nile virus cases could be attributed to climate, the number and types of birds and mosquitoes in an area, birds’ immune systems and drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 19, 2014The number of mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus was at an all-time high, said state health officials.  Since the start of the year, 181 cases of West Nile virus were reported to the California Department of Public Health, and eight people have died.  During the last week alone, 52 new cases were reported.  A state public health official said drought may be contributing to the spread of the virus via birds and mosquitoes. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 4, 2014
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Dryland hay production was down drastically in Montana in 2012
Description: Dryland hay production was down drastically in Montana in 2012, stated a hay grower near Fromberg.  That winter farmers went to Canada for hay to get their livestock through the winter.  Butte Montana Standard (Mont.), Aug. 11, 2013

Title: Drought losses in Oklahoma reached $426 million in 2012
Description: Crops, livestock, wildfire property losses and municipals cost were all figured into the roughly $426,125,520 in drought-related losses for Oklahoma 2012.  The losses for crops, including hay, alfalfa, soybeans, cotton and grain sorghum were $239,299,520; livestock losses, including lost pasture production and fewer winter stockers were $157,109,000; wildfire property losses amounted to $27,299,000; and drought cost municipalities $2,418,000.  KOSU-FM Oklahoma Public Radio (Okla.), Dec. 5, 2012

Title: Drought reduced corn and soybean production in South Dakota
Description: Drought reduced South Dakota corn and soybean production by 18 and 6 percent, respectively, compared to production in 2011.  Corn and soybean growers in South Dakota harvested 535.5 million bushels of corn and 141.3 million bushels of soybeans.  Drought also limited hay, sorghum and millet production.  Rapid City Journal (S.D.), Jan. 15, 2013

Title: California utility customers paid $1.4 billion more for alternate energy sources
Description: The nonprofit Pacific Institute think tank in Oakland, California investigated hydropower production and found that during the past three years, declining hydropower production in California cost utility customers an estimated $1.4 billion as power from alternate sources, such as natural gas-fired plants, was purchased to compensate for reduced hydroelectric production.  The greater use of fossil fuels also drove California carbon dioxide emissions up 8 percent.Municipal and agricultural water users in the West have priority over power production when water is short.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 21, 2015
Categories: Energy, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Livestock producers running short of feed, water in Utah
Description: Livestock producers are running short of feed because of limited rainfall, hot temperatures, and a lot of wind this year.Some cattlemen have moved off summer ranges and have put their cattle on fall/winter-type pastures.Livestock water has also dried up so they either have to haul water or move the livestock.  A range fire burned several thousand acres last week and was started by dry lightning.From James Hall, USDA, in Tremonton, Utah, on July 30, 2013

Title: Drought cut into hydropower production in California, driving energy costs higher
Description: Drought has cut into hydropower production in California, driving energy costs higher as the state turns to other energy sources, which cost more than cheap, clean hydropower does.  Hydropower generation dropped from 18.2 percent in 2011 to 11.7 percent in 2012 when drought began.Despite years of decreases in greenhouse gas emissions since 2004, California’s emissions began to rise in 2012, due to drought and the closing of the San Onofre nuclear plant in San Diego County.  Emissions data for 2013 were not yet available.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 20, 2014

Title: Hotter, drier summers increasing tree mortality in Oregon
Description: Many Douglas firs and grand firs in Oregon were declining amid the region’s hotter, drier summers.  Drought may be responsible for declines in Western red cedar and bigleaf maple also.  The tree deaths were particularly noticeable in the hills when traveling along Interstate 5.Oregon’s Doug firs began declining in 2012 during drought.  Deaths were first noted in the driest areas, such as south-facing sites, ridges and rocky areas.  Drought still persisted, and tree deaths remained higher than the historical average.Salem Statesman-Journal (Ore.), July 22, 2019
Places: Oregon, Benton County, OR, Clackamas County, OR, Lane County, OR, Linn County, OR, Marion County, OR, Multnomah County, OR, Polk County, OR, Washington County, OR, Yamhill County, OR

Title: Drought reduced Nebraska’s corn production in 2012 for a loss of nearly $240 million
Description: Drought reduced Nebraska’s corn production by 18 to 22 percent in 2012, stated the director of research for the Nebraska Corn Board, for a loss of roughly $240 million.  The state produced 1.4 to 1.5 million bushels on average over the last ten years, he said, but is expected to harvest about 1.3 million bushels this year.  Dryland farmers found that their efforts did not yield much with the drought and heat.  A dryland farmer in southwestern Nebraska said his corn was a total loss.  Another dryland farmer northeast of Lincoln said his yield was 90 bushels per acre, which is a little more than half of the usual yield.  Ninety-one to 92 percent of the corn crop was harvested in 2012, in comparison with an average harvest of 97 percent of the acres planted.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Dec. 5, 2012

Title: 2012 among most destructive wildfire seasons in Wyoming
Description: Hot, dry weather in 2012 led to one of Wyoming's most destructive fire seasons when up to 1,400 wildfires blackened about 560,000 acres, according to the state forester.  Only 75,000 acres typically burn annually in the state.  The cost of fighting the fires was about $100 million.The largest fire was the Arapaho Fire, burning about 98,000 acres in the Laramie Peak area and around the Medicine Bow National Forest in southeast Wyoming.The 2012 fire season was comparable to the 1988 fire season when the Yellowstone National Park wildfires scorched nearly 700,000 acres and consumed 75 homes and 60 outbuildings.Billings Gazette (Mont.), Aug. 25, 2014 and Wyoming Business News (Cheyenne), Feb. 18, 2021

Title: Iowa trees continue to manifest drought damage from 2012
Description: Iowa trees continue to manifest drought damage from 2012 that was not apparent until this spring.  A district forester with the Iowa department of Natural Resources said, “I've seen very mature 40- and 50-foot arbor vitae (evergreens) that are just dead brown.  Typically, a mature tree like that can survive a dry summer. That just kind of expresses the magnitude of just how bad things were."  Evergreen trees across Iowa sustained significant damage, notably in northeastern Iowa, where 30 to 50 percent of the arbor vitae died.  Some newly planted trees all died in 2012.  The next few weeks will reveal how many oaks, hickory and black walnut trees suffered damage or were killed by drought. Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier (Iowa), April 28, 2013

Title: Kansas did not use water from John Martin Reservoir in Bent County, Colorado
Description: The John Martin Reservoir in Bent County contained just 23,700 acre-feet of water, due to drought, although the maximum storage for recreation and conservation purposes is 344,000 acre-feet.  For the second year running, Kansas did not use any water from the reservoir, which was constructed to help Colorado and Kansas to share the water from the Arkansas River.  The low volume of water, dry conditions and the timing of flows kept Kansas from using the water.  Pueblo Chieftain (Colo.), Dec. 20, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: South Dakota's GDP up only 1.9 percent in 2012
Description: Drought took the wind out of South Dakota’s economic sails in 2012 as the preliminary estimate of the state’s gross domestic product was 1.9 percent, in comparison with an increase of 8.8 percent in 2011, according to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis.  South Dakota’s GDP was $42.5 billion in 2012.  Sioux Falls Argus Leader (S.D.), June 11, 2013

Title: Kansas pheasant population rebounding after drought
Description: Pheasant numbers were down for the 2012-13 and 2013-14 pheasant seasons, due to drought.  Consequently, hunting has been poor, but spring 2014 resulted in a boom of chicks and will boost the pheasant population.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), Jan. 10, 2015

Title: California bees lack the nectar to produce much honey
Description: The California drought has dried up native plants and wildflowers, whose nectar honeybees use to make honey.  Beekeepers must supplement the bees’ diets with sugar syrup to keep them alive and healthy until they can find enough nectar to eat and begin to produce honey again.Drought has cut California’s honey production by more than half, compared to annual averages before the drought.  In 2010, 27.5 million pounds of honey were produced in the state, and in 2013, the honey crop was 10.9 million pounds.  The 2014 honey crop is expected to be even lower than last year.The price of honey has climbed to record highs due to a worldwide shortage, and drought has only compounded the problem.  Since 2007, the average retail price for honey rose 65 percent from to $3.83 to $6.32 per pound, according to the National Honey Board.  ABC News, Aug. 21, 2014

Title: Drought, El Nino conditions improved water quality at Hawaii's beaches
Description: In Hawaii in 2012, there were only 736 water samples that exceeded the Environmental Protection Agency’s standards, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council’s Testing the Waters: A Guide to Water Quality at Vacation Beaches.  Of the 736 closings and advisories, 720 were from storm water runoff and 16 were from sewage leaks or spills.  Water quality in 2012 was better than 2011 because El Nino conditions limited rainfall, and drought reduced the amount of storm water runoff.  In 2011, there were 4,696 closing and advisory days; in 2010, there were 4,215; and in 2009, there were 2,352.  West Hawaii Today (Hawaii), June 27, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Agricultural water users in Wisconsin used more groundwater than municipalities in 2012
Description: Agricultural water users in Wisconsin used more groundwater than municipalities in 2012, according to the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources.  The DNR’s annual report stated that groundwater withdrawals for agricultural use increased 83 percent to 135.2 billion gallons in 2012, while municipal use in 2012 crept up just 2.6 percent.  Prior to 2012, municipalities were the largest users of groundwater, but drought drove more farmers to pump groundwater for irrigation.  Of the groundwater pumped in 2012, 46 percent was for farm irrigation and 34 percent was for municipalities.  In 2011, farms used 35 percent and municipalities used 42 percent.  Portage County used more groundwater than any other county in 2012 and increased its water use by 65 percent.  Adams County, the second largest groundwater user increased itswater use by 79 percent, while Waushara County, third largest user of groundwater, upped its water use by 68 percent.A groundwater expert at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point, noted that "these pumping statistics show we are in a scary situation in Wisconsin,” because streams and lakes shrunk or went dry during the drought, due to excessive groundwater pumping.  Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), Oct. 22, 2013

Title: The 2012 drought harmed many seedlings planted on Indiana tree farms
Description: The 2012 drought harmed many seedlings planted on Indiana tree farms.  Terre Haute Tribune-Star (Ind.), Nov. 30, 2013

Title: The hot, dry summer of 2012 resulted in Tennessee Christmas tree growers losing up to 80 percent of trees planted this year and up to 20 percent of older trees, according to the state Department of Ag
Description: The hot, dry summer of 2012 resulted in Tennessee Christmas tree growers losing up to 80 percent of trees planted this year and up to 20 percent of older trees, according to the state Department of Agriculture.   One tree farm owner in Clarksville said that about half of his 400 trees died.  A tree farm in Gallatin lost every tree planted there this year.  Clarksville Leaf-Chronicle (Tenn.), Dec. 5, 2012

Title: Dry conditions increased fire activity in Florida
Description: There were 512 wildfires that scorched 6,759 acres reported across Florida since the start of 2012, according to the Florida Forest Service.  Forty-three of the fires continue to burn.  Three of the active fires were in Clay County.  Jacksonville Times-Union & Jacksonville.com (Fla.), Feb. 9, 2012

Title: Dry weather in 2012 caused an unusually high number of deaths among adult pheasants in South Dakota
Description: The director of the South Dakota Game, Fish & Parks Wildlife Division stated the dry weather in 2012 caused an unusually high number of deaths among adult pheasants.  Hunters shot 1.4 million pheasants in South Dakota in 2012, which was lower than the 10-year average of 1.8 million and the 20-year average of 1.53 million birds, according to state Game, Fish & Parks Department.  Rapid City Journal (S.D.), April 17, 2013

Title: USDA Designates 62 Counties in Colorado as Primary Natural Disaster Areas
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) on July 3, 2012, designated all counties in Colorado except for Delta and San Juan as primary natural disaster areas due to damage and losses caused by drought, excessive heat and high winds that began Jan. 1. Although Delta and San Juan counties were not listed as primary natural disaster areas, farmers and ranchers in those counties qualified for natural disaster assistance because the counties are contiguous. All counties were designated natural disaster areas July 3, 2012, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met. USDA press release 0070.12, July 3, 2012

Title: South Dakota received an unusually high number of applications for irrigation permits in 2012
Description: South Dakota received the highest number of applications for irrigation permits in 2012 since the 1970s, according to Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) staffers.  Through Nov. 26, the DENR has granted 113 irrigation permits and was still reviewing 91 applications.  Last year, the DENR issued 62 permits and issued 43 permits in 2010.  Demand for irrigation was very high in the 1970s; the state issued 271 irrigation permits in 1975, 551 permits in 1976 when there was drought, 524 permits in 1977 and 104 permits in 1978.
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Nearly 100 dairies closed in Missouri during 2012
Description: Nearly 100 dairies closed in Missouri during 2012, due to severe drought conditions, according to Dave Drennan, executive director of the Missouri Dairy Association.Columbia Missourian (Mo.), Sept. 9, 2014

Title: Utah experienced more than 1,000 wildfires with fire suppression expenses reaching $16 million through mid-August
Description: Utah experienced more than 1,000 wildfires with fire suppression expenses reaching $16 million through mid-August, reported the Associated Press.  Drought sparked an exceptional fire season for the West, while the U.S. saw its third worst fire season on record.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Dec. 13, 2012

Title: Crop insurance payments climbed to $1 billion in Indiana
Description: Crop insurance payments for corn, soybean and wheat losses in Indiana climbed to an all-time high of $1 billion.  The previous high occurred in 2008 when farmers received $522 million in crop insurance payments.  The average corn yield in the state in 2012 was 99 bushels per acre, which is nearly 40 percent below average.  Roughly 75 percent of the corn crop was insured in 2012.  Claims were still coming in, so the figure will rise further before the final tally is made for 2012.  WFIE-TV NBC 14 Evansville (Ind.), March 12, 2013

Title: Record wildfire season in Nebraska
Description: Wildfires in Nebraska consumed more than 400,000 acres, or about 620 square miles, in 2012, for the most destructive wildfire season on record, according to the fire program leader for the Nebraska Forest Service.  A meteorologist for the National Weather Service in North Platte said that strong winds, extreme high temperatures, exceptionally low humidity and drought all contributed to the bad fire season.  Omaha World-Herald (Neb.), March 26, 2013Nebraska endured 1,205 wildfires that consumed more than 343,000 acres since the start of the year, stated the assistant director of the Nebraska Emergency Management Agency.  Drought and heat increased the fire activity, which affected all counties in the state.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Nov. 30, 2012

Title: High number of new irrigation wells registered with the Nebraska Department of Natural Resources in 2012
Description: There were 1,105 new irrigation wells were registered with the Nebraska Department of Natural Resources in 2012.  The number of new wells has not exceed 1,000 since 2005.  KCSR-AM (Chadron, Neb.), Feb. 22, 2013

Title: Recreational shooting sparking fires in Utah
Description: Recreational shooting sparked 19 wildfires in Utah since the start of 2012, with yet another three months to go in the dry season.  Twenty-four wildfires were caused by guns in 2011 and 20 fires in 2010.  While cities can restrict particular types of ammunition and targets for safety, the state cannot do much to avert more such fires.Arizona Republic (Phoenix) & AZCentral.com, June 21, 2012

Title: Northern Idaho elk calf-cow ratios rising after drought, many other factors curbed it
Description: Low elk calf-cow ratios in northern Idaho stemmed from drought and many other factors, such as deteriorating habitat quality and predation by black bears and other animals. The low numbers in 2012 spurred the end of the general either-sex elk hunt.  The 2015 winter survey found a significant increase in elk calf-cow ratios, and the recovery continues.Spokane Spokesman-Review (Wash.), Feb. 10, 2015

Title: Drought led livestock owners in Montana to graze and hay 255,000 acres of land enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program
Description: Drought led livestock owners in Montana to graze 110,000 acres of land enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program and to hay 145,000 acres of CRP land, according to the administrator of the Montana Farm Service Agency.  Grand Forks Herald (N.D.), May 1, 2013
