Title: Farmers in South Dakota were eligible to receive $1 billion in crop insurance payments in 2012
Description: Farmers in South Dakota were eligible to receive $1 billion in crop insurance payments in 2012, according to an economics professor at South Dakota State University.  Strong crop prices boosted the insurance payments, which were about twice the amount paid in 2011.  Sioux Falls Argus Leader (S.D.), March 28, 2013

Title: Drought reduced California's hydropower production
Description: The recent years of drought caused a significant lull in hydropower production, but the unusually snowy 2016-17 winter refilled reservoirs and promised to bring plenty of hydropower, possibly as much as 21 percent of the state’s total electricity output, according to the California Energy Commission.  Fifteen to 18 percent of California’s electricity generation typically comes from hydropower, according to Peter Gleick of the Pacific Institute, but during the drought, hydropower generation dropped to less than 10 percent on average.  The state turned to burning natural gas to make up the difference, driving up greenhouse gas emissions by 10 percent over what they would have been.  Burning natural gas also cost Californians $2.4 billion more than they would have paid if hydropower production had been near normal.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 20, 2017
Categories: Energy, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Imperial County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Corn farmers in Iowa received more than $1 billion in crop indemnities in 2012
Description: Corn farmers in Iowa received more than $1 billion in crop indemnities from the U.S. Department of Agriculture after drought ravaged the corn crop in 2012.  Corn production amounted to 1.87 billion bushels, in comparison with 2.36 billion bushels last year.  The average yield was 137 bushels per acre, down from 172 bushels per acre last year.  The soybean yield was 43 bushels per acre, down from the average 51.5 bushels per acre.  Total soybean production in the state was 415 billion bushels in 2012, lower than the 475 billion bushels grown in 2011.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Jan. 12, 2013

Title: Drought, other factors hurt livestock industry in South Dakota
Description: A study evaluating the effects of drought and other factors on the livestock industry in South Dakota found that high feed prices played a large role in the profitability of livestock in 2012.  The average dairy herd in the program lost $398 per cow in 2012, on the heels of gains of $707 per cow in 2011.  One hundred participants shared their experiences with the South Dakota Center for Farm/Ranch Business Management, which performed the study.  Cow-calf operations lost an average of $27.05 per cow in 2012, in comparison with a gain of $88.34 per cow in 2011.  Net returns at beef finishing feedlots fell in 2012 because some operations struggled to control costs and choose suitable alternative feeds.  Rapid City Journal (S.D.), April 28, 2013

Title: Drought put a dent in Nebraska’s agricultural output in 2012
Description: Drought put a dent in Nebraska’s agricultural output in 2012.  Hay production was 28 percent lower in 2012 than in 2011, corn production dropped by 16 percent, while soybean production fell by 21 percent.  In addition, drought increased the fire danger, leading to a busy wildfire season with fire burning more than 100,000 acres of pasture and rangeland.  A Dec. 30 report from the National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) revealed that 14 percent of the winter wheat was rated good to excellent, much lower than the 74 percent in the same categories a year ago.  The average hay price in Nebraska had nearly double from $120 per ton in 2011 to $211 per ton at the end of 2012, according to NASS.  Grand Island Independent (Neb.), Jan. 24, 2013

Title: Fewer marijuana plants seized in Utah in 2012
Description: Marijuana growers in Utah struggled to produce their crop during a drought year, leaving the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency to seize just 13,167 pot plants, which was less than 20 percent of the number of plants found last year.  Salt Lake Tribune (Utah), Nov. 1, 2012

Title: Increased fire activity in Maine blamed on warm, dry weather
Description: Since the start of 2012, 229 wildfires burned 270 acres in Maine.  In comparison, 76 fires had charred 45 acres by this time in 2011.  Warm, dry weather was blamed for the uptick in fires.  Portland Press Herald (Maine), April 19, 2012

Title: Texas drought led to mistletoe shortage
Description: A florist shop in Excelsior did not carry mistletoe this year because drought in Texas reduced the crop and lowered the quality of the mistletoe.  Two local rotary clubs had to make alternate plans for their mistletoe sale to raise money for a food bank.  Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Dec. 13, 2011

Title: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department aiming to raise $4.6 million through donations from public in effort to keep parks open
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department was aiming to raise $4.6 million through donations from the public in an effort to keep parks open, according to a series of news conferences held on December 6.  The parks service hoped to make up $3 million in lost visitation and $1.6 million in projected revenue from donations offered while renewing vehicle registrations. Since park visitations have been down due to drought and heat, the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department received roughly $1.2 million less in entrance and use fees in the 2011 fiscal year compared to the previous year, while revenue was already $2 million below projected levels for this fiscal year.  The state parks system gets half of its annual $69 million needed to cover operating expenses from the state and half from visitors fees.  Amarillo Globe News (Texas), Dec. 6, 2011

Title: Thousands of horses and donkeys abandoned across Texas
Description: Thousands of horses and donkeys continue to be abandoned across Texas as the scarcity and high cost of hay has made it difficult to care for the animals, according to a horse specialist with Texas A&M University.  Drought has driven hay and feed prices to new highs and dried up pastures, leaving many animal owners to try to sell, but there just isn’t a market for horses or donkeys.  Since many ranchers have sold livestock, even fewer horses are needed to ride to check on the cattle.  Texas ranchers have been able to purchase hay from Oregon and Idaho, but supplies were dwindling there, too.  Allentown Morning Call (Pa.), Dec. 3, 2011

Title: Visitation to Colorado Ski Country's 22 member resorts down by 7.4 percent
Description: The dearth of snow this winter contributed to the drop in visitation to Colorado Ski Country’s 22 member resorts by 7.4 percent through the end of February.  Denver Post (Colo.), March 17, 2012

Title: Meager snowfall cut into visitation to Vail Resorts’ four ski areas in Colorado by 8.8 percent
Description: The meager snowfall cut into visitation to Vail Resorts’ four ski areas by 8.8 percent through the end of January.  Denver Post (Colo.), March 17, 2012

Title: Long-term drought still affecting water supplies in Texas
Description: Precipitation in December only managed to put a dent in the ongoing drought for the entire state even though most cities received above normal precipitation for the month. ... Water supply levels continued to decrease and values were exceptionally low in the High Plains and Trans Pecos regions, according to the Texas Water Development Board. Overall there are 999 public water systems that are asking their customers to restrict water use, compared to 1,004 a month ago. Of these systems, 646 are asking customers to follow a mandatory watering schedule and 353 are asking customers to follow a voluntary watering schedule. There are 51 public water systems that have restricted all outside watering, compared to 53 a month ago. The availability of unappropriated water for new water use permits continues to decrease in all river basins in the State, and the search for long-term, dependable alternate sources of water remains a high priority issue.Texas Statewide Drought Situation Report, Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Lack of snow cover prolongs occurrences of grass fires in South Dakota
Description: Various agencies continue to deal with periodic grass fires well into December, which is very unusual. The lack of snow cover and months of dry conditions, as well as periods of above-normal temperatures, have allowed for fire activity to persist well into December. As of December 18th, the only parts of the area with snow cover (excluding the Black Hills) are across the far northeast tip of South Dakota and eastward into west central Minnesota. A small section of north central South Dakota also has light snow cover. Therefore, grass fires are still possible until a persistent snow cover establishes itself over the region.NWS - Drought Information Statement - Aberdeen, South Dakota - December 22, 2011

Title: Christmas tree growers in Iowa have struggled against drought, disease and hungry deer
Description: Christmas tree growers in Iowa have struggled against drought, disease and hungry deer, all of which have harmed young trees in recent years.  The owner of a Christmas tree farm in Maxwell lost many saplings to drought in 2012 and lost 35 percent of her new white pine plantings during the summer of 2013.  The Charlotte Observer (N.C.), Nov. 30, 2013

Title: Blue Bell Creameries in Brenham, Texas made less butter pecan ice cream because drought reduced pecan production in Texas
Description: Blue Bell Creameries made less butter pecan ice cream because drought reduced pecan production in Texas and drove up prices for the nuts, according to the company spokesman.  The business did not want to compromise quality by using fewer nuts or smaller pieces.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 16, 2012

Title: Texas barbeque restaurant owner faced with rising beef prices
Description: Barbeque restaurant owners are faced with rising beef prices and are considering price increases on their menus.  One restaurant owner in Lockhart stated that briskets cost several dollars more than they did at this time last year.  KEYE-TV We are Austin.com (Texas), Nov. 16, 2011

Title: Amount of water stored in Colorado irrigation ditches at 88 percent of average
Description: The amount of water stored in Colorado irrigation ditches from November 15, 2011 through March 15, 2012 was just over 125,000 acre-feet or 4,000 acre-feet greater than last year, but still not much better than it was from 2002 – 2005 when the state endured a few years of drought.  Pueblo Chieftain (Colo.), March 22, 2012

Title: Fed cattle prices rose to a new high of $127 per hundredweight
Description: Fed cattle prices rose to a new high of $127 per hundredweight, according to a livestock economist with the Texas AgriLife Extension.  Two months ago, fed cattle sold for $113 per hundredweight.  One year ago, fed cattle sold for $98 per hundredweight.  Drought was one of several factors driving the price to record levels as producers sold many livestock early due to shortages of grazing, water and hay.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 15, 2011

Title: Better Business Bureaus in Texas receiving up to 75 percent more calls about foundation repairs
Description: Better Business Bureaus in Texas were receiving up to 75 percent more calls about foundation repairs than last year.  The bureau has since included cracking foundations to a number of problems that arise from drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Nov. 7, 2011

Title: Remaining cotton stalks a problem for Texas farmers
Description: Cotton did not grow well in many parts of Texas due to drought, which, in turn, was making it a challenge to grow follow-up crops because cotton stalks remained, particularly in east, central and south Texas.  The state cotton specialist stated that many farmers were having trouble with cotton stalks that were not easily controlled with tillage or herbicides, which are less effective during drought.  In some areas, such as Taylor and Jones counties, the dryland cotton did not germinate without moisture, so stalks were not a problem there.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Nov. 6, 2011

Title: Texas Drought Survival Kit
Description: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Department created a Drought Survival Kit with a multitude of tips to teach people how to help wildlife, manage their yards and lower their water bills during drought.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), Nov. 5, 2011

Title: Monarch butterflies scarce in Texas during fall migration
Description: Monarch butterflies were scarce in Texas this year when they should be flitting across the state on their annual fall migration to Mexico.  One invertebrate biologist with the Texas Parks & Wildlife Department in Austin reported seeing just four or so monarchs in the past three weeks.  It was thought that the reduction in flowers that provide nectar for the butterflies and many acres burned by wildfires resulted in a wide migration route, which could explain why monarchs were seen from the Davis Mountains in West Texas to the I-35 corridor, although they would normally fly a narrower route.  An entomologist who coordinates the Texas Monarch Watch, stemming from the monarch education and research organization in Kansas, was concerned about the number of dead plants, few butterflies and dying juniper in the Hill Country and noted that there was precious little to nourish the butterflies on their journey.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 2, 2011

Title: Planned power plants in Texas opposed over water supply concerns
Description: Energy projects across Texas were struggling to find water supplies and were finding themselves at odds with Texans over the water needed to operate the plants.  Groups concerned about the water supply were pushing government agencies to deny construction permits to potential power plants and were litigating to keep power plants out of some communities deemed to be short of water.  A study done by the University of Texas showed that 287 million gallons of water will be needed in 2020 to meet Texas’ electricity demand, which was roughly 100 billion gallons more than was needed in 2000, but the water demand already exceeds supply, according to a water expert who previously worked with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  There were nine coal-fired plants in the works across the state with 19 already in operation.  A power plant planned for Bay City lost support despite opting to install a cooling system that uses less water.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 2, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality

Title: One-fifth of Texas water systems have restrictions on water use
Description: There were 956 public water systems with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in Texas, according to a commissioner with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality who presented the status of Texas’ water systems to the Senate Natural Resources Committee.  Fifty-five systems did not allow any outdoor watering, while 23 water systems were so low that it was unclear how much water they had or had less than a six month supply.  Of the 175 major water supply reservoirs in the state, 109 contained less than 60 percent of capacity by late September.  The reservoirs have a combined capacity of 31.1 million acre feet, but hold only 18.8 million acre feet.  Water rights have been cut back in 1,005 instances, as those with senior water rights get priority over those with more recent water rights.  There are 4,721 community water systems in Texas.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 1, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: More than 4,000 people petitioned for use of National Guard, other Texas resources to transport hay
Description: Roughly 4,400 signatures were gathered to petition the governor of Texas to utilize the National Guard or other state resources to help transport hay to Texas livestock.  The chief executive of a nonprofit farm-animal rescue agency in Argyle started the petition.  The rising number of abandoned horses and donkeys across the state underscored the difficulty and expense of locating hay.  The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011

Title: Alabama cattleman purchased at least 1,600 head of cattle in Texas
Description: A livestock auction owner from Uniontown purchased at least 1,600 cows at cattle sales in drought-stricken Texas to bring back to Alabama.  The cost for each animal ranged from $650 to $1,200, which were very good prices.  Montgomery Advertiser (Ala.), Oct. 23, 2011

Title: Alfalfa hay costlier for dairy producers in New Mexico
Description: The cost of alfalfa rose from $145 to $150 per ton in 2010 to $300 to $310 per ton in 2011 because drought reduced the availability, according to the spokesman for the Dairy Farmers of America.  He said that there was no alfalfa hay left in New Mexico and that farmers were purchasing it from Canada.  The higher prices were making it difficult for dairy farmers to feed their livestock.  Clovis New Journal (N.M.), Oct. 20, 2011

Title: Louisiana officials want Army Corps of Engineers to consider the possibility of additional water releases from Felsenthal lock and dam near Crossett, Arkansas
Description: The governor of Louisiana requested that the Army Corps of Engineers release more water from the Felsenthal lock and dam near Crossett, Arkansas to boost the level of the Ouachita River for businesses and communities downstream in Louisiana.  The low water level has crimped normal activities because it limited the amount of wastewater that could be released into the river.  The chairman of the Coastal Protection and Restoration Authority of Louisiana wanted the corps to consider whether or not the Felsenthal pool could be lowered further in the event that more water was needed or that no rain falls before the end of 2011.  Monroe News-Star (La.), Oct. 19, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Ashley County, AR, Union County, AR, Louisiana

Title: Cattle watering holes drying up, fire danger risk high in many areas of Alabama
Description: Some local mandatory water restrictions remain in place, especially in some of the southeastern sections of central Alabama, with voluntary restrictions in other areas. The drier weather is hurting pasture growth and winter wheat planting in some parts of the area with some reports of cattle watering holes drying up in the worst drought areas. The fire danger risk across central Alabama remains high in many areas, especially in the southeast sections.

Title: Persistent drought continued to take its toll on Texas wildlife
Description: The persistent drought continued to take its toll on Texas wildlife as revealed in statewide wildlife surveys performed by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  No new fawns were found among 76 white-tailed deer in a 30-mile area in the Panhandle.  In the same area, only 3 quail were seen, where biologists would normally find 15.  Deer were dying from inadequate water supplies in South Texas, where 20 dead adult deer were found on one ranch.  Quail were not able to reproduce this year, according to the game bird program leader for Texas Parks and Wildlife.  In the northeastern Panhandle and north central Texas, the quail population was at historic lows, with a count of just 5 in areas where 21 were usually found.  Only one quail was found in a 20-mile radius in the Hill Country where 5 or more were normally found.  Six scaled quail were seen in the Trans Pecos region of West Texas where usually 16 or more birds would be found.  The antelope population in the Trans Pecos area has been suffering from a parasite for several years that has reduced the number of antelope.  Drought will likely further reduce antelope numbers.  A survey of antelopes in the northeastern Panhandle in June and July revealed 16 fawns among the 100 does, whereas there would usually be 35 fawns, indicating a fairly high mortality rate.  Antelope, deer and mule deer bucks may not fare well this breeding season because they use lots of energy and require adequate food to recover well afterward. Does were already doing poorly, which explains the meager fawn crops, which was as low as 27 percent in parts of the Southeast and Central Texas.  Ash juniper, which is drought-tolerant, was dying in the Hill Country.  The Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 13, 2011

Title: Reservoirs decreasing; drier weather hurting pasture growth and cattle watering holes in Alabama
Description: AREA RESERVOIR LEVELS ARE CONTINUING TO DECREASE AS WE HEAD FURTHER INTO FALL AND OPERATORS LOWER THEM FOR THE WINTER SEASON. AT THIS TIME THERE IS NOT A WIDESPREAD THREAT OF MUNICIPAL WATER SHORTAGES...BUT SOME LOCAL MANDATORY WATER RESTRICTIONS REMAIN IN PLACE...ESPECIALLY IN SOME OF THE SOUTHEASTERN SECTIONS OF CENTRAL ALABAMA...WITH VOLUNTARY RESTRICTIONS IN OTHER AREAS. THE DRIER WEATHER IS HURTING PASTURE GROWTH AND WINTER WHEAT PLANTING IN MANY PARTS OF THE AREA. LAST WEEK`S RAIN TEMPORARILY HELPED PASTURES IN SOME AREAS BUT MORE RAIN IS NEEDED. THERE HAVE BEEN SOME REPORTS OF CATTLE WATERING HOLES DRYING UP OR LOWERING IN THE WORST DROUGHT AREAS. THE PLANTING OF WINTER GRAZING IS BEING DELAYED IN SOME AREAS DUE TO THE DRY CONDITIONS. THE FIRE DANGER RISK ACROSS CENTRAL ALABAMA REMAINS HIGH IN MANY AREAS...ESPECIALLY IN THE SOUTHEAST SECTIONS.

Title: Burning permits cancelled in most western and northwestern Wisconsin counties
Description: Warm dry weather led to the cancellation of all burning permits in most counties in western and northwestern Wisconsin.  Eau Claire Leader-Telegram (Wis.), Oct. 11, 2011

Title: Texas bats altering behavior during drought
Description: Drought has reduced the food availability for bats in Texas, forcing them to emerge earlier in the evenings to search for food, which puts the bats in greater danger from predators, such as hawks, falcons, raccoons, owls and snakes.  More infant bats than usual were dying, suggesting that adult bats were not able to find enough food to supply themselves and their young.  The 20 million bats from the Bracken cave were coming out up to two hours before nightfall to travel greater distances to reach insects that inhabit corn and cotton plants.  The bats in Austin were emerging early, as well.  The 3 million bats in the Old Tunnel Wildlife Management Area near Fredericksburg normally take 40 to 60 minutes to fly out of the abandoned train tunnel, but presently take just six to 10 minutes to come out for the night.  The manager of the Old Tunnel Wildlife Management Area noted that the number of bats usually doubles in August as the young bats begin to fly, but the drastic change in the evening departures from the tunnel indicates that there are many fewer bats, meaning that many young probably did not survive.  The Houston urban biologist for the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department shared that she has noticed more dead baby bats on the ground and assumes that the adults don’t have enough to adequately feed their young.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Oct. 4, 2011
Places: Texas, Bracken, TX, Fredericksburg, TX, Houston, TX, Austin, TX

Title: Drought damaged spring wheat, slowed winter wheat planting in Montana
Description: Spring wheat growers in Montana noticed crop damage from drought and grasshoppers, according to the Montana Field Office of the National Agricultural Statistics Service.  Dry conditions also delayed the planting of the winter wheat crop.    Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Oct. 3, 2011

Title: Respiratory problems have arisen among cattle in dry, dusty parts of South Dakota
Description: Respiratory problems have arisen among cattle in dry, dusty parts of South Dakota.  Topsoil moisture ranged from very short to short in most parts of the state.  Sioux City Journal (S.D.), Oct. 3, 2011

Title: Drought interfered with cloud seeding project in Wyoming
Description: A research project by the Wyoming Water Development Office evaluating the effectiveness of cloud seeding over the mountains in Wyoming has been hindered by drought during two recent winters.  The drought limited the number of cloud seeding opportunities.  Roughly $13 million has been spent on the experiment since 2005.  Casper Star-Tribune (Wyo.), July 22, 2013

Title: Oklahoma leads nation in payments from United States Department of Agriculture’s Livestock Forage Disaster Program
Description: Livestock producers in Oklahoma, Texas, Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri altogether received over $2.7 billion in payments from the United States Department of Agriculture’s Livestock Forage Disaster Program for losses stemming from drought between Oct. 1, 2011 and Dec. 1, 2014.   Oklahoma led the pack with $883 million, Texas followed with $592.36 million, Nebraska got $512.89 million, Kansas received $461.26 million, and Missouri producers got $303.58 million.Oklahoma producers statewide received more than 70,000 payments.  Producers in northwestern and southwestern Oklahoma suffered the most since drought began in that part of the state in October 2010. Tulsa World (Okla.), Jan. 28, 2015

Title: Drought lowered revenue for Tyson Foods Inc.
Description: Tyson Foods Inc. revised downward its full-year sales forecast and noted that revenue would be lower for the year ending Sept. 30, 2012, from $34 billion to $33 billion after drought drove up animal feed costs. Arkansas Democrat-Gazette & Arkansas Online (Fayetteville, Ark.), Aug. 6, 2012
Places: Arkansas, Washington County, AR, Springdale, AR

Title: Food, water sparse for monarch butterflies migrating through Texas
Description: Monarch butterflies congregated along the Llano River and supped on the nectar from Frostweed, Water Hemlock, Swamp Milkweed, Goldenrod and Purple Mistflower since drought eliminated the usual fall flowers.  The journey across Texas is anticipated to be very challenging for the butterflies since food and water is difficult to find.  Less food will lower the butterflies’ fat reserves and jeopardize their survival this winter in Mexico.  The founder of Monarch Watch encouraged Texans to put out feeders containing Gatorade or Juicy Juice, small dishes of applesauce or slices of watermelon at flower level in their gardens to provide some sustenance for the butterflies as they travel south.  San Antonio Express-News (Texas), Sept. 29, 2011
Places: Texas, Kimble County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX

Title: Additional air tankers arrived in Austin to fight fires across Texas
Description: Two Canadian air tankers arrived in Austin from Saskatchewan on September 28 to support firefighting efforts across the state.  The airplanes came from Canada because there were not enough heavy air tankers in the U.S. to meet demand.  The Texas Forest Service fought 86 fires that scorched 4,698 acres in the past week.  12 News KBMT (Beaumont, Texas), Sept. 29, 2011

Title: Strain on rural Oklahoma fire departments led to new initiative for corporate donations
Description: The exceptional drought and high number of wildfires has depleted rural fire departments’ financial resources, leading corporations to donate to the fire departments to allow them to continue operating.  This practice led state Reps. Joe Dorman, D-Rush Springs, and Mike Sanders, R-Kingfisher to present a new initiative to allow funding to be directed through one of Oklahoma’s 11 regional councils to more easily get funding to rural fire departments during times of heightened demand.  Recently Apache Corp. donated $50,000 for rural fire departments after the fire at the wildlife preserve in Comanche County cost responding fire departments $25,000 in fuel alone.  Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), Sept. 27, 2011

Title: Texas ranchers downsizing during drought, according to survey
Description: The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association surveyed 8,995 ranchers and found that of the 872 respondents, 8 percent of them anticipated having no cattle in 2012, but intended to rebuild their herds in the future.  Sixteen percent of ranchers have not altered their herd sizes in response to drought, while 84 percent have culled some cattle compared to their three year average.  On average, ranchers downsized their herds by 38 percent.  The online survey was done in late August.  Nationwide, the cattle herd was the smallest it has been since the 1950s.  Lufkin News (Texas), Sept. 20, 2011

Title: Low alfalfa supply and production led to high alfalfa prices in Kansas
Description: Alfalfa supplies were low in Kansas, driving up prices to twice that of a year ago, leading alfalfa producers to keep the alfalfa hay for their own livestock rather than selling it to out of state buyers.  According to a market reporter with USDA/KDA Market News in Dodge City, the alfalfa supply was low at the beginning of the year.  There were 650,000 acres of alfalfa grown in 2010 and 850,000 acres in 2009, while the 10-year average was 950,000 acres.  Drought, combined with less alfalfa in cultivation, meant production was much lower than in previous years, which has driven up the price.  Ground and delivered alfalfa hay cost $240 to $250 per ton, compared to $115 to $130 per ton a year ago.  Top quality alfalfa hay cost as much as $300 per ton.  Salina Journal (Kan.), Sept. 19, 2011

Title: More available acreage for planting winter wheat in Kansas
Description: More acreage than usual was available for planting winter wheat in Kansas because drought caused many acres of corn and crops planted in the spring to fail, according to an extension wheat specialist at Kansas State University.  Many Kansas farmers desperately need a good crop to bring an income since recent crops have failed.  Good prices for wheat  also encourage additional wheat planting this fall, but the topsoil moisture was short across 70 percent of Kansas, reported the Kansas Agricultural Statistics Service.  Without enough soil moisture, the wheat may not germinate, possibly leading to another failed crop and more financial loss for Kansas farmers.  Salina Journal (KS), Sept. 13, 2011

Title: Most Georgia counties in drought disaster declaration
Description: One hundred fifty Georgia counties were declared to be drought disaster areas due to drought and heat.  Athens Banner-Herald (Ga.), Sept. 8, 2011

Title: Indiana soybeans damaged by drought
Description: Soybean plants in the southeastern part of Indiana were just shin high and had as few as five pods on them, according to an assistant professor of agronomy at Purdue University.  Soybeans in the northeast and central parts of the state also manifested damage from drought and heat.  Hoosier Ag Today (Ind.), Sept. 7, 2011

Title: Wildfires blaze in Bastrop County and throughout Texas
Description: A wind-driven wildfire that began September 4 burned 30,000 acres and nearly 600 homes in Bastrop County.  More than 5,000 people fled their homes.  Dozens of fires blazed in Texas on September 4 as strong winds from Tropical Storm Lee drove the fires across a parched landscape.  Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 6, 2011.  The Bastrop County fire ultimately burned more than 34,000 acres, ended two lives and destroyed 1,600 homes.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 15 and 26, 2011
Places: Texas, Bastrop County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Cass County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Harris County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Montague County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Travis County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Several oil and natural gas producers in Oklahoma sought alternative water sources
Description: Four oil and natural gas companies have had to seek alternative water sources when their original sources became depleted as drought persisted in Oklahoma.  Another well driller plans to construct a large pond near Geary or Calumet to hold 500,000 barrels worth of hydraulic fracturing water for reuse, which has never been done in Oklahoma.  Poten & Partners (N.Y.), Sept. 2, 2011

Title: Corn, soybean, hay yields down in Kansas
Description: Corn and soybean yields were down substantially in Kansas, according to a Wildcat District Extension agent.  Hay production was decreased by 30 to 40 percent in many areas, leading to a potential forage shortage this winter.  Ranchers began feeding hay three months early because there was no grass, but have less hay for the winter.  Pittsburg Morning Sun (Kan.), Oct. 25, 2011

Title: Water restrictions imposed in 856 Texas communities
Description: As of Sept. 1, 2011, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality reported there were 295 systems (190 ground water, 143 surface water) with voluntary restrictions in place, and 561 systems (442 ground water and 271 surface water) with mandatory restrictions in place. The total number of systems affected was 856, out of the 4,717 active community water systems in the state.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Ranchers sent 145,000 Texas cattle to better pasture in September 2011
Description: There were 140 percent more breeding cows or 145,000 head transported out of Texas to greener pastures in September 2011, compared with 2010, according to the Texas Animal Health Commission. An economist with the Texas AgriLife Extension Service estimated that by January 2012, roughly 12 percent of the state’s 5 million cattle will have been shipped, slaughtered or sold, dramatically reducing the number of cattle in Texas.  The Macon Telegraph (Ga.), Oct. 11, 2011

Title: Drought beneficial for reducing mosquito-borne illnesses in Texas
Description: Drought has diminished the mosquito population because there were fewer water sources for them to breed, noted the Nacogdoches Natural Resources Conservation District Conservationist.  As a result, there were fewer cases of mosquito-borne illnesses, such as encephalitis and West Nile virus, among humans or livestock.  Fewer mosquitoes can be beneficial to those who organize large outdoor events because they would not need the evaluation or services of an exterminator.  Drought can also present an opportune time to remove silt from stock ponds to allow more room for water when the rains do return.  KTRE (Lufkin, Texas), Aug. 31, 2011

Title: Texas drought affects revenue for water utilities
Description: Drought has impacted the revenue of many water utilities across the state as outdoor irrigation increases, boosting revenue, or stringent water restrictions cut into water use and lead to a decrease in revenue.  San Marcos, San Antonio, Odessa and Lubbock were enjoying higher than usual revenues.  Robert Lee, on the other hand, was experiencing an income drop of 40 percent since severe water restrictions were in effect because its reservoir was nearly dry.  Llano, too, had a 10 percent decline in revenue.  Soil dries and shifts during drought, spurring an increased number of water main breaks as has been seen in Houston and Austin.  These repairs can be expensive, costing up to $350 per foot to replace the line, according to the director of the Austin Water Utility.  Some communities were seeking new expensive water supplies.  The Colorado River Municipal Water District was constructing a pipeline at a cost of $142 million, while Amarillo spent more than $100 million to purchase groundwater.  KEYE-TV (Texas), Aug 30, 2011

Title: More snakes were seen throughout Oklahoma
Description: More snakes were seen throughout Oklahoma as drought drove them out in search of food and water, according to wildlife officials.  Residents were urged to keep their lawns cut short and remove brush piles to reduce the number of hiding places for snakes.  Norman Transcript (Okla.), Aug. 29, 2011

Title: Two men from Oklahoma created The Hay Connection on Facebook to connect hay buyers and sellers
Description: Two men from Oklahoma created The Hay Connection on Facebook to connect farmers with hay with others who need hay.  The site quickly accrued 7,500 fans.  Odessa American (Texas), Aug. 29, 2011

Title: Fewer flowers across Texas to nourish migrating hummingbirds
Description: There were fewer flowers across Texas to offer nourishment to migrating hummingbirds, prompting hummingbird aficionados to put out feeders to help the birds on their journey.  The drought threatens 18 species of hummingbirds as they fly through Texas on their way to Central America.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 28, 2011

Title: Hungry bears roving New Mexico in search of food
Description: Bears have been causing more problems around New Mexico as their search for scarce food brings them into contact with people.  A bear and her cub dropped in uninvited to a wedding at an upscale Taos resort two weeks ago.  A bear ate fruit from a tree in a Santa Fe neighborhood.  In Albuquerque, a bear was removed from a tree.  A bear visited the governor’s garbage cans earlier in the summer in search of a tasty morsel.  Drought has reduced the usual food supplies for bears, while wildfires have forced them to move to escape the fires.  The spokesman for the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish stated that 26 bears were trapped and relocated, while a record 147 bears were euthanized, 11 were killed by hunters and 17 bears were killed accidentally.  Scranton Times & Tribune (Pa.), Aug. 27, 2011

Title: Dryland cotton in Oklahoma devastated by drought
Description: Essentially all dryland cotton in Oklahoma has been so adversely affected by drought that it cannot produce a crop worth harvesting, according to the Oklahoma State University Research Director and Cotton Extension program leader.  Southwest Farm Press, Aug. 26, 2011

Title: South Dakota State University created a hay hotline
Description: South Dakota State University created a hay hotline to connect farmers in South Dakota with hay to ranchers and feed lots outside of the state who need hay.  The increased demand for hay caused the price to climb 25 percent above last year’s price.  KOTA-TV ABC 3 (S. D.), Aug. 25, 2011

Title: A farmer from Muscoda, Wisconsin spurred effort to collect hay for ranchers in Oklahoma
Description: A farmer from Muscoda headed up an effort to collect hay and share two semitrailers full of hay with ranchers in Oklahoma who needed the hay badly.  Milwaukee Journal Sentinel (Wis.), Aug. 25, 2011

Title: Drought and wildfires in New Mexico have increased number of animals needing and receiving care at the Wildlife Center in Arroyo Seco
Description: Drought and wildfires in New Mexico have increased the number of animals needing and receiving care at the Wildlife Center in Arroyo Seco.  Bears, fawns, coyotes, birds of prey and raccoons were among the animals being cared for at the center.  The executive director stated that one- and two-year old bears were having a particularly difficult time finding food and water and were barely surviving in the drought.  With the exceedingly dry conditions, it was not possible to relocate back into the wild, forcing the animals to stay longer at the center.  Santa Fe New Mexican (N.M.), Aug. 24, 2011

Title: Montana hay grower transporting hay to Texas
Description: A hay grower in Fromberg received about six telephone calls daily from Texas ranchers wanting hay since he had placed advertisements in Texas offering hay for sale.  The Montana man has three weeks’ worth of orders for hay to deliver to ranchers 1,400 miles away.  Billing Gazette (Mont.), Aug. 23, 2011

Title: Emergency water conservation implemented in Lafayette, Alabama
Description: Phase I emergency water conservation plan instituted for the city of Lafayette, AL in Chambers County. Lake reservoir level usually at 151 days useful reserve and now at 88 days. Full pool is about 5 feet and as of Friday lake level was at 3.2. Phase I includes: no hose washing of sidewalks, no filling of swimming pools/fountains, no washing of automobiles, no watering of lawn, turf or landscapes- no irrigation of crops.

Title: 796 Texas communities have restrictions on water use
Description: There were 796 communities in Texas with restrictions on water use, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  Of those, 506 had mandatory restrictions on water use.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 22, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas arranged for backup power supplies
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas asked two electricity providers to reactivate two natural gas units each to make sure that the state has sufficient electricity and can avoid more rotating power outages.  NRG Energy and Garland Power and Light are prepared to provide a total of 400 megawatts if and when needed through October 2011.  There is concern that there may be inadequate supplies of cooling water for power plants if drought and heat persist.  These reactivated units will only be used to prevent power outages and will not be used when there is an adequate power supply.  Pearland Journal (Texas), Aug. 16, 2011
Places: Texas, Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: High quality alfalfa selling for as much as $280 per ton in parts of Kansas
Description: The cost of hay in parts of Kansas has risen to $280 per ton for high quality alfalfa, according to the Kansas Hay Market Report which came out on August 16.  Poor quality hay or junk hay, used in rations, was even fetching $70 to $90 more per ton than it did a year ago.  Salina Journal (Kan.), Aug. 15, 2011

Title: Oklahoma 2011 Cotton Loss Estimated at $144 million
Description: 2011 OK Planted Acreage: 300,000 acres. 2011 OK Est. Harvest Acreage: 100,000 acres. 2011 OK Est. Yield: 408 pounds per acre. 2011 OK Est. Abandonment: 67 percent. 2011 OK Est. Production: 85,000 bales (41 million pounds). 2011 OK Est. Cotton Value: approx. $34 million (using last year’s price). 2010 OK Planted Acreage: 285,000 acres. 2010 OK Harvested Acreage: 270,000 acres. 2010 OK Yield: 750 pounds per acre. 2010 OK Abandonment: 5 percent. 2010 OK Production: 422,000 bales (203 million pounds). 2010 OK Cotton Value: approx. $169 million ($0.83 per pound). Comments: The estimated Oklahoma cotton value for 2011 is estimated using the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per bushel. Cotton prices have been running higher this year but have fallen in recent weeks. Early in the year, cotton was trading near $2 per pound, but in recent weeks the price has fallen to near $1. If Oklahoma had experienced a near-optimum year in 2011 (see 2010 for near-optimum results), the state could have achieved a production total of approximately 214 million pounds (446 thousand 480-pound bales). This is a rounded value assuming a 2011 optimum harvested acreage of 285,000 acres (5 percent abandonment) and an optimum yield of 750 pounds per acre. At the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per pound, this year’s Oklahoma crop had a potential value of $178 million. Given the 2011 estimated Oklahoma cotton value of approximately $34 million, it is fairly safe to say that the raw losses from this year’s Oklahoma cotton crop are in the ballpark of $144 million. -Brad Rippey, USDA

Title: Texas 2011 cotton losses estimated at $2.2 billion
Description: Estimated 2011 Cotton Losses for Texas 2011 TX Planted Acreage: 7.12 million acres. 2011 TX Est. Harvest Acreage: 3.40 million acres. 2011 Est. TX Yield: 635 pounds per acre. 2011 Est. TX Abandonment: 52 percent. 2011 Est. TX Production: 4.50 million 480-lb bales (2.16 billion lbs). 2011 Est. TX Cotton Value: approx. $1.8 billion (using last year’s price.) Contrast with 2010: 2010 TX Planted Acreage: 5.57 million acres. 2010 TX Harvested Acreage: 5.35 million acres. 2010 TX Yield: 703 pounds per acre. 2010 TX Abandonment: 4 percent. 2010 TX Production: 7.84 million 480-lb bales (3.76 billion lbs). 2010 TX Cotton Value: approx. $3.1 billion ($0.83 per pound). Comments: The estimated Texas cotton value for 2011 is estimated using the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per bushel. Cotton prices have been running higher this year but have fallen in recent weeks. Early in the year, cotton was trading near $2 per pound, but in recent weeks the price has fallen to near $1. If Texas had experienced a near-optimum year in 2011 (see 2010 for near-optimum results), the state could have achieved a production total of approximately 4.80 billion pounds (1.00 billion 480-pound bales). This is a rounded value assuming a 2011 optimum harvested acreage of 6.85 million acres (4 percent abandonment) and an optimum yield of 700 pounds per acre. At the 2010 U.S. cotton price of 83 cents per pound, this year’s Texas crop had a potential value of $4.0 billion. Given the 2011 estimated Texas cotton value of approximately $1.8 billion, it is fairly safe to say that the raw losses from this year’s cotton crop are in the ballpark of $2.2 billion. As an aside, the record-high cotton abandonment in Texas was set in 1998, with 42%. -Brad Rippey, USDA

Title: The governor  of Missouri requested that the Farm Service Agency begin damage assessments for crops, livestock
Description: The governor  of Missouri requested that the Farm Service Agency begin damage assessments for the entire state because heat and drought have hurt crop yields and stressed livestock.   Memphis Democrat (Mo.), Aug. 11, 2011

Title: 88 water systems in Oklahoma restrict use
Description: As of August 10, 2011, 88 water suppliers had reported to the Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality that they had imposed voluntary or mandatory water use restrictions. The Oklahoma DEQ is producing weekly updates on water systems with restrictions. A spokesman said nearly all restrictions are related to drought, either directly because of a lack of water, or indirectly due to line breaks from the ground shifting because it's so dry.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought could be having long-term impact on Texas wildlife
Description: The record-breaking drought in 2011 is endangering entire ecosystems across Texas. According to news reports, of the state's 3,700 streams, 15 major rivers and more than 200 reservoirs at least seven reservoirs are effectively empty and more than half of the streams and rivers are at below normal flow rates. Fish are among the first species to suffer, but the lack of water also affects plants, insects and other animals, including migratory birds, bats, song birds, antelope, deer, and predators. From the Associated Press, published by many media outlets in early August.

Title: Kansas officials open state lakes for water supply
Description: Drought conditions across Kansas have continued to worsen, prompting state officials to open up the use of state lakes as an emergency supply of water.From the Kansas Water Office August 15, 2011, Drought Update: Public Water Supply ConditionsA Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) for emergency use of state fishing lake water under conditions ofdrought emergency declared by the Governor is in place. This will allow small communities and individualswithin the emergency counties category to pump water from named state fishing lakes to provide some relief ifthey are in dire need of water. Individuals and communities need to contact the KWO for a water supplyrequest and they will in turn be referred to the appropriate Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourismoffice to obtain the necessary permit to withdraw the water. The MOU limits the types of water use and a feemay be set for use of the state fishing lakes’ water supply. The priority order established for this MOU isdomestic, municipal and then livestock uses, while also protecting the lake’s fish population.The State Fishing Lakes available for withdrawals for Emergency Declared counties include Atchison, Barber,Brown, Bourbon, Butler, Chase, Clark, Crawford, Goodman, Jewell, Kingman, Leavenworth, Lyon, Pott#1,Pott#2, McPherson, Miami, Mined Lands (Pits), Neosho, Osage, Ottawa, Saline, Scott, Shawnee, Sheridan,Washington, Wilson and Woodson Lakes.Additional water supply may also be available for Drought Emergency counties from federal lakes. Water fromU.S. Army Corps of Engineer lakes is available for domestic, industrial and livestock use but is prohibited forirrigation use. Requests from applicants have to go through the KWO or other appropriate State agency.Bureau of Reclamation lake water may be made available by temporary contract under drought conditions.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kansas, Allen County, KS, Anderson County, KS, Atchison County, KS, Barber County, KS, Barton County, KS, Bourbon County, KS, Brown County, KS, Butler County, KS, Chase County, KS, Chautauqua KS, Wichita County, KS, Wilson County, KS, Woodson County, KS, Wyandotte County, KS

Title: Fire restrictions in all Oklahoma counties
Description: The governor of Oklahoma issued an executive proclamation on August 3 which extended the burn ban to all of the 77 counties in the state.  Deteriorating drought conditions, heat and increased fire activity all indicated that fire restrictions were needed.  KOTV-TV CBS 6 Tulsa (Okla.), Aug. 3, 2011

Title: Dairy operations in Kansas counties searching for hay and feed
Description: More rain fell in Wichita last week than in the entire month of July. Dairy operations are searching for hay and feed. Irrigation pumps have not been shut off since they started in late May or early June.
Places: Kansas, Andover, KS, Augusta, KS, Sedgwick County, KS, Andale, KS, Colwich, KS, Goddard, KS, Maize, KS, Valley Center, KS, Wichita, KS

Title: Effects of 2011 Drought on Oklahoma Water Systems
Description: This summer ODEQ reinstituted and supplied the voluntary drought report online which was last needed in 1996. It is primarily a tool to help give the public an idea of the impacts of the drought and if possible to help troubleshoot the water systems problems. The report consists of information volunteered from 113 systems and is updated weekly as information comes in. At one time 40% of those systems were on mandatory rationing, 35% were on voluntary rationing, and 25% were not rationing. This summer was very hard on much of Oklahoma causing some wells to run dry and many operators to be servicing line breaks throughout their water distribution systems. This summer ODEQ reinstituted and supplied the voluntary drought report online which was last needed in 1996. It is primarily a tool to help give the public an idea of the impacts of the drought and if possible to help troubleshoot the water systems problems. The report consists of information volunteered from 113 systems and is updated weekly as information comes in. At one time 40% of those systems were on mandatory rationing, 35% were on voluntary rationing, and 25% were not rationing. This summer was very hard on much of Oklahoma causing some wells to run dry and many operators to be servicing line breaks throughout their water distribution systems. Oklahoma public water system drought impacts include 1) Line breaks due to ground drying and cracking. 2) Surface water reservoir water surface elevations nearing intake. 3) Elevated iron and manganese concentrations. Although I did not receive any specific inquiries about elevated iron and manganese concentrations I do understand that this can be an issue for PWS systems during drought conditions. 4) Blue green algae in reservoirs. 5) Fire fighting has caused some demand problems The Oklahoma 2011 drought necessitated: 1) Precautionary water rationing to prevent the need for extending SW intakes to deeper parts of the reservoir, 2) supply interconnections between systems to prevent the need for new GW wells, 3) Water conservation notices. 4) Boil water advisories. Additionally, at least one GW PWSs “went dry”. Other PWS’s had some issues with water supply levels in wells, but did not go completely “dry” on entier supply. Private Wells reported to have had to “lower” pumps in wells due to subsidence. The private well comment was not work related but through personal experience. Summary for USEPA by Michael Taylor, Oklahoma DEQ, provided via email Dec. 5, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Greater number of fires than usual in Georgia in August
Description: The Georgia Forestry Commission fought 455 fires during August, which represents 42 percent more fires than the state’s five year monthly average.  Rome News-Tribune (Ga.), Sept. 8, 2011

Title: Budgets of many small Oklahoma fire departments stressed by lengthy fire season, drought, heat
Description: The lengthy fire season in Oklahoma, drought and heat were all stressing the budgets of small fire departments across the state.  The assistant fire chief in Weatherford said that the fire department has answered 30 percent more fire calls than usual, due to drought and heat.  The Elmore city fire chief thought that fire calls were 30 to 50 percent higher than usual.  The state received roughly $3.8 million in grants that must be divvied up among 880 rural and volunteer fire departments, which comes out to about $4,300 per department.  Wichita Falls Times (Texas), Aug. 1, 2011
Places: Oklahoma, Weatherford, OK, Elmore City, OK

Title: Hot, dry conditions discouraged park visitations and overnight stays in Texas parks
Description: Hot, dry conditions discouraged park visitations and overnight stays in Texas parks.  Bans on outdoor burning and using charcoal grills also made park stays less enjoyable.  Parks that offered water-based recreation noticed the greatest reduction in visitation.  In August, visits to Garner State Park on the Frio River and Pedernales Falls State Park on the Pedernales River were down by nearly 40 percent, while visits to the Guadalupe River State Park were down by 60 percent, compared to the same time in 2010.  About 50 Texas parks saw revenue fall by at least 20 percent, while overall revenue to Texas parks dropped by 24 percent in August.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 21, 2011
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Pastures inadequate in Lawrence and Mount Vernon counties, Missouri
Description: Not enough pasture for the dairy and in turn not enough hay for this winter. Rain has been falling in the town of Mt. Vernon but not out of the farm where we need it. How are we to feed our cows this winter and our families? The farmers are needing help in finding hay and help in purchasing it also.
Places: Missouri, Lawrence County, MO, Mount Vernon, MO

Title: Kansas soybean crop manifesting signs of drought stress
Description: The leaves on soybean plants across much of Kansas were curling or dropping off, due to drought and heat stress, according to a K-State Research and Extension crop production specialist.  Pittsburg Morning Sun (Kan.), Aug. 1, 2011

Title: Record numbers of donkeys abandoned across Texas
Description: More than 300 donkeys were rescued in Texas as owners, who cannot afford to provide hay and water during drought, continue to  abandon the animals in record numbers.  Texas is overpopulated with donkeys because they are worth little and cannot be sold at most auctions, leaving owners few options to get rid of them when they no longer want the donkeys.  KATV-TV ABC 7 Little Rock (AR), July 28, 2011 and Allentown Morning Call (Pa.),  Dec. 3, 2011

Title: Sparse hay supply led to increased cost in Texas
Description: Ranchers purchasing hay must hand over at least $100 per grass roll, whereas they used to cost $40.  Drought has browned pastures, stunted hay growth and forced ranchers to feed hay. KTBC-TV MyFoxAustin (Texas), July 25, 2011

Title: Food prices rose slightly, due to drought
Description: Food prices rose slightly, due to drought, according to recent government and industry surveys.  The USDA estimated that grocery bills will cost 4 percent more in 2011 than in 2010.  KTBC-TV MyFoxAustin (Texas), July 25, 2011

Title: Declining aquifer levels across Texas posing problems
Description: Homeowners relying on private wells in Texas were discovering that the water table has fallen, leaving them with no water until pumps were lowered or wells were drilled deeper.  Drought has meant that aquifers weren’t recharging while demand has increased due to drought and population growth.  The greatest depletion of groundwater appeared to be occurring along Interstate 35 near Fort Worth, Austin and San Antonio.  Aquifer levels declined by 20 to 50 feet in parts of the Upper Trinity Groundwater Conservation District, according to the district president.  The Blanco-Pedernales Groundwater Conservation District has experienced even greater declines in some areas.  The Blanco and Pedernales rivers no longer flow.  San Angelo area wells in the Lipan-Kickapoo Water Conservation District were reaching record lows, according to the general manager.  Well users were required to cut their water use by 40 percent.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 24, 2011

Title: Arkansas Forestry Commission sought early arrival of air tankers as number of fires in state doubled
Description: The Arkansas Forestry Commission asked that air tankers be brought to Arkansas a week earlier than scheduled, due to heat and drought.  A commission member stated that the planes arrived two weeks earlier than planned.  More than 200 fires were reported across the state in July, which was about twice the usual number of wildfires.  KTHV-TV CBS 11 Little Rock, July 24, 2011

Title: Drought may be responsible for an increase in the number of rabies cases in Texas
Description: Drought may be responsible for an increase in the number of rabies cases in Texas, particularly in the northern part of the state, say veterinarians and state health officials.  Depleted water sources could be leading wild animals to approach residential areas for food and water, bringing the animals into contact with domestic pets.  There were 591 rabies cases, according to preliminary state records.  Last year, there were 387 statewide for the same time period.  In Denton, Johnson, Parker, Tarrant and Wise counties, there were 51 rabies cases through the end of June, compared with 25 cases in the first six months of 2010.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (TX), July 23, 2011

Title: Drought reducing crop yields across South Carolina
Description: Agricultural reports indicated that hay production was down 30 to 50 percent, while the corn manifested a 50 to 70 decline.  Aiken Standard (SC), July 22, 2011

Title: Drought, reduced planting led to smaller peanut crop in Georgia
Description: Fewer peanuts were produced in Georgia, due to drought and reduced planting as many farmers turned to cotton for a better return on their investment.  Peanut butter manufacturers were preparing for meager supplies with one major brand increasing its price by 23 percent. Georgia Public Broadcasting (Ga.), July 22, 2011

Title: Drought affected wildlife across North Carolina
Description: Drought caused many flowering plants to bloom earlier than normal, according to the education director for Audubon North Carolina.  The majority of frogs and turtles have been dormant, due to the drought, while mosquito and dragonfly populations were smaller than usual.  A fisheries biologist with the N.C. Wildlife Resources Commission shared that numerous people have contacted him to tell him about fish kills in small ponds.  Wilmington Morning Star (N.C.), July 22, 2011

Title: Weight restrictions lifted in parts of Oklahoma to hasten hay, feed deliveries to hungry livestock
Description: The governor lifted restrictions on commercial vehicle shipments in parts of Oklahoma to hasten hay and feed deliveries to hungry cattle as dry pastures offered nothing for the livestock to eat.  The governor made a declaration earlier in the year concerning weight restrictions, but amended it as drought worsened.  Yahoo! Finance, July 21, 2011 and Oklahoma Farm Report, Nov. 22, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: State of emergency declared for all Oklahoma counties
Description: The lieutenant governor of Oklahoma announced a state of emergency for 33 counties to make sure that they were eligible for any federal aid that may become available.  The governor later included another 44 counties, including all Oklahoma counties in the state of emergency.  KOKH FOX25 Oklahoma City (OK), July 20, 2011

Title: Florida swarming with mosquitoes after rains return
Description: The executive director of the Florida Mosquito Control Association shared that all of Florida was swarming with mosquitoes because the drought provided plenty of dry land on which the mosquitoes laid their eggs.  When rain returned, the population explosion began.  Residents of Broward and Palm Beach counties were calling to report problems with mosquitoes as the insects plague the area in unthinkable numbers.  The mosquito control unit in Broward County has been fielding 500 to 700 calls daily, while the Palm Beach County unit received roughly 100 calls daily.  Many people reported running from their house to their cars or simply staying indoors to avoid the mosquitoes.  Florida Jewish News, July 20, 2011

Title: Oklahoma ranchers selling excessive numbers of livestock
Description: Drought conditions were forcing many Oklahoma ranchers to sell their cattle.  Feeder cattle sales in Oklahoma during the last two weeks were up 56 percent, while cow and bull sales were up 205 percent compared to last year.  Notable among the livestock sales were high numbers of cows and lightweight feeder cattle that would not typically be sold.  A livestock marketing specialist from the Oklahoma State University Cooperative Extension stated, “Most likely we are seeing a second wave of cow liquidation made up of animals with spring-born calves that are just now big enough to wean early and sell.”  So many ranchers want to sell that livestock haulers are busy, forcing a delay in shipping the cattle to market.  Southeast Farm Press, Aug. 2, 2011

Title: Hot, dry weather affecting Mississippi corn crop
Description: Corn crop suffering in hot, dry weather; dryland corn shows significant loss; even irrigated corn yields declining. (User-submitted media report; http://msbusiness.com/2011/07/corn-crop-suffering-in-hot-dry-weather/)

Title: Most non-irrigated corn in Oklahoma dying
Description: Most non-irrigated corn in Oklahoma did not receive enough rainfall and was dying from drought and heat.  A farmer in northeastern Canadian County cut his corn in preparation for baling it.  According to the Crop Weather update released on July 18, 2011, more than 50 percent of the corn crop in Oklahoma was rated poor to very poor.  Oklahoma Farm Report, July 19, 2011

Title: Cattle sales triple last year's sales in parts of Kansas
Description: The Kansas Agricultural Statistics Service reported that cattle sales were triple the usual number in some locales across the state as drought, dry pastures and diminished water supplies drove ranchers to cull their herds.  About 14,500 cattle were auctioned at Pratt, Salina and Dodge City during the week of July 18.  Just 4,300 animals were sold at the same time last year.  The Kansas City Star, July 27, 2011
Places: Kansas, Dodge City, KS, Pratt, KS, Salina, KS

Title: Burn bans in effect in 247 Texas counties
Description: There were 247 counties in Texas with bans on outdoor burning, according to the Texas Forest Service, as drought hangs on and raises the fire danger.  The previous record for the greatest number of Texas counties with burn bans occurred in January 2006 when 221 counties prohibited outdoor burning.  KVUE-TV ABC Austin (Texas), July 18, 2011

Title: Ragweed season in Central Texas ought to be milder than usual this year
Description: The ragweed plant population was halved by the drought, according to an Austin allergist.  As a result, the ragweed season should not be as uncomfortable for Central Texas allergy sufferers this year.  KVUE (Texas), July 18, 2011

Title: Day of prayer for rain in Oklahoma
Description: Oklahoma Governor Mary Fallin called for a day of prayer on July 17, 2011 to pray for rain.  Drought conditions increased the fire activity,prompting the governor to issue a burn ban for 45 counties.OK.gov (Oklahoma City, Okla.), July 14, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Certain restrictions and permitting requirements lifted to ease hay transport in Texas
Description: The Texas Agriculture Commissioner requested and received a waiver that lifts some restrictions and permitting requirements to hasten the hay transportation for ranchers who desperately need it to sustain their livestock.  The waiver expires on August 4, but may be renewed if the governor extends the state’s disaster proclamation.  North Texas e-News, July 17, 2011 and The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011

Title: Livestock deaths, crop stress reported in Huntington, Indiana
Description: Huntington, Indiana. The extreme high heat the week of July 17th through August 7th has caused animal deaths to be reported throughout the county. The lack of precipitation has had a negative impact on crops during this year's growing season. The normal precipitation in July is 3.58. The most precipitation reported in spots of the county for July was .98. The heat and lack of precipitation is causing stress on crops and livestock.
Places: Indiana, Huntington County, IN, Huntington, IN

Title: A new electric usage record was set for July when Texas used 64,226 megawatts on July 14
Description: A new electric usage record was set for July when Texas used 64,226 megawatts on July 14, according to the spokeswoman for the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT).  The previous high usage for July was 63,400 megawatts, but that record has been topped three times this summer.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 21, 2011

Title: Reports of Texas cattle dying from water intoxication
Description: Cattle in various parts of Texas died from water intoxication after thunderstorms dropped rainfall over the drought-stricken state on July 12.  Many cattle hadn’t had adequate supplies and overindulged when they got the opportunity.  Odessa American (Texas), July 13, 2011

Title: Texas drought emergency extended
Description: Gov. Rick Perry extended the drought emergency for Texas as the ongoing drought continued to threaten water supplies, public health, property and the economy.  Dallas County was among the more than 50 counties included in the proclamation.  WBAP-AM 820 Arlington (Texas), June 9, 2014Texas Governor Rick Perry extended the drought emergency for more than 200 counties across the state.  The declaration authorizes needed measures to guard public health, property and the economy in drought-stricken parts of Texas.  KHOU-TV CBS 11 Houston (Texas), June 19, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Burn bans nearly statewide in Texas in summer 2011
Description: All but 26 of Texas' 254 counties had burn bans in place as of June 23, 2011.Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011

Title: Counties under burn bans and some limit fireworks in Florida
Description: Thirty Florida counties are under statewide burn bans, and 23 counties limit personal use of fireworks.

Title: Fireworks, open fires, smoking banned on State Trust Lands until further notice
Description: All fireworks, smoking and open fires were prohibited on State Trust lands in New Mexico until further notice. The trust administers 13 million acres throughout the state.

Title: Firefighters battled 15 blazes in Nassau County, Florida
Description: Firefighters battled 15 blazes in Nassau County, Florida. A 15-acre fire has been burning in the 86000 block of Pages Dairy Road and a 69.9-acre fire was at Lessie and Kings Ferry roads at the Kings Ferry boat ramp. Firefighters also have been fighting a 1-acre fire west of U.S. 17 at the Yulee Fire tower. Three fires - 1, 3.5 and 5.5 acres - have burned near East Crandall Road, west of U.S. 17. Firefighters have been battling a 1-acre fire east of Candlewood Road, a 6.1-acre blaze west of I-95 near County Road 108 and a 5-acre fire near County Road 121 and Trigg Road. A .2-acre fire also has been burning in the 85000 block of Radio Avenue off U.S. 17. Three fires ranging from a small outbreak less than an acre to 10 acres also have been burning near Kolars Ferry Road. As of mid-June, 3,428 fires had burned 194,271 acres statewide so far in 2011.Jacksonville, Florida, Times-Union, June 22, 2011

Title: North Carolina counties issue burn bans
Description: Burn bans took effect for 27 counties in eastern North Carolina.  As of July 29, the fire restrictions remain in effect for Beaufort, Bladen, Brunswick, Carteret, Columbus, Craven, Dare, Duplin, Hyde, Jones, New Hanover, Onslow, Pamlico, Pender, Sampson, Tyrrell and Washington counties.  The Charlotte Observer (N.C.), July 29, 2011

Title: Texas counties banning fireworks because of drought
Description: Almost 130 Texas counties had banned fireworks by late June, 2011, because of the drought.Fort Worth Star-Telegram, June 22, 2011

Title: Drought threatens Georgia crops, livestock
Description: Many farmers have had to run their irrigation systems more than normal. Pastures of some dairy farmers have dried up, and some farmers are selling their cattle for beef because the price of corn feed is too expensive.

Title: Southeast Texas faces wildfire
Description: Wildfire in Grimes County, Texas had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. Fire in Trinity and Polk counties had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires across 145,000 acres. A total of about 2,000 residents had been evacuated.  Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Texas, Grimes County, TX, Houston, TX, Jasper County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Polk County, TX, Potter County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Florida bans open fires on public lands.
Description: The state of Florida has banned all open fires on public lands, due to extremely dry conditions. Any violation is considered a second-degree misdemeanor, punishable by up to a $500 fine and 60 days in jail. In light of significant drought conditions and the increased threat of wildfires, the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, in cooperation with the state Division of Forestry and other agencies, issued an executive order prohibiting campfires in wildlife management areas, wildlife and environmental areas and all other lands it manages. For Myers, Florida, News-Press, June 23, 2011

Title: Fish and Wildlife Commission Prohibits Campfires on Public Lands
Description: The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, state Division of Forestry, and other partner agencies have issued an order prohibiting campfires on all lands that FWC manages.

Title: Fire officials encourage Arizona residents not to shoot fireworks in 2011
Description: A change in Arizona law in December 2010 legalized fireworks, but fire chiefs in 2011 urged people not to use fireworks under this year's drought conditions.  Nogales International (Ariz.), June 15, 2011

Title: Drought in Texas may help boost prices of good Arkansas hay crop
Description: The first cut of hay was good across Arkansas. Drought in Texas was expected to drive up hay prices, representing a money-making opportunity for growers who aren't feeding their own cattle.Baxter, Arkansas, Bulletin, June 15, 2011

Title: South Carolina sees drought emerging
Description: Crispy lawns, a brush fire, and an official designation all underscored emerging drought conditions in Charleston and elsewhere in South Carolina. South Carolina's State Drought Response Committee met as the state entered drought to evaluate the situation. Anderson Independent-mail, June 15, 2011Lawns are crunchy brown and water sprinklers have become ubiquitous in subdivisions. Palmetto leaves are drooping and hardwood tree leaves sag. Farmers have pulled in the tomatoes early to save what they could. Corn, one of the money feed crops, is dying on the stalk in unirrigated fields. It's been so dry for so long that even the Lowcountry's soaking-sweat humidity is evaporating.  Charleston Post & Courier, June 14, 2011A brushfire burned 23 acres near St. Johns High School and threatened a larger area, but a coordinated effort by area fire departments and the South Carolina Forestry Commission brought it under control after five hours. Charleston Post & Courier, June 15, 2011
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Texas agriculture assessment shows drought's effects statewide
Description: AgriLife Extension reports show that a variety of crops and livestock across the entire state of Texas are affected by drought and heat.

Title: Trees in Indiana were succumbing to disease
Description: Many trees in Indiana were succumbing to disease after a period of drought in 2010.  Arborists expect to see more tree deaths and damage for the next three to five years.  Indy.com (IN), June 13, 2011

Title: Florida governor declares state of emergency due to drought
Description: Florida Gov. Rick Scott on June 13, 2011, declared a state of emergency because of wildfire and drought, putting the state Division of Emergency management in charge.The Miami Herald, June 15, 2011.Eleven employees of the Kentucky Division of Forestry headed to Florida in mid-June to help with that state's wildfire emergency.Lexington, Kentucky, Herald-Leader

Title: 91 Georgia counties eligible for aid through the Livestock Forage Program
Description: Effingham, Bryan, and Chatham were just a few of the 91 counties in the central and southern portions of Georgia that were eligible for aid through the Livestock Forage Program.  Drought reduced grazing in much of the state, forcing ranchers to purchase feed.  Savannah Morning News (Ga.), June 11, 2011
Places: Georgia, Bryan County, GA, Chatham County, GA, Effingham County, GA

Title: Texas statewide fire disaster proclamation extended
Description: The governor of Texas extended his statewide disaster proclamation and again sought help from the federal government for firefighting costs.  Wildfires have burned more than 460 homes and charred more than 2.8 million acres in Texas since November 2010.  The governor requested a federal disaster declaration in April, but was denied since the state had already received dozens of grants to cover some of the firefighting costs.  New York Times (N.Y.), June 11, 2011

Title: Kansas governor sought federal disaster declaration for additional 25 counties
Description: The governor of Kansas sought a federal disaster declaration for an additional 25 counties in the south central part of the state as drought continued to take its toll.  He announced June 24 that his request had been granted. The affected counties were Barber, Barton, Butler, Clark, Comanche, Cowley, Edwards, Ellis, Ford, Graham, Gray, Harper, Harvey, Hodgeman, Kingman, Lincoln, Norton, Phillips, Reno, Rice, Russell, Sedgwick, Stafford, Sumner and Trego.  The Wichita Eagle (Kan.), June 10, 2011
Places: Georgia, Bryan County, GA, Chatham County, GA, Effingham County, GA, Barber County, KS, Barton County, KS, Butler County, KS, Clark County, KS, Comanche County, KS, Cowley County, KS, Edwards County, KS, Ellis County, KS, Ford County, KS, Graham County, KS, Gray County, KS, Harper County, KS, Harvey County, KS, Hodgeman County, KS, Kingman County, KS, Lincoln County, KS, Norton County, KS, Phillips County, KS, Reno County, KS, Rice County, KS, Russell County, KS, Sedgwick County, KS, Stafford County, KS, Sumner County, KS, Trego County, KS

Title: Alabama governor issued statewide burn ban
Description: Because extremely dry conditions have created an atmosphere where the probability of catastrophic wildfire activity is high, Governor Robert Bentley on June 7, 2011, signed an Emergency Drought Condition Declaration prohibiting outdoor burning in all 67 counties in Alabama.  The burn ban was lifted July 18, after rains alleviated conditions across the state.Clanton Advertiser, June 14, 2011; WSFA, June 7, 2011; Mobile Press-Register (AL), July 18, 2011

Title: Texas had burn bans in 193 of its 254 counties
Description: Burn bans were in effect in 193 of Texas’ 254 counties as the drought persisted.  Officials were referring to the drought as “one of the worst in the past 100 years.”  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 7, 2011

Title: 175 water suppliers with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect in Texas
Description: There were 175 water suppliers with voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect in Texas with many of them concentrated in the San Antonio area.  Statewide Texas has more than 4,500 water suppliers.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), June 5, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Texas cattle sales exceptionally high in June 2011
Description: Cattle sales in June rose to 482,450 head, which was the highest monthly sales figure since 2007, according to the Texas Department of Agriculture.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 11, 2011

Title: Texas' energy usage in June was 5 percent above that used in 2010
Description: Texas' energy usage in June was 5 percent above that used in 2010, according to the spokeswoman for the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT).  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 21, 2011

Title: Small businesses in Delaware eligible for federal assistance
Description: Small businesses in Delaware were eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought and heat from June 1 through August 30, 2011.
