The neighboring counties of Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's, Wicomico and Worcester in Maryland were also eligible for assistance.The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Farmers and ranchers should not apply.  Applications must be received by May 30, 2012.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 27, 2012
Places: Delaware, Caroline County, MD, Dorchester County, MD, Kent County, MD, Queen Anne's County, MD, Wicomico County, MD, Worcester County, MD

Title: Firefighters across Florida battled wildfire in June 2011
Description: Fires dotted Florida and straddled the Georgia border in late June 2011. The Florida Division of Forestry said Friday that 3,427 fires have burned more than 194,000 acres in the state, moving 2011 into 11th place in the all-time rankings. The worst year in recorded history was 1989, when 7,175 fires burned more than 645,000 acres.Firefighters were battling 15 blazes in Nassau County.The Santa Fe Swamp Fire was 65 percent contained at 5,700 acres. The Kelly Fire inside the Osceola National Forest had burned 818 acres by June 22. The Impassable Bay Fire, 10 miles north, had burned 11,305 acres. Jacksonville had issued an air quality advisory. About 20 active fires were burning in the Ocala National Forest. Fires in the Big Cypress National Preserve had burned 10,504 acres as of June 18, 2011.A 10- to 15-acre brush fire was burning near Punta Gorda in Charlotte County.Indian River County and Treasure Coast were fighting fires.Jacksonville Florida Times-Union, June 22, June 23, 2011Palm Beach Florida Post, June 18, 2011Fort Myers Florida News-Press, June 18, June 20, 2011Gainesville Florida Sun, June 18, 2011Ocala Florida Star Banner, June 19, 2011Palm Beach Post, June 20, 2011
Places: Florida, Hawthorne, FL, Baker County, FL, Bradford County, FL, Charlotte County, FL, Collier County, FL, Jacksonville, FL, Hamilton County, FL, Indian River County, FL, Salt Springs, FL, Nassau County, FL, Putnam County, FL, Volusia County, FL, Brantley County, GA, Candler County, GA, Charlton County, GA, Ware County, GA

Title: Drought and heat affecting wildlife in Oklahoma
Description: High Heat, Drought stress wildlife Young birds leaving their nests as early as 2 weeks old to escape heat; declining populations of game birds
Places: Oklahoma, Adair County, OK, Alfalfa County, OK, Atoka County, OK, Beaver County, OK, Beckham County, OK, Blaine County, OK, Bryan County, OK, Caddo County, OK, Canadian County, OK, Carter County, OK, Cherokee County, OK, Choctaw County, OK, Cimarron County, OK, Cleveland County, OK, Coal County, OK, Comanche County, OK, Cotton County, OK, Craig County, OK, Creek County, OK, Custer County, OK, Delaware County, OK, Dewey County, OK, Ellis County, OK, Garfield County, OK, Garvin County, OK, Grady County, OK, Grant County, OK, Greer County, OK, Harmon County, OK, Harper County, OK, Haskell County, OK, Hughes County, OK, Jackson County, OK, Jefferson County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Kay County, OK, Kingfisher County, OK, Kiowa County, OK, Latimer County, OK, Le Flore County, OK, Lincoln County, OK, Logan County, OK, Love County, OK, Major County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Mayes County, OK, McClain County, OK, McCurtain County, OK, McIntosh County, OK, Murray County, OK, Muskogee County, OK, Noble County, OK, Nowata County, OK, Okfuskee County, OK, Oklahoma County, OK, Okmulgee County, OK, Osage County, OK, Ottawa County, OK, Pawnee County, OK, Payne County, OK, Pittsburg County, OK, Pontotoc County, OK, Pottawatomie County, OK, Pushmataha County, OK, Roger Mills County, OK, Rogers County, OK, Seminole County, OK, Sequoyah County, OK, Stephens County, OK, Texas County, OK, Tillman County, OK, Tulsa County, OK, Wagoner County, OK, Washington County, OK, Washita County, OK, Woods County, OK, Woodward County, OK

Title: Drought caused hundreds of millions in losses to Missouri agriculture
Description: Drought reduced the Missouri corn harvest by about 24 million bushels, the soybean crop by roughly 20 million bushels and lowered the production of forage and pasture land.  It was estimated that drought caused a loss of $350 million to the state’s grain crops.  The hay crop was down 15 to 30 percent in parts of Missouri, leaving what was harvested in high demand by out of state buyers since drought decimated the hay crop over a large portion of the southern U.S.  Dairy farmers were paying up to $300 per ton for hay of adequate quality for dairy cattle.  Some cattle ranchers have sold cattle to reduce their herd size to match the amount of stored hay for the winter.  Researchers from the University of Missouri estimated that the state needed about 13 feet of snow to compensate for the hot, dry summer and restore soil moisture.  Lebanon Daily Record (Mo.), Dec. 18, 2011

Title: Outdoor burning banned in Louisiana
Description: Louisiana had a statewide burn ban that took effect on June 1 after the state fire marshal and the agriculture and forestry commissioner issued the order due to ongoing drought.  Baton Rouge Advocate (La.), June 1, 2011 and WBRZ-TV (La.), July 17, 2011

Title: Livestock producers in Louisiana may be eligible for assistance through the Livestock Forage Disaster Program
Description: Livestock producers in Louisiana may be eligible for assistance through the Livestock Forage Disaster Program for loss of grazing for qualified livestock on native or improved pasture land with long-term vegetation or that was cultivated for grazing.  Applications must be received by January 30, 2012.  Baton Rouge Advocate (La.), Nov. 7, 2011

Title: Drought drawing out more bears in South Carolina
Description: The increase in bear sightings in the Lowcountry has been attributed to drought as the bears have to move into new areas to find food and water.  There have been more than 10 bear sightings in Berkeley and Charleston counties since the start of the year.  Wildlife biologists say that wildlife is more likely to be visible during drought, such as deer grazing in gardens, for example.  Upstate counties were also seeing record numbers of bears, according to a DNR biologist.  Charleston Post & Courier (S.C.), June 11, 2011
Places: Asheville, NC, South Carolina, Berkeley County, SC, Charleston County, SC, Orangeburg County, SC, Sumter, SC, Rock Hill, SC

Title: New Mexico representative sought federal assistance for producers suffering pasture loss
Description: U.S. Rep. Steve Pearce of New Mexico sought federal assistance through the Emergency Haying and Grazing of Conservation Reserve Program for ranchers who lost pastures to drought and recent wildfires.  Carlsbad Current-Argus (N.M.), May 25, 2011

Title: Drought and heat led Georgia cotton farmers to postpone planting
Description: Drought and heat led cotton farmers in Georgia to postpone planting around mid-May when roughly 20 percent of the crop was planted, compared to the five year average of 25 percent of the cotton crop being in the ground.

Title: Kansas legislators consider impact of drought on state's revenue
Description: Kansas legislators considered the financial impact drought was having on farmers in the western part of the state and acknowledged that the state revenue may be lower than anticipated, depending on the duration and severity of the drought.  The budget for 2012 was trimmed back compared to the previous year by 5 to 6 percent.  The Wichita Eagle (Kan.), May 9, 2011

Title: Approximately 140 wildfires burning in Florida
Description: Approximately 140 wildfires were burning in Florida as dry conditions increased the fire danger, according to the Florida Division of Forestry.  The majority of the fires had charred at least 100 acres.  Ocala Star-Banner (Fla.), May 9, 2011

Title: Oklahoma agriculture officials urged farmers to avoid plowing to reduce soil erosion
Description: Oklahoma agriculture officials urged farmers to avoid plowing their fields to reduce soil erosion.  Some of the wheat crop across the state failed from the lack of rain, leading farmers to plow the wheat under in preparation for planting a different crop. Much of the western half of the state was in severe to extreme drought.

Title: Oklahoma hay haulers having difficulty finding hay
Description: Oklahoma hay haulers have had to travel farther to find hay. One company, Drinnon Hay Service, has been traveling more miles and therefore making fewer trips each week. They have had to go as far north as North Dakota for hay. The Oklahoma Department of Agriculture keeps a hay directory to connect those seeking hay with those able to provide it; the directory has gone from 34 pages to 5 this year.

Title: Small businesses in Tennessee eligible for assistance through the SBA
Description: Small businesses in Tennessee and four Kentucky counties were eligible for low-interest loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought and high temperatures from May 1 through October 31, 2011.  The primary counties were Anderson, Bledsoe, Blount, Bradley, Campbell, Cannon, Clay, Crockett, Cumberland, Davidson, Dekalb, Fayette, Fentress, Hamilton, Hardeman, Haywood, Jackson, Knox, Lauderdale, Loudon, Macon, Madison, McMinn, Meigs, Monroe, Morgan, Overton, Pickett, Polk, Putnam, Rhea, Roane, Rutherford, Scott, Sevier, Shelby, Smith, Sumner, Tipton, Trousdale, Van Buren, White and Wilson.  The neighboring counties also eligible for aid include all counties in Tennessee not named as primary counties; Benton and Marshall counties in Mississippi; Cherokee, Graham and Swain counties in North Carolina; and Allen, McCreary, Monroe and Wayne in Kentucky.  The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Farmers and ranchers should not apply.  Applications must be received by August 29, 2012.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 9, 2012
Places: Allen County, KY, McCreary County, KY, Monroe County, KY, Wayne County, KY, Benton County, MS, Marshall County, MS, Cherokee County, NC, Graham County, NC, Swain County, NC, Tennessee

Title: All counties in Arkansas received federal disaster declaration
Description: All counties in Arkansas were declared to be natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture due to flooding, drought, excessive heat, wind and hail since April.  This declaration permits affected farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural producers to apply for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.  ArkansasMatters.com (Ark.), Sept. 8, 2011

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas recommended inspection of electrical lines and equipment
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas recommended that all electric transmission and distribution companies inspect and clean their equipment to avoid more power outages like those that affected refineries in Texas City and in Galveston Island.  Dust, pollen, salt and other substances can build up when there is no precipitation to remove the materials.  When fog or mist moistens the layer of dust and debris, short-circuits sometimes occur, causing power outages.  Coastal areas and West Texas were thought to be more susceptible to this issue than other parts of the state.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 29, 2011

Title: The governor of Texas declared Days of Prayer for Rain
Description: The governor of Texas declared April 22 through April 24 to be Days of Prayer for Rain as the state endured intense drought and widespread wildfires.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 21, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Many resources used across Texas to fight wildfires
Description: The spate of wildfires across Texas brought 925 federal workers and 123 trucks, bulldozers and airplanes to assist with firefighting efforts mainly in West and North Texas, where almost 600 federal employees and 219 pieces of equipment were in use.  The U.S. Forest Service provided 717 people, while the Bureau of Land Management offered 74 people and 17 pieces of equipment to fight fires.  There were 21 major fires affecting at least 770,000 acres on April 18, as reported by the National Interagency Fire Center report.  there were 283 people from the Texas Forest Service and 90 pieces of equipment engaged in fighting fires on April 18, while private citizens offered the use 135 pieces of equipment and another 34 citizens volunteered to fight fires.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 18, 2011

Title: Wildfires led Texas governor to request major disaster declaration
Description: The governor of Texas requested a major disaster declaration for the state of Texas since wildfires have ravaged or endangered 252 of the state’s 254 counties.  In a letter to the president, the governor noted that at least 7,800 fires had scorched in excess of 1.5 million acres or 2,400 square miles and destroyed 244 homes while jeopardizing 8,500 more homes.  The declaration would provide funds to help the state fight the fires and deal with the aftermath.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 17, 2011

Title: Small business owners in Georgia, counties in neighboring states eligible for aid through Small Business Administration
Description: Small businesses in some Georgia, Alabama, Florida and Tennesseecounties were eligible for federal disaster loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought and heat since April 15, 2011.  The primary counties were all of the counties in Georgia.  The neighboring counties of Barbour, Chambers, Cherokee, Cleburne, DeKalb, Henry, Houston, Jackson, Lee, Randolph and Russell in Alabama; Baker, Columbia, Gadsden, Hamilton, Jackson, Jefferson, Leon, Madison and Nassau in Florida; Cherokee, Clay, Jackson and Macon in North Carolina; Abbeville, Aiken, Allendale, Anderson, Barnwell, Edgefield, Hampton, Jasper, McCormick and Oconee in South Carolina; and Bradley, Hamilton, Marion and Polk in Tennessee were also eligible for aid.  The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Farmers and ranchers should not apply.  Applications must be received by May 7, 2012.
Places: Barbour County, AL, Chambers County, AL, Cherokee County, AL, Cleburne County, AL, DeKalb County, AL, Henry County, AL, Houston County, AL, Jackson County, AL, Lee County, AL, Randolph County, AL, Russell County, AL, Baker County, FL, Columbia County, FL, Gadsden County, FL, Hamilton County, FL, Jackson County, FL, Jefferson County, FL, Leon County, FL, Madison County, FL, Nassau County, FL, Georgia, Cherokee County, NC, Clay County, NC, Jackson County, NC, Macon County, NC, Abbeville County, SC, Aiken County, SC, Allendale County, SC, Anderson County, SC, Barnwell County, SC, Edgefield County, SC, Hampton County, SC, Jasper County, SC, McCormick County, SC, Oconee County, SC, Bradley County, TN, Hamilton County, TN, Marion County, TN, Polk County, TN

Title: More than 76 percent of Texas counties with burn bans
Description: There were 194 counties out of Texas’ 254 counties with burn bans in effect because drought and windy conditions raised the fire danger.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 13, 2011

Title: Surface water rights holders in Texas notified of possible restrictions
Description: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality sent letters to holders of surface water rights in the state to alert them to potential restrictions on their water rights if drought worsens.  Water rights holders in south central Texas and along the Concho River received notices of the possible restrictions in March.  Nearly all of the state was experiencing some degree of drought.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 11, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Kansas grassland bird populations on property belonging to the Nature Conservancy have fallen sharply
Description: Grassland bird populations on property belonging to the Nature Conservancy of Kansas have fallen sharply, due to drought, according to the avian program manager.  The heat prevented the eggs from hatching, and the young that did hatch had no ground cover since nearly 500,000 acres of Conservation Reserve Program land was cut for hay or grazed in 2012.  There has been very little grassland bird reproduction for the last two years.  The decreased pheasant population drew few hunters in the fall of 2012, causing a loss of many millions of dollars from the rural Kansas economy.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 11, 2013

Title: More than 700,000 acres burned in Texas during last seven days
Description: More than 700,000 acres burned in Texas wildfires during the last seven days.  Odessa American (Texas), April 17, 2011

Title: Nearly 700 square miles of Texas burned in 81 wildfires between April 7 and April 13
Description: The Texas Forest Service reported that 81 fires during the last 7 days burned nearly 700 square miles.  These blazes were fought by more than 900 firefighters from Texas and 33 additional states.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 13, 2011

Title: Majority of counties in Oklahoma ban outdoor burning
Description: Forty-seven of the 77 counties in Oklahoma have bans on outdoor burning, due to drought conditions and elevated fire danger.  KOTV-TV CBS 6 Tulsa (Okla.), April 7, 2011.

Title: More than 1 million acres burned in Texas since April 6
Description: More than 1 million acres burned in Texas since April 6, according to the Texas Forest Service.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 19, 2011

Title: Wildfires, drought led to particulate matter advisories in Oklahoma
Description: Parts of Oklahoma had particulate matter advisories issued on two or more days during the week of April 3 due to smoke from numerous wildfires and dust from a lack of precipitation.  Tulsa World (Okla.), April 9, 2011

Title: The Texas Forest Service fought 15 fires on April 2
Description: The Texas Forest Service fought 15 wildfires that burned 2,359 acres across the state on April 2, prompting the evacuation of approximately 350 homes and 400 recreational vehicles.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 3, 2011.

Title: Wildfires burn more than 10,000 acres in Texas
Description: A spokeswoman for the Texas Forest Service stated that fires across the state burned more than 10,000 acres on April 2 and 3.   Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 3, 2011.

Title: Burn bans in effect for several Texas counties
Description: Burn bans remain in effect for La Salle, Webb, Jim Wells, McMullen, Live Oak, Bee, Kleberg, and Refugio counties. Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Residents in Victoria and Corpus Christi are also strongly encouraged to conserve water. Additional locations that have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS), according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality: Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary) Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary) Calhoun County: Port Comfort (stage 1) Jim Wells County: Alice (stage 1), English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3), and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary) Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary) Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary) Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary) Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) In an article written in Agrilife today, updated 2011 Texas agricultural drought losses now total 7.62 billion. This makes the 2011 drought the most costly in history, and more than 3.5 billion higher than the 2006 drought loss estimates (now the 2nd most costly). NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - March 22, 2012

Title: Texas agricultural losses reach record levels in 2011
Description: According to the Texas Agrilife Extension Service, statewide agricultural losses in 2011 were a record 7.62 billion dollars, easily exceeding the previous record of 4.1 billion in 2006. The 2011 losses were equivalent to 43 percent of the average annual value of all agricultural receipts during the last 4 years. Livestock (3.23 billion) and cotton (2.2 billion) accounted for much of the tally. Despite improved conditions, impacts from the drought will linger. In the hardest hit areas of the state, pastures may take years to fully recover. Tree mortality is becoming clearly evident as some trees fail to emerge. The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association estimates that it may take more than 5 years to rebuild the Texas cattle industry. Texas is the leading beef producer in the nation, and third in overall agricultural production, which means food prices will likely be affected for years to come. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas - April 1, 2012

Title: Donkey rescue group collected almost 800 abandoned donkeys in Texas in past year
Description: A donkey rescue group has taken in almost 800 donkeys in Texas since March 2011 as owners have abandoned the animals.  The donkeys, which are hostile to dogs, wolves and coyotes, were used to guard cattle, but were no longer needed to guard the livestock since many of them were sold off during drought.  The director of the rescue agency stated that in just two days he collected 40 donkeys and was notified of another dozen or so near Midland in need of a home.  A man in Claiborne Parish in northwestern Louisiana has also rounded up dozens of abandoned donkeys.  Hay was more expensive than it used to be, going for $290 to $350 per ton, compared to $90 per ton before the drought, making it more costly for owners to feed the livestock they want to keep, let alone the ones they don’t want.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), March 29, 2012

Title: Wildfires burned more than 23,000 acres across Texas between March 29 and April 4, 2011
Description: The Texas Forest Service fought 67 fires statewide that charred 23,349 acres in the past week.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 6, 2011.

Title: Drought conditions prompted Georgia Forestry Commission to withhold burn permits
Description: Burn permits were not being issued by the Georgia Forestry Commission because drought conditions in the state made outdoor burning too dangerous.  The Macon Telegraph (Ga.), March 26, 2011

Title: New Mexico residents encouraged to create defensible space around structures near urban wildland interface
Description: New Mexico residents living near urban wildland interfaces were encouraged by the state Forestry Division to create a 30-feet buffer around all structures to make them more defensible against wildfires.  Most of the state was in drought and experiencing an increased number of wildfires.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), March 24, 2011

Title: Two-thirds of the counties in Texas had bans on outdoor burning
Description: Two-thirds of the counties in Texas had bans on outdoor burning since much of the state was experiencing some level of drought.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), March 18, 2011 and Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 4, 2011.

Title: Ryegrass pastures in Louisiana stifled by dry weather
Description: Ryegrass was not growing well in Louisiana, due to the lack of rain, according to a forage specialist with the Louisiana State University Agriculture Center.  Slowed ryegrass growth may result in farmers needing to provide hay for their cattle this spring.  Some areas in the state received just 50 to 75 percent of their normal amounts of precipitation.  Acadiana - Lafayette Daily Advertiser (La.), March 3, 2011

Title: North Carolinians urged to conserve water
Description: North Carolina residents were urged by the N.C. Department of Environmental and Natural Resources to conserve water since winter precipitation has been rather meager, leaving surface water supplies low.  There was concern that public water supplies and agriculture may be affected by the dry conditions, given that precipitation deficits were 3 to 5 inches below that of early March 2010.  Rocky Mount Telegram (N.C.), March 2, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Ranchers in New Mexico received $5 million in aid from the Farm Service Agency for the purchase of livestock feed since March
Description: Ranchers in New Mexico received $5 million in aid from the Farm Service Agency for the purchase of livestock feed since March.  A program specialist with the FSA stated that the FSA anticipated offering New Mexico ranchers as much as $20 million for livestock feed in 2011.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), June 1, 2011

Title: Wildfire outbreak across Virginia
Description: There were almost 300 wildfires across Virginia that consumed roughly 3,000 acres as dry conditions, strong winds and low humidity combined to create high fire risk.  More than 2,000 acres of Shenandoah National Park and adjacent land burned on February 20, resulting in Skyline Drive being closed temporarily.  The central part of Virginia is in moderate drought.  Washington Post (DC), Feb. 20, 2011.

Title: Dry conditions, winds contribute to fire activity in North Carolina
Description: Dry conditions and strong winds contributed to a spate of wildfires in North Carolina on February 19 as 288 fires burned 2,958 acres, according to the North Carolina Division of Forest Resources.  Notably, there were multiple wildfires in Division 5 in the northeastern part of the state including Edgecombe, Franklin, Greene, Halifax, Nash, Northampton, Warren, Wayne and Wilson counties.  There were 8 fires in Nash County that charred about 8 acres.  Three fires burned 21 acres in Edgecombe County and destroyed 72 hay bales, two buildings for a loss of $20,000 and caused approximately $20,000 in damage to a home. Three wildfires scorched 82 acres in Wilson County and caused about $15,000 worth of damage.  The Division 5 district forester noted that one wildfire burned 1,100 acres in Warren County.  Rocky Mount Telegram (NC), Feb. 20, 2011.
Places: North Carolina, Durham County, NC, Edgecombe County, NC, Nash County, NC, Wake County, NC, Warren County, NC, Wilson County, NC

Title: Outdoor burning discouraged due to lack of rainfall in North Carolina
Description: The North Carolina Division of Forest Resources authorities urge residents to avoid outdoor burning due to the dry conditions and prevalence of wildfires.  Winston Salem Journal (NC), Feb. 16, 2011.

Title: Push for stricter regulation of California's protection of aquifers
Description: Members of the California Senate committees on environmental quality and natural resources met after critical state and federal reviews of the oil and gas industry’s wastewater disposal activities.  Loose enforcement of regulations and errors in record-keeping have endangered federally protected water sources for drinking and irrigation.  State regulators say they are committed to intensifying supervision of water disposal.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 10, 2015California could see new changes in the protection of underground water supplies from oil and gas operations if the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency approves a plan to do so.  The aim is to return the state to compliance with federal safe-drinking water laws since it was revealed that more than 2,500 authorizations for oil field injections into protected aquifers took place.  The Associated Press uncovered that nearly half of the injection wells received approval or began operation in the last four years.CBS News (N.Y.), Feb. 9, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought increased incidence of fires across Georgia
Description: There were roughly 2,000 wildfires in Georgia from February through March 25 as dry conditions increased the number of wildfires across the state, according to a spokeswoman for the Georgia Forestry Commission.  She noted that there were 70 fires on March 24 and 25 with one of those fires claiming 2,100 acres in Camden County.  Athens Banner-Herald, (Ga.), March 25, 2011

Title: Spate of wildfires before wildfire season begins in South Carolina
Description: South Carolina Forestry Commission staff spent their weekend fighting wildfires rather than educating the public about wildfire prevention as they had planned.  Although the wildfire season has not yet begun, there were 114 calls to report fires which consumed 334 acres of forest land and 208.6 acres of non-forested land between January 28 and 30.  Easley Progress (SC), Feb. 2, 2011.

Title: Drought decreased turkey population in Texas
Description: The 2011 drought harshly stressed the turkey population, which prevented them from reproducing.  Since drought conditions persist in the state, turkeys have not yet recovered from 2011 and are relatively scarce, although reproduction was better in 2012.  Scientific American (N.Y.), May 20, 2013

Title: Drought halved honey production in Texas in 2011
Description: Honey production in Texas was down by approximately 50 percent in 2011 as heat and drought strained the bees and decreased honey production, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Honey production ceased by September.  Some bee colonies in the vicinity of Corpus Christi died from the heat and absence of nectar.  About 20 percent of the apiarists in the San Marcos area lost all of their bees to drought.  There were 7.2 million pounds of honey produced in 2010.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), March 23, 2012

Title: Wildfires consumed more than 100,000 acres in New Mexico since start of 2011
Description: Wildfires consumed more than 100,000 acres in New Mexico since the start of 2011 as drought and winds raised the wildfire danger.  At the beginning of January, the southern third of the state was in drought, but by the end of March, nearly all of the state was in some stage of drought.  Santa Fe New Mexican, March 26, 2011

Title: High bear predation rates in New Mexico
Description: About 250 bears were killed by the New Mexico Game and Fish Department during 2011, which was about ten times as many bears as are usually killed for depredation.  Bears caused more problems, leading authorities to shoot them more frequently because drought diminished the bears’ food supply, forcing them to search further for food and water.  Santa Fe New Mexican, April 4, 2012

Title: Texas agricultural losses in 2011 reached $7.6 billion
Description: Agricultural losses in Texas reached $7.6 billion, said the Texas AgriLife Extension Service, as drought blistered the state in 2011.  The figure is $2.4 billion higher than a previous estimate made in August 2011.  Some of the upward revisions include losses to the livestock industry of $3.2 billion rather than $2.1 billion, damage to the cotton crop of $2.2 billion, up from $1.8 billion, and corn losses at $736 million, previously put at $409 million.  The second highest drought loss for Texas occurred in 2006, when agricultural losses topped $4.1 billion.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), March 21, 2012 Despite improved conditions, impacts from the drought will linger. In the hardest hit areas of the state, pastures may take years to fully recover. Tree mortality is becoming clearly evident as some trees fail to emerge. The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association estimates that it may take more than 5 years to rebuild the Texas cattle industry. Texas is the leading beef producer in the nation, and third in overall agricultural production, which means food prices will likely be affected for years to come. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas - April 1, 2012

Title: Drought losses in Oklahoma top $2 billion
Description: The Oklahoma Agriculture Secretary announced that drought had cost the state upwards of $2 billion in drought losses so far in 2011.  The amount included damage to livestock and grain production, but excluded the cost of feed stocks.  He also noted that the figure was likely to rise since the impact of cattle sales will reduce the number of calves born in the state in 2012.  KTEN (Denison, Texas), Aug. 31, 2011

Title: Hundreds of millions of Texas trees died during ongoing drought
Description: More recent ground and aerial surveys show that 301 million trees died in rural Texas, according to the Texas A&M Forest Service.  A previous estimate put the number of tree deaths around 500 million.  It was estimated that 5.6 million trees in urban areas of Texas died too.  USA Today, Sept. 25, 2012Drought has led to the deaths of up to 500 million trees in Texas, according to a survey done by the Texas Forest Service, which gathered information from forestry professionals across the state.  Of the roughly 4.9 billion trees in Texas, researchers found that anywhere from 100 million to 500 million or 2 to 10 percent of the trees were killed by drought.  The most severely impacted parts of the state include Sutton, Crockett, Kimble and Pecos counties in West Texas where many Ashe junipers died; Montgomery, Harris, Grimes, Madison and Leon counties in Southeast Texas where many loblolly pines perished; and Bastrop and Caldwell counties in Central Texas where many cedars and post oaks were lost.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Dec. 19, 2011 and Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Dec. 19, 2011

Title: Drought in parts of the country boosted Oregon's alfalfa hay sales in 2011
Description: Drought in parts of the country boosted Oregon's alfalfa hay sales, resulting in sales of nearly $100 million more than in 2010, stated an economist with the Oregon State University Extension Service.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), April 11, 2012

Title: Drought reduced Oklahoma's wheat crop in 2011
Description: The wheat harvest in Oklahoma amounted to 70.4 million bushels in 2011, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, after a dry growing season devastated the crop.  The last time the state’s wheat crop was so small was in the 1950’s.  Enid News & Eagle (Okla.), May 20, 2012

Title: Agricultural losses in Kansas reached $1.8 billion
Description: Agricultural losses for Kansas amount to $1.7 billion, according to the state Department of Agriculture, which calculated the figure using current production forecasts and average historic production.  The wheat harvest was down 36.4 million bushels for a loss of $285.8 million.   The corn crop was anticipated to be 137.9 million bushels shy of average production, for a loss of $965.7 million.  Sorghum production was expected to be down 31.3 million bushels for a loss of $213.7 million.  Soybean production was predicted to be short 22.7 million bushels for a loss of $309.8 million.  KAKE / KUPK ABC 10 Wichita (Kan.), Sept. 14, 2011.  Agricultural losses in Kansas reached $1.8 billion for 2011, according to the Kansas Department of Agriculture.  A report from the Hutchinson News stated that the loss in corn production amounted to $1 billion, while damage to the wheat crop reached $269 million.  The Risk Management Agency paid $515 million in indemnity payments for crop damage in 2011, up from $375 million three weeks ago.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), Nov. 15, 2011

Title: Less than 60 percent of the crops planted in New Mexico in 2011 were harvested
Description: Less than 60 percent of the crops planted in New Mexico were harvested, according to a crop production summary by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), March 17, 2012

Title: Drought cut into agricultural production in Colorado in 2011
Description: Drought cut into agricultural production in Colorado in 2011 as drought affected the southeastern part of the state.  There were 152,000 acres of cotton planted, but only 60 percent of that was harvestable with an average yield of 136 bushels per acre, the lowest yield in the last four years.  There were 375,000 acres of wheat planted, but just 296,000 acres were harvested.  The average wheat yield was 26 bushels per acre.  Pueblo Chieftain (Colo.), March 8, 2012

Title: California hydropower down 60 percent
Description: Across California, the supply of hydropower fell 60 percent from 2011 to 2014, and 2015 was expected to be poor as well.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 6, 2015

Title: Wildfires burned more than 490 square miles in New Mexico
Description: More than 400 wildfires burned at least 490 square miles in New Mexico since the beginning of 2011.  January, February and March were the second driest for that time frame since record-keeping began.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 9, 2011

Title: Wildfires burn more acres in Texas in 2011 than previous year
Description: The Texas Forest Service fought more than 360 wildfires which scorched more than 246,000 acres since the start of the year.   Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), March 18, 2011.   As of April 6, the Texas Forest Service fought 605 wildfires that burned 279,279 acres statewide since the beginning of 2011.  At least 160 buildings were consumed.  During the same time last year, there were 149 fires that consumed 5,221 acres and 17 buildings.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 6, 2011.

Title: Cotton losses at $1.8 billion in Texas
Description: More than fifty percent of the 4.53 million acres of cotton planted on the Texas High Plains were not harvested as drought prevented crop growth.  Across Texas, about 7.1 million acres of cotton were planted with harvest rates of roughly 50 percent, according to the state cotton specialist.  Normally farmers harvest about 90 percent of the planted cotton.  The value of the lost cotton was about $1.8 billion of the $5.2 billion in agricultural losses listed in August.  Essentially no dryland cotton survived west of Interstate 35, excluding the Blacklands.  Almost 2.5 million acres of dryland cotton died this year, while irrigated cotton produced just 50 percent of the normal yield.  Country World News (Texas), Oct. 24, 2011

Title: Drought hard on Oklahoma's new Christmas tree plantings
Description: Drought and record heat in 2011 and 2012 claimed new Christmas tree  plantings on Oklahoma’s tree farms, said the assistant director of forestry services for the state Agriculture, Food and Forestry Department.NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), Dec. 8, 2014

Title: Wildfires consumed 315,000 acres in New Mexico
Description: More than 400 wildfires charred roughly 315,000 acres in New Mexico since the beginning of 2011, according to the state forester.  Dry conditions and the elevated fire risk led a couple of national forests to enact fire restrictions and the Lincoln National Forest to close its gates to the public until the drought and fire danger eases.  Farmington Daily Times (N.M.), May 5, 2011

Title: Drought drove Texas ranchers to sell or slaughter 15 percent of their cattle
Description: Drought drove Texas ranchers to sell or slaughter 15 percent of the cattle or about 2 million livestock in the state between January 2011 and January 2013.  Heifers and pregnant heifers are in high demand so ranchers can rebuild their herds, pushing the prices of pregnant heifers to $2,500, or $1,000 more than before the drought.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Jan. 4, 2014

Title: Dry conditions across South Carolina led to excessive number of wildfires
Description: There were 247 wildfires that charred at least 1,000 acres across South Carolina in January, which is substantially more than usual, according to a S.C. Forestry Commission member.  He stated that the elevated number of wildfires was due to the dry conditions affecting much of the state.  Lake Wylie Pilot (SC), Feb. 8, 2011.

Title: To date, 2011 is Georgia's second worst year for wildfires
Description: This year wildfires in Georgia have consumed 448,000 acres, which is nearly three times the state’s five year average. Of that amount, 306,000 burned in the Okefenokee Swamp, while 142,000 acres of private land burned. This is the state’s second worst fire season and hopefully will not surpass the worst fire season, which occurred in 2007 when 499,000 acres burned.  Rome News-Tribune (Ga.), Sept. 8, 2011

Title: Wildfires in Texas scorched more than 2 million acres since the start of 2011
Description: Wildfires in Texas scorched more than 2 million acres since the start of 2011.  Drought and strong winds elevated the fire danger across the state.  Odessa American (Texas), April 29, 2011

Title: Kansas farmers claimed $987.3 million in insurance payments for drought-damaged wheat and other crops
Description: Kansas farmers claimed $987.3 million in insurance payments for drought-damaged wheat and other crops, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  The director of the USDA’s office in Topeka stated that she anticipated that the payments would amount to $1 billion.  KAKE / KUPK ABC 10 Wichita (Kan.), Jan. 26, 2012

Title: Number of beef cows in Nebraska climbed in 2011
Description: The number of beef cows in Nebraska from January 1, 2011 to January 1, 2012 rose from 1.77 million to 1.88 million, reflecting the massive influx of cattle from Oklahoma and Texas as ranchers shipped their cattle out of state for grazing.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Jan. 28, 2012

Title: Fires in New Mexico scorched more than 655 square miles since the beginning of 2011
Description: Wildfires burned more than 655 square miles or more than 420,000 acres in New Mexico through mid-May, according to a study done by the University of Arizona.  The average acreage consumed by wildfires annually over the past 20 years was 375 square miles.  The fires in 2011 have far exceeded the average.  In the vicinity of Silver City, a single wildfire charred 137 square miles and was nearing containment.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), June 1, 2011

Title: Number of cattle reduced by 600,000 in Texas
Description: Despite above-normal rainfall in December and January, depleted soil moisture and groundwater concerns continue. The cattle industry has already been reshaped by the drought. In 2011, the number of cattle in Texas was reduced by 600,000, a record one-year decline (although a greater percentage drop occurred from 1934 to 1935). Only 200,000 were slaughtered; the rest were relocated to preserve genetic stock. The Texas Agrilife Extension Service projects a 4 percent decrease in beef production during 2012. Water restrictions remain in place across north Texas. Many water supply reservoirs remain below conservation levels. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas - January 31, 2012

Title: Hay production in Texas roughly 50 percent of 2010 production
Description: Hay production in Texas in 2011 was approximately 5.9 million tons, which was roughly half of the amount produced in 2010.  A bale of hay sold for about $115 in Terrell, up from about $60 the previous year.   The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011

Title: Texas received almost $48 million in federal assistance for firefighting expenses during 2011
Description: Texas received almost $48 million in federal assistance to reimburse the state for firefighting expenses during 2011 when fires charred more than 1.3 million acres in 168 counties.  Agencies that will receive some of the reimbursement include the Texas A&M Forest Service, the U.S. Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management, the U.S. National Park Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  In 2011, wildfires burned about 4 million acres and caused losses to agriculture amounting to almost $8 billion.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), July 10, 2013

Title: Wildfires in Florida blackened roughly 87 square miles
Description: Wildfires in Florida blackened roughly 87 square miles since the start of the year, according to the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services’ Division of Forestry.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), April 25, 2011

Title: Roughly 5.6 million urban trees perished from drought in Texas
Description: Roughly 5.6 million urban trees perished from drought since 2011, according to a survey performed by the Texas Forest Service.  The TFS examined satellite images of urban areas to estimate the number of trees killed by drought in the past year.  Texas has about 4.9 billion trees.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Feb. 15, 2012

Title: The pecan harvest in Texas yielded only 32 million pounds in 2011
Description: The pecan harvest in Texas yielded only 32 million pounds in 2011 during a year of drought when tens of thousands of trees died from insufficient moisture, stated the executive vice president of the Texas Pecan Growers Association.  The area most affected by the drought was in west central Texas from San Saba to Goldthwaite.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 16, 2012

Title: Beef cattle herds in Texas continuing to recover from 2011
Description: Beef cattle producers in Texas were continuing to recover from 2011, the driest year on record for the state, as they cut their beef cow herds by about 20 percent for a loss of more than one million beef cattle.  By 2014, the number of beef cattle in Texas was 3.9 million, the lowest since 1958, according to National Agricultural Statistics Service.  In the Brazos Valley, beef cattle herds numbered 167,000 head.  In January 2016, the beef cattle population in Texas continued to rise to nearly 4.3 million statewide and 183,000 in the Brazos Valley as producers continued to rebuild herds.  "Since the drought was so severe, it really colors everything after," said Dave Anderson, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service agricultural economist. "A drought that severe takes multiple years for plant life to recover."  He also noted that the slow herd growth was partially attributable to urban development, rising costs and the lingering effects of drought.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 28, 2016
Places: Texas, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Houston County, TX, Leon County, TX, Madison County, TX, Milam County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Washington County, TX

Title: Many oak trees in Arkansas have been weakened by drought and succumbed to a fungus called hypoxylon canker
Description: Many oak trees in Arkansas have been weakened by drought and succumbed to a fungus called hypoxylon canker.  The staff chair for the Sebastian County Extension office stated that 90 percent of the calls to his office were related to tree concerns.  “Two years of really, really bad drought has weakened the immune systems of trees,” he said. “I get calls from people saying, ‘My tree is sick,’ and when you go out and look at it, the bark is already sloughing off and it actually died last year.”  He and an urban forester for the University of Arkansas at Fort Smith both expect oak trees to continue to die from this fungus aided by drought stress for another two years.  Fort Smith Southwest Times Record (Ark.), May 25, 2013

Title: Approximately 68 percent of the crops planted in Oklahoma in 2011 were harvested
Description: Approximately 68 percent of the crops planted in Oklahoma were harvested, according to a crop production summary by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), March 17, 2012

Title: Hay production in Texas in 2011 down by $750 million
Description: Drought cost the state of Texas $750 million in lost hay production in 2011.  Dried up pastures and the lack of hay forced many ranchers to sell or slaughter livestock because feed and hay were too expensive.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 26, 2012

Title: Approximately 57 percent of the crops planted in Texas during 2011 were harvested
Description: Approximately 57 percent of the crops planted on 21.3 million acres in Texas during 2011 were harvested, according to a crop production summary by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Less than 41 percent of the cotton was harvested, while soybean production was just 56.4 million bushels, compared to the previous year’s harvest at 119 million bushels.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), March 17, 2012

Title: All Texas counties eligible for federal aid
Description: There were 213 Texas counties declared to be natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture due to ongoing drought, heat, strong winds and wildfires since January 1, 2011.  The remaining 41 counties that were not recognized as natural disaster areas may be eligible for aid because they border the primary counties.  This declaration permits affected farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural producers to apply for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.  The New York Times, July 12, 2011 and the USDA’s Farm Service Agency website.

Title: Rabies cases on the rise in Texas
Description: Rabies cases were on the rise in Texas in 2011, compared to 2010, and continued to climb in 2012.  During 2011, there were 32 percent more positive tests for rabies, while the number of tests dropped by almost 9 percent.  In 2010, 57 doses of prophylaxis were given; in 2011, 31 doses were used; and in 2012, 16 doses have already been required.  Denton County had 25 cases of rabies in 2011 and has had nine cases of rabies so far in 2012.  A Lewisville resident is receiving prophylaxis for rabies after being bitten repeatedly by a rabid skunk in the last week.  The Collin County chief epidemiologist felt that drought was responsible for the uptick in rabies cases and said that more cases of rabies could occur.  Star Local News (Texas), March 28, 2012

Title: Drought reduces Colorado crop yields
Description: The latest data on prevented planted and failed acreage as of 7-23-11: Failed acreage now equals 211,325.01 acres. Prevented planted now equals 91,524.57.

Title: Drought bit into Kansas corn crop
Description: The average corn yield in Kansas was 100 bushels per acre as drought hurt the crop, compared to 125 bushels per acre last year, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Des Moines Register (Iowa), Dec. 6, 2011

Title: More than 8,000 wildfires blackened more than 1.8 million acres and burned 400 homes across Texas
Description: More than 8,000 wildfires blackened more than 1.8 million acres and burned 400 homes across Texas since the start of the year as heat, low humidity and drought have elevated the fire danger.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 21, 2011

Title: Wildfires across the state of Texas cost nearly $200 million in agricultural losses
Description: Wildfires across the state of Texas cost nearly $200 million in agricultural losses, according to the Texas AgriLife Extension Service at Texas A&M University.  Timber losses alone account for $97 million, while grazing losses represent the second largest loss.  The remaining $103 million in losses covers 2.9 million acres of burnt land, 198 structures, 21 pieces of equipment, 1,133 head of cattle, 142 calves, 19 sheep, 20 horses, 210 goats and 5,965 miles of fence.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Sept. 19, 2011

Title: More marijuana plants confiscated, people arrested in Oklahoma in 2011
Description: The Oklahoma Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs confiscated 26,075 marijuana plants and arrested 15 people, despite the challenge of cultivating a crop during a drought year.  In 2010, authorities seized 18,777 plants and arrested 13 people.  Agents also found shriveled marijuana crops that had apparently been abandoned, given the drought and heat of the summer.  Oklahoma City Daily Oklahoman,NewsOK.com, News9 (OK), Nov. 2, 2011

Title: Large number of wildfires and acres burned in New Mexico
Description: More than 350 wildfires across New Mexico charred 226,348 acres and some homes since the start of the year.  A public information officer for the New Mexico State Forestry stated that more fires than occurred last year have already burned more land than was affected by wildfires in 2010.  January through March in New Mexico were the second driest on record in the past 100 years, while some counties in the southern part of the state experienced their driest January through March time period, according to a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Albuquerque.  Santa Fe New Mexican, April 22, 2011

Title: Number of wildfires in Florida several times higher than recent years' fire activity
Description: Three to four times more wildfires burned in Florida compared to the previous two years, according to a spokesman for the Florida Division of Forestry.  Since the start of the year, there were 1,144 fires that consumed more than 42,000 acres.  Nearly all of the state is in some degree of drought.  The Miami Herald (Fla.), March 4, 2011

Title: Drought contributed to the bad fire season Florida experienced in 2011
Description: Drought contributed to the bad fire season Florida experienced in 2011 when 5,136 wildfires scorched almost 300,000 acres of state and federal land.  The 2012 fire season is anticipated to be extremely active if the dry conditions persist.  Lakeland Ledger (Fla.), Feb. 18, 2012

Title: Florida Division of Forestry fought twice the number of wildfires in 2011 than in 2010
Description: The Florida Division of Forestry fought 2,664 wildfires in the state that blackened 128,675 acres since the beginning of 2011.  The number of wildfires so far in 2011 was double the number of wildfires that the Division of Forestry fought in 2010.  Lakeland Ledger (Fla.), May 28, 2011

Title: Texas lost 301 million rural trees to drought in 2011
Description: Texas lost 301 million rural trees to drought in 2011, according to a survey done by Texas A&M Forest Service.  Surveyors evaluated hundreds of forested plots statewide and considered both on-the-ground tree health assessments made earlier this year and satellite images taken before and after the drought.  The Brazos Valley lost nearly 10 percent of their rural trees, North Texas and western Northeast Texas lost 8.3 and 8.2 percent of their trees.  In eastern Northeast Texas, 3.9 percent of the trees, while just 1.3 percent of the trees in East Texas died.  The Texas A&M Forest Service also found that an additional 5.6 million trees in urban areas died during the drought.  CattleNetwork (Kan.), Sept. 26, 2012

Title: Drought and Hurricane Irene reduced North Carolina's tobacco crop by $114 million
Description: The tobacco crop in North Carolina was set back $114 million by drought and Hurricane Irene in 2011.  The average yield was 1,700 pounds per acre in 2011, compared to a ten-year average of 2,204 pounds per acre.  Raleigh News & Observer (N.C.), Nov. 10, 2011

Title: Wildfires in Texas blackened more than 1.4 million acres since the start of 2011
Description: Wildfires in Texas have blackened more than 1.4 million acres since the start of 2011 and resulted in two firefighters losing their lives.  Austin American Statesman, April 21, 2011

Title: New Mexico governor urges caution amidst high fire danger
Description: New Mexico Governor Susana Martinez made a plea June 22, 2011, for residents and visitors to help prevent wildfires. More restrictions were placed on public lands and firefighters battled blazes north of Santa Fe and along the border with Arizona. So far this fiscal year, she said, 791 fires, more than 640,000 acres have burned and 100 structures have been destroyed, including about 40 homes. The cost of fighting the fires is expected to exceed $15 million, she said. The Lincoln National Forest and the Santa Fe National Forest were closed.

Title: Texas wildfires consumed 916 square miles since start of 2011
Description: The Texas Forest Service and local fire departments fought 654 wildfires that blackened 916 square miles and burned 189 homes across the state since the beginning of the year.  Arizona Republic (Phoenix) & AZCentral.com, April 12, 2011

Title: Size and quality of Oklahoma pecans down
Description: The owner of a grocery store in Shawnee reported that the pecan crop was poor in quality and size, particularly in the central and western parts of Oklahoma.  He has sought pecans from his usual suppliers and was scrounging to find enough for his store.  Growing Magazine (VT), Oct. 23, 2011

Title: Agricultural losses in Texas reach $5.2 billion
Description: Estimated crop and livestock losses in Texas have reached $5.2 billion as of August 1, according to a Texas AgriLife Extension Service economist.  Livestock losses amounted to $2.1 billion and crop losses were $3.1 billion, but could easily rise as the drought wears on.  This figure tops Texas’ previous drought loss in 2006 of $4.1 billion.  Drought has caused $13.1 billion in agricultural losses since 1998.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 17, 2011

Title: Cattle thefts continued in Texas
Description: Cattle theft remained a problem in Texas, particularly as drought has driven cattle prices up in recent years.  Fewer livestock have been stolen because ranchers sold off animals as drought gripped the state in 2011, so there were fewer animals to steal.  In 2011, there were 804 reported cases of theft, involving 13,000 livestock stolen or missing, while the value of recovered livestock came to about $4.07 million.  In 2012, there were about 790 reported cases of theft, including 6,320 livestock stolen or missing.  The value of recovered livestock amounted to $3.3 million.  In 2013, there were 700 reports of stolen livestock, involving 4,200 livestock.  Authorities recovered $2.2 million in livestock.  Since cattle production was down, prices for livestock were at record highs in 2014 when there were 726 cases of stolen livestock, involving 5,325 animals valued at $4.89 million, an uptick of more than $800,000 from 2011.  KGBT-TV CBS 4 Harlingen (Texas), Oct. 28, 2015
