Title: Smallest winter wheat crop in New Mexico since 1954
Description: An estimated 95,000 acres of winter wheat were harvested in New Mexico in 2011, according to a range specialist with the New Mexico Department of Agriculture.  This meager harvest was the first time that there were fewer than 100,000 acres of winter wheat harvested since 1954.  He also stated that crop losses would be in the tens of millions of dollars.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), Oct. 25, 2011

Title: Drought reduced numbers of pheasants, crows, quail and lesser prairie chickens in Kansas
Description: Drought caused the 2012 pheasant harvest to fall to roughly 200,000 birds, the lowest since 1957, stated the small game program coordinator for the Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks and Tourism.  The pheasant harvest in 2010 was 900,000 birds, while the historical average is about 600,000 pheasants.  The number of crows, quail and lesser prairie chickens has declined also.  Topeka Capital-Journal (Kan.), July 6, 2013

Title: Drought in 2011 cost Oklahoma’s agriculture sector about $1.5 billion and $1.7 billion in 2012
Description: Drought in 2011 cost Oklahoma’s agriculture sector about $1.5 billion, said Blayne Arthur, deputy commissioner for the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry.  The state lost about $1.7 to drought in 2012.  NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), Oct. 23, 2014Drought cost Oklahoma agriculture $1.5 billion in economic losses from 2011 through 2013, stated John Collison, vice president of public policy for the Oklahoma Farm Bureau.  NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), March 26, 2014Two consecutive years of heat and drought have cost Oklahoma agriculture more than $1.1 billion in direct losses, as reported by Oklahoma State University.  In those two years, ranchers sold nearly 20 percent of their cattle as water sources and the feed supply dwindled.  Washington Post (D.C.), May 4, 2013

Title: Drought reduced sunflower production in Kansas by 20 percent in 2011
Description: Drought reduced sunflower production in Kansas by 20 percent in 2011, according to the executive director of the National Sunflower Association in North Dakota.  As a result, prices for black oil sunflower seed rose 20 to 30 percent in the past year, stated an employee at a Wichita, Kansas nursery, leading people to offer birds different foods or cease to feed the birds.  Other factors affecting the price of sunflower seeds include transportation costs and fewer acres planted with sunflower seeds.  The Wichita Eagle (Kan.), Feb. 27, 2012

Title: The Georgia Environmental Protection Division received 734 applications for new well permits in 2011
Description: The Georgia Environmental Protection Division received 734 applications for new well permits in 2011 as people searched for additional water supplies.  One hundred fewer applications were submitted in 2010.  WALB-TV NBC 10 Albany (Ga.), Feb. 20, 2012

Title: Dry weather and winds increase number of forest fires in Louisiana
Description: There were 434 forest fires in Louisiana in January and February 2011, in comparison with 213 fires during the same timeframe in 2010, according to Louisiana Department of Agriculture and Forestry officials.  They attribute the greater incidence of fires to dry weather and windy conditions.  Many of the fires were in the Florida parishes and southwestern Louisiana.  A complicating factor in the higher volume of fires this year is the reduced manpower in the Office of Forestry, which had to lay off 35 employees in February due to budget cuts, bringing the number of firefighters down to 100.  A state forester stated that prior to February, insufficient manpower had led to more timber land loss than would likely have occurred otherwise.  There were 4,491 acres of timber land lost to fires in January and February this year, in comparison with 2,500 acres during the same time in 2010.  Baton Rouge Advocate (La.), March 7, 2011

Title: Wildfire threat led to state disaster declaration in Texas
Description: The governor of Texas announced a wildfire-threat disaster for 244 of Texas’ 254 counties and ordered that all means necessary to be used to deal with the fire danger.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (TX), Dec. 22, 2010.  Update: The governor of Texas extended the disaster proclamation for more than 190 counties as drought and the fire threat persist.  Houston Chronicle (TX), Jan. 20, 2011.  Update:  The wildfire disaster proclamation was reissued on February 17, March 18 and April 10 as wildfires continued to burn across the state.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 12, 2011.  The proclamation was renewed.  El Paso Times (Texas), April 21, 2012

Title: Wildfires have charred 3.6 million acres across Texas
Description: Wildfires have charred 3.6 million acres across Texas since December 2010.  CBS, Sept. 6, 2011

Title: Crawfish population diminished by drought and cold temperatures
Description: The crawfish population in Louisiana is down, due to drought and chilly temperatures during the fall.  The dry conditions did not draw the mother crawfish out of their burrows to find food as they normally would, possibly leading to the baby crawfish being consumed by each other or their mother.  In addition, the cold temperatures slow the crawfish’s movement and cause them to remain rather still.  The decline in the number of crawfish led to an increase in the price for the crawfish.  Prices rose to $3.50 to $4 per pound for live crawfish or $4.25 to $5 per pound for boiled crawfish, which is roughly $0.50 to $1 higher than last year.  Between September and November, the area around New Orleans received just 3.8 inches of precipitation, according to the National Weather Service, making it the third-driest fall since records were kept.  New Orleans Times-Picayune & Nola.com (LA), Feb. 4, 2011.

Title: Wildfires across Texas cost the state $152.1 million in lost agricultural production
Description: Wildfires across Texas from November 15, 2010 through September 19, 2011 cost the state $152.1 million in lost agricultural production, according to an economist with Texas AgriLife Extension Service.  The largest portion of the $152.1 million came from the loss of 5,965 miles of fences and infrastructure, while the loss of 3 million acres of burned pasture accounts for the second largest component.  Firefighters fought 23,519 fires since the start of the wildfire season on November 15.  Timber losses in East Texas reached $97 million since more than 200,000 acres of timber burned.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 28, 2011

Title: Wildfires burned 6,000 square miles, more than 2,700 homes in Texas
Description: Extraordinary drought conditions in Texas contributed to the state’s dire wildfire season in which 6,000 square miles burned and more than 2,700 homes were lost.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Oct. 5, 2011

Title: More than 4,200 square miles burned in Texas since Nov. 15, 2010
Description: More than 10,500 wildfires charred more than 4,200 square miles in Texas since November 15, 2010, according to the Texas Forest Service.  Six of the 10 largest wildfires in Texas since 1985 burned this year.  The third largest wildfire since 1985, the Rock House fire, burned 491 square miles in Presidio and Jeff Davis counties in April and May.  Odessa American (Texas), May 28, 2011

Title: Wildfires burned 2.8 million acres since mid-November 2010
Description: The Texas Forest Service and local fire departments fought 11,362 wildfires in Texas that burned 2,838,428 acres since the fire season began on November 15, 2010.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 7, 2011

Title: Cost of fighting fires in Texas up to $70 million
Description: The Texas Forest Service has run up a bill of $70 million in firefighting costs as wildfires have plagued the state since the start of the fire season on November 15, 2010.  It has cost about $1.3 million daily since mid-March to battle the blazes, but increased fire activity in the past week racked up bills of nearly $2 million daily.  Slower days with moderate fire activity cost the TFS about $700,000 daily.  Out of state firefighters and aerial support have cost roughly $22 million through April 12.There have been 7,807 wildfires that have consumed about 2 million acres and devoured 244 homes since the fire season began.  KTXS (Abilene, Texas), April 20, 2011

Title: Texas wildfires burned 3.4 million acres since Nov. 15, 2010
Description: Texas wildfires have burned 3.4 million acres since November 15, 2010 as drought increased the fire danger and made fires more difficult to contain.  Austin American-Statesman (TX), Aug. 17, 2011

Title: The Texas fire season lasted from November 15, 2010 through October 31, 2011
Description: The Texas fire season that began on November 15, 2010 continued as the fire danger remained high.  Since the beginning of the fire season, blazes consumed nearly 4 million acres and more than 2,900 homes and took the lives of 10 people.  A spokeswoman for the Texas Forest Service said that start and end dates for fire seasons vary by year.  Seven of the 10 largest fires on record in Texas burned this spring as drought made the state vulnerable to wildfires.  A spring wildfire burned 315,000 acres near Fort Davis, but spared the Fort Davis Historic Site and the McDonald Observatory.  Wildfires swept through the Possum Kingdom Lake area, charring 160 homes in April and another 40 homes in August.  In September, a wildfire seared Bastrop County and destroyed at least 1,500 homes.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Nov. 15, 2011.  The Texas Forest Service determined that the fire season ended on October 31, 2011.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Jan. 19, 2012

Title: Ag losses in Texas climbing to $2.6 billion
Description: Drought may have cost Texas farmers and ranchers up to $2.6 billion since November 2010, according to an estimate made by an economist with the Texas AgriLife Extension Service.  More than 2 million acres of dryland cotton died without adequate rainfall, increasing the drought loss by an additional $1.1 billion from the previous estimate of $1.5 billion made in mid-May.  The estimate includes losses to livestock, wheat, corn and sorghum.  Seventy percent of rangeland and pastures in Texas was rated to be in very poor condition, indicating total or near total crop loss and an absence of grazing for animals.  Crop values are higher this year than in previous years, due to increased demand and less abundant supplies, and are pushing crops losses higher.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (TX), July 27, 2011

Title: Drought reduced number of visitors, revenue at New Mexico ski areas
Description: Drought and insufficient snow hurt visitation to ski areas in New Mexico during the 2010-2011 winter season.  Compared to the 2009-2010 winter season when almost 1 million skiers spent $541 million, visits were down 25 percent while revenue was off $155 million during the 2010-2011 winter season.

Title: Agricultural losses in Texas reach $1.5 billion since November 2010
Description: Early estimates put agricultural losses in Texas due to drought from November 2010 through May 1, 2011 at $1.5 billion, according to the Texas AgriLife Extension Service.  The estimate includes damage to livestock, wheat, corn and sorghum.  The livestock sector alone has borne $1.2 billion in costs related to transporting water and supplemental feed.  Parts of the state have not received substantial rainfall since August 2010.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 18, 2011

Title: Oklahoma’s agricultural industry lost about $1 billion from the fall of 2010 through the end of 2011
Description: Oklahoma’s agricultural industry lost about $1 billion from the fall of 2010 through the end of 2011, due to drought, said J.D. Strong, executive director of the Oklahoma Water Resources Board.  NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), Oct. 16, 2013

Title: Apples slightly smaller in Bethel
Description: Connecticut’s apple crop was smaller and yields were down this year, due to drought and other factors, but apples were sweeter.  An East Windsor apple grower reported that yields were down 30 percent.  Journal Inquirer (Manchester, Conn.), Oct 19, 2020Apples grew to a diameter of just two to two and a half inches instead of a more typical three inches at an apple orchard in Bethel, but the drought has enhanced the sweetness in sweet apples and the tartness of the tart apples, according to the orchard owner.  Danbury News-Times (CT), Sept. 14

Title: Wildfire damage to Texas’ 94 state parks in 2011 reached $11 million
Description: Wildfire damage to Texas’ 94 state parks in 2011 reached $11 million, and visitation to parks remains below normal into 2012, according to the executive director of Texas Parks and Wildlife.  Davis Mountains, Possum Kingdom and Bastrop state parks in particular were badly damaged by wildfires.  During the first quarter of the 2012 fiscal year, which began in September, revenue was down by 8.4 percent or $928,000.  Fifty-five percent of total park funding is from visitor revenue, making the reduction in revenue worrisome.  Surveys of drought impact to more than 220 Texas lakes revealed that fifty percent of them had reduced boat and public access as water levels dropped.  Freshwater fishing license sales were 30 percent lower in 2011 than in 2010.  Non-Texas resident hunting license sales declined by 8 percent, while total hunting license sales decreased by nearly 5 percent.   Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Jan. 24, 2012
Categories: Fire, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought lowered revenue from entrance and user fees in Texas parks
Description: Entrance and use fees for Texas parks brought in roughly $1.2 million less in the 2011 fiscal year compared to the previous year, according to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department deputy executive director for operations, who attributed the decline in revenue to heat and drought.  Entrance fees and other fees, such as for overnight camping, pay for fisheries and wildlife management programs.  In the 2012 fiscal year beginning on September 1, revenue was already $2 million below projected levels for this fiscal year.  Annual income from user fees in state parks is about $38 million.  Sales of hunting and fishing licenses were about 5 percent or $2.5 million below that of the same time last year.  The sales of freshwater fishing licenses were down 17 to 20 percent, an improvement from a couple of months ago when sales were off 30 percent.  Revenue from boat registrations across Texas were down 2.5 percent.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 21, 2011

Title: About 259,000 acres burned in Georgia in past 10 months
Description: There were 8,500 blazes in Georgia since July 2010 that scorched more than 93,000 acres or 145 square miles of state land.  The Okefenokee Swamp fire has burned at least 166,000 acres of federal land since a lightning bolt started the conflagration in late April.  Combining state and federal land damaged by wildfire, roughly 259,000 acres have burned in Georgia.  Athens Banner-Herald (Ga.), June 13, 2011

Title: Excessive wildfire activity in Georgia
Description: The Georgia Forestry Commission counted 9,219 wildfires that charred at least 421,000 acres or 650 square miles. Dry conditions contributed to the high number of wildfires and acreage burned, which has already been nearly the worst year in the past ten years.  Athens Banner-Herald (Ga.), July 3, 2011

Title: Drought allowed wildfires to rekindle in Georgia
Description: There have been 8,500 blazes in Georgia that have scorched more than 93,000 acres or 145 square miles of state land since July 2010 as drought made it easier for dry vegetation and trees to burn.  The Okefenokee Swamp fire has burned at least 166,000 acres of federal land since a lightning bolt started the conflagration in late April.  When state and federal acres are combined, around 259,000 acres have burned in Georgia.  More than $20 million in timber was consumed.  The Macon Telegraph (Ga.), June 13, 2011

Title: A large portion of Texas’ warm season grass pastures still have not recovered from damage incurred during drought in 2010
Description: A large portion of Texas’ warm season grass pastures still have not recovered from damage incurred during drought in 2010, according to a Texas A&M Agricultural Extension Service forage expert.  He stated that ongoing drought, cool spring temperatures, reduced fertilizer use and overstocking were hindering pasture recovery.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Millions of trees continued to die in California's Sierra Nevada after end of drought
Description: California suffered the loss of another 18 million trees since the fall of 2017, a substantial number, but fewer than the 27 million dead trees counted in the fall of 2017 or the 62 million dead trees documented in the fall of 2016.  The return to more rainfall and less drought has helped trees resist the bark beetles that have damaged and killed so many trees.  Since drought began in 2010, more than 147 million trees on 9.7 million acres died.  The slowing rate of tree mortality was encouraging.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2019Trees continued to die in the Sierra Nevada more than a year after the end of California’s multiyear drought.  The U.S. Forest Service reported that 27 million trees died since November 2016, bringing the total of dead trees to roughly 129 million on about 8.9 million acres of land since 2010.  The trees were stressed and dehydrated by drought, making them more vulnerable to bark beetle infestations and other ills.The density of dead trees was so great in areas that foresters closed roads and campgrounds to protect the public from falling trees.  Views in Yosemite and Sequoia national parks were marred by the spectacle of rust-colored trees, as were some stretches along the coast.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Dec. 11, 2017
Places: California, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Spring crops being dusted in, prevented planting requests occurring in Bent, Kiowa, and Prowers counties in Colorado
Description: Effective precipitation has been well below normal. Wheat crop is stressing severely. Grass growth has stopped since May 15. Spring crops are being dusted in and prevented plant requests are being made.
Places: Colorado, Bent County, CO, Kiowa County, CO, Prowers County, CO

Title: Small businesses in most of Indiana eligible for disaster loans
Description: Small businesses in most Indiana counties are eligible for federal disaster loans from the Small Business Administration for financial loss due to drought in 2010.  The declaration makes small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, and nurseries eligible for loans through the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program.  Applications must be received by  September 14, 2011.  Evansville Courier and Press (IN), Jan. 29, 2011

Title: Texas groundwater being mapped from old oil and gas logs
Description: Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin are sifting through numerous oil and gas drilling logs in the Bureau of Economic Geology building to map out the locations of brackish groundwater throughout the state for the purpose of siting desalination plants.  They are also consulting well water data and other information to better understand the underground rock formations.  Measurements of a well’s naturally occurring radiation at various depths and its resistance to electrical current, data which is contained in many of the drilling records, helps determine the rock’s properties and suggests the type of water that may be in the rock.The project began in 2009 with funding from the state legislature, resulting in one complete study of the Pecos Valley Aquifer in West Texas, which was determined to contain about 4.9 trillion gallons of fresh water and 27.7 trillion gallons of brackish water.  Studies of the Carrizo-Wilcox Aquifer in Central Texas and the Queen City and Sparta aquifers are nearing completion.New York Times, April 10, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought emergency declared by California governor
Description: The governor of California declared a state of emergency and reiterated the request for Californians to trim their water use by 20%.  He also ordered the Department of Water Resources and the State Water Resources Control Board to hasten the water transfer process concerning the 2009 Drought Water Bank and to respond to water quality issues in the Delta.  State agencies and facilities are to immediately curb their water use in accordance with a plan drawn up by the Department of General Services.  Other agencies are given 30 days to offer mitigation plans for their respective areas for better stewardship of limited water supplies.  The drought emergency ended on March 30, 2011, after an especially wet winter.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), March 30, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The size of California’s cow herd shrank significantly
Description: The size of California’s cow herd shrank significantly after four years of severe drought in many parts of the state, according to the executive vice president of the California Cattlemen’s Association.  Western Farm Press, Nov. 28, 2012

Title: California officially in drought
Description: The governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, proclaimed that the entire state was in drought following two years of below normal amounts of precipitation.  The governor urges all Californians to reduce their water use to avoid or delay the possibility of water rationing in the event that next winter is dry.  The state Department of Water Resources is directed to expedite water transfers to areas most in need, to assist local water districts with water conservation, and to help farmers impacted by drought.  The months of March, April, and May of 2008 saw the least amounts of snowfall ever recorded for the Sierra Nevada.  The drought emergency ended on March 30, 2011, after an especially wet winter.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), March 30, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Ranchers and farmers struggling to survive; non-native plants and game animals compete with native plants and livestock on Maui
Description: As a hunter, who spends a lot of time in the field, I have noticed some disturbing weather trends. We have been experiencing drought conditions for the past four years on the island of Maui.  One of the hardest hit areas runs from Kula to Kipahulu.  Normally we rely on at least one or two Kona (from the South) storms a year, which provide the much-needed moisture for the leeward side of our islands.  With the absence of these Kona storms in less than normal trade showers these areas are becoming increasingly parched.  Ranchers and farmers struggle trying to adjust to drought conditions which are seemingly becoming the norm.  Native plants which struggle to survive become overtaken by non-native species which are more drought tolerant.  Game animals tend to gravitate to the green areas for feed.  They compete with livestock for limited grasses and damage farmers' crops for their survival.  Our normal rainy season begins in late October and runs through the end of April.  However, this year we received very little significant rainfall until mid February and things began drying up by mid March.From Bruce Faulkner, Kaupo Wildlife Club, Makawao, Hawaii, on May 1, 2012

Title: Drought declaration for Arizona extended
Description: Arizona’s Drought Interagency Coordinating Group recommended to the governor that the state’s drought-emergency declaration be extended again.  Arizona has had a Drought Emergency Declaration in effect since June 1999 and a Drought Declaration since May 2007.Pinal Central (Casa Grande, Ariz.), Nov. 12, 2020The governor of Arizona signed a Drought Declaration for the state the last week of May to promote drought awareness and to encourage people to conserve water.Impact Source:  Media
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Average net income per farm dropped in New Mexico
Description: Drought was one of the factors in the drop in average net income per farm from 2007 through 2011, according to the 2012 Agriculture Census.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture said that farmers brought in more than $17,500 in 2007, but only $9,501 in 2011.Santa Fe New Mexican (N.M.), May 4, 2014

Title: Texas’ beef industry numbers tumbled from 2005 to 2014
Description: Texas’ beef industry numbers tumbled from 5.35 million head in 2005 to 3.91 million head in 2014 as drought and reduced forage, among other factors, led ranchers to sell cattle.Cotton Grower (Cordova, Tenn.), Dec. 23, 2014

Title: Large wildfires more common in Texas, due to drought, other factors
Description: Drought, development and changes in land use in Texas have encouraged the occurrence of larger, more threatening wildfires.  Nearly 80 percent of the 157,000 wildfires that burned in the state between 2006 and 2014 burned within 2 miles of a community.  The forest service responded to only one wildfire larger than 5,000 acres between 1985 and 2000, but in the last 15 years, fires of that size have occurred almost annually.  In 2008, there were 27 fires at least that big, and in 2011, there were 76 wildfires larger than 5,000 acres.  Grazing animals were present on the landscape more frequently in previous decades, reducing the amount of vegetation, but with the increase in housing and other developments, the vegetation is no longer grazed down and becomes a fire hazard.   Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Oct. 28, 2015

Title: Drought Emergency Declaration in Arizona
Description: Arizona’s Drought Interagency Coordinating Group recommended to the governor that the state’s drought-emergency declaration be extended again.  Arizona has had a Drought Emergency Declaration in effect since June 1999 and a Drought Declaration since May 2007.Pinal Central (Casa Grande, Ariz.), Nov. 12, 2020The Governor’s Drought Interagency Coordinating Group met on Nov. 12 and recommended that the Governor extend the drought declaration for the state.  Department of Water Resources (Phoenix, Ariz.), Nov. 19, 2019
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Fewer snakebites in California after drought
Description: An analysis of snakebite data for California revealed that rattlesnakes were less likely to bite after a drought, but more likely to bite after heavy rainfall.  Researchers with Stanford University looked at data from the California Poison Control System, documenting 5,365 snakebites in California between 1997 and 2017.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Sept. 24, 2018

Title: Conservation strategies from previous droughts in California still benefiting, harming state
Description: Water managers in California learned that during previous droughts some of their strategies for weathering drought led to harmful consequences, while other strategies put water systems in a better position to withstand future droughts. Measures to deal with the 1977 drought in California resulted in some of the urban water conservation activities that have made water use more efficient in the state.  The water market was established so that water can be leased, and the Legislature passed laws to aid water trading, changes which helped the state bear the 1987-92 drought with less expense related to water shortages for cities, farms and wildlife refuges.  The California Urban Water Conservation Council, a team of urban water agencies, managed demand and curbed per capita water use beyond the end of the drought.  Mitigation planning helped make cities more drought-resistant, and years later, communities have invested in groundwater storage, new surface storage in local reservoirs, wastewater recycling and desalination.  In the Bay Area, water agencies have become interconnected to share water when needed.  Large volumes of water were exported from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta during the 1987-92 drought, affecting the flow and salinity in the delta that encouraged the proliferation of invasive species, which contributed to the loss of delta smelt and other native fish. In spite of efforts to restore the previous balance in the delta, delta smelt and other native fish populations have not rebounded.During the 2007-09 drought, San Joaquin Valley farmers received federal grants to drill wells to supplement their water supplies. Since parts of the Valley had experienced excessive groundwater withdrawals and land subsidence, additional pumping only exacerbated the subsidence and damaged the California Aqueduct. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 27, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
